If I could, I'd make this clunker drop and give me twenty push-ups for screwing a great idea up this badly.
Plagues & Pleasures on the Salton Sea is funny, enlightening, informative, and most importantly of all - admiring.
movie_title: Plagues & Pleasures on the Salton Sea (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Shoot 'Em Up is filled with ingenious moments. This movie is seriously cool.

I won't make the case that Halloween is anything other than a well-crafted slasher film. That's all it wants to be, and that's what it achieves. But I will say that the movie does the horror genre a big favor by reclaiming a legendary character.
Not exactly the Jet Li/Jason Statham battle royale we had been promised.
Somehow, after most of the other 2007 movies have faded from memory, I have a feeling that I will still remember the passion and commitment of the people I met in Air Guitar Nation.
Rowan Atkinson is one of those people who can inspire laugher with a twitch of his eyebrow or a stumble of his feet. He is this movie, and he gives us a good time.
Not just one of this year's best films, but also one my favorite westerns ever...What an entertaining, thoughtful, relevant film this is.
While it doesn't completely succeed at anything it tries to do, it succeeds sufficiently at most of them to be enjoyable.
After the potent final image of In the Valley of Elah faded to black, I had that very special tingle I get when I know I've just seen a great movie.
This movie is LAME. The dark may be rising, but the boredom is crushing.
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Director Robert Zemeckis has created a computer-animated movie is that exciting, funny, sexy, and thrilling. A genuinely cool moviegoing event.
While the movie is often undeniably amusing, it's rarely funny.
Sun Dogs is a warm, engrossing, and ultimately inspiring movie that's worth seeking out.
The problem is that Pete Jones the director has cast Pete Jones the actor in the lead role - and Pete Jones the actor is not particularly compelling.
It feels like perhaps the screenplay was intensely personal and/or autobiographical, yet it's suspiciously lacking in any dramatic tension.
This is a mesmerizing film that serves as a reminder of just how amazing our country's space exploration has been.
movie_title: Magnificent Desolation: Walking on the Moon 3D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Despite some sizeable flaws, I still recommend the movie for what it is: a laugh machine.

This is an unapologetically liberal film. Does it preach to the choir? Absolutely. My own left-leaning views being what they are, I liked it on those terms, even as I acknowledge that some complexity would have been nice.
Regardless of its PG rating, if you are a fan of Jerry Seinfeld's comedy style, then you will probably find a lot to like here. This is an incredibly witty film.
This is a great, great film.
This is one of those "feel good" movies that really does make you feel good.
Rendition is an important film. Art, by definition, is supposed to provoke, to spur emotions, to enlighten. On those counts, this movie scores a bull's-eye.
Gone Baby Gone goes beyond just being a good mystery. This is a film with something valid to say about child welfare, and it imparts its message with passion, depth, and grace.
I've seen a lot of legal dramas over the years; this is one of the best (if not the best) of them.
Ridley Scott carefully controls the tone so that we almost feel like a fly on the wall of an era in crime.
Night is definitely hampered by the fact that it has no viewpoint on history. Some satirical ideas would have elevated it onto a higher comic plane.
What's interesting about the movie is that, while it's only moderately funny, it's extremely amusing...It held my interest throughout.

Little Children is neither a sitcom nor a melodrama. Instead, it feels like real life, inhabited by real people with real problems. If this story actually happened, this is exactly how it would go down.
If you're a fan, then put this on your must-see list. If you've gotten away from Allen's movies in recent years, now is the time to come back.
Rumor Has It is a completely charming movie with terrific performances.
It's inspiring that an ultra-successful director and a major Hollywood studio would have the guts to take on such an intense topic.
Just a retread of an age old formula. The film had the potential to do something a little different with it, but didn't take the opportunity.
If you listen to Marilyn Manson, read Fangoria magazine, and do all your clothes shopping at Hot Topic, then Underworld: Evolution is the movie for you. All others needn't bother.
Nanny McPhee? Nanny McPhooey is more like it.
As a portrait of low-class desperation, Bubble is nothing short of haunting.
Not as bad as it could have been, but still a great concept with no actual substance, few scares, and lots of cliches.
Anthony Hopkins gives a performance that stands among his best, and the film has a quiet, straightforward style of storytelling that appealed to me.

Fans of the series won't be terribly disappointed, but if there's an FD4, I hope they have the sense to scale things back just a little bit. Comparing FD3 to the original proves that a modicum of restraint is most effective.

If you can divorce yourself from total allegiance to the original %u2013 or if you have no allegiance to the original - then this is an enjoyable movie with some real laughs courtesy of a modern day comic genius.
Firewall feels like other movies we've seen starring the same actor...It feels like Harrison Ford is phoning in his performance this time.
You'd be much better off watching any of the films that Date Movie parodies than you would be watching this one.
Sometimes movie biographies (even when dealing with fascinating people) are dry and familiar. Capote, on the other hand, is full of life.
Eight Below is so filled with action, adventure, and genuine emotion that it's easy to ignore the few little things that don't work.
If Running Scared is supposed to be a satire, it's not funny enough to work. If it's meant to be taken seriously, then it's the most unintentionally funny movie of the past ten years.
Ultraviolet is all second act. There is no beginning to the story and no end; it's all middle. A non-sensical, hard to follow assemblage of action, completely devoid of any context.

As you would expect, this is not an easy film to watch. It is intensely sad and it brings up powerful emotions. At the same time, I did not leave the theater emotionally wrecked. United 93 is ultimately a healing experience.
I liked the passion with which the story argued its point about unfairness in gymnastic judging. But - and this is a big but - I didn't believe the plot twist that is used to make the point.
You know exactly what you're going to get, and you get it. Is that so wrong?
Thank You For Smoking looks for laughs in a topic that is (literally) deadly serious. It finds them, and at the same time it also finds meaning.
The Benchwarmers doesn't know what it wants to be, so it ends up a mostly unsatisfying mixture of sweet and sour.
You know that kid in school who would eat anything just for the fun of grossing people out? Well, Slither is the movie equivalent of that kid.
Fun with Dick and Jane produces a handful of big laughs - big enough to make it worth a recommendation.

For whatever it lacks in the way of a compelling story, Ice Age: The Meltdown still manages to give family audiences what they want and expect: lovable characters, gorgeous computer-generated animation, and laughter.

Failure to Launch shoots itself in the foot by refusing to take its premise seriously. The very thing that seems most interesting is the same thing that the film goes out of its way to avoid dealing with.
Under the guise of comic book entertainment, the movie asks ambitious questions and raises provocative issues. The end result is uniquely cool.
Anybody given the assignment to write a movie in which a man turns into a dog would come up with these same jokes.
We've all heard of movies being "so bad they're good." The Hills Have Eyes may be the first recorded case of a movie being so good it's bad.
One of the worst dramas I have ever seen. In fact, this movie is so dramatically inept that I wanted to tear my eyeballs out.
The theme of racial self-empowerment runs throughout Dave Chappelle's Block Party. I don't think the comedian just wanted to organize a concert. I think he wanted to encourage positivity.
I still want Spike Lee to make the challenging independent features for which he has become well known. However, as a detour into more mainstream filmmaking, Inside Man is genuinely satisfying.
Watching it isn't like seeing something new and exciting; it's like re-watching a good movie you've already seen.
The film throws so much information at you so quickly and so relentlessly that it's easy to become overwhelmed and confused.
One of the things I like about The Family Stone is that the characters seem real. They may have some quirks, but they're realistic quirks, not those devised by an overly clever screenwriter.
The often-funny chemistry between Jackson and Levy makes it worth a look, but you'd probably be happier paying to see it on video.
August Rush kind of feels like a 2-hour coming attractions preview. Lots of fragmented stuff happens, without ever connecting the dots in between.
It uses the horror genre to say something and, despite some elements that could have been stronger, it generally succeeds.
Ruffalo and Witherspoon bring conviction to their roles; they're taking the story seriously and that allows us to do the same.
Moral ambiguity has rarely been so well done on screen.
Burton and his crew have once again challenged the medium and come with something appealingly unique.
When the movie was over, I stepped out into the daylight and felt a weird sensation. It was a form of relief. The suspense had gotten to me more deeply than I expected.
Although it works in as a pleasantly mindless thriller, the film never reaches its full potential because it can't decide what it is ultimately going to be about.
All I can say is that I really enjoyed Serenity, and I plan on getting my hands on that "Firefly" DVD to see what I missed.
Many films only pay lip service to the theme of familial conflict. This one really explores the way pain and love are often hopelessly intertwined in relationships.
Satisfying family entertainment that will please fans and newbies alike.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: [David Cronenberg] no doubt wanted to say something profound about the nature of violence, but his approach betrays his intentions.
Elizabethtown is a wonderful comedy/drama about those moments in life when you get lost and have to find your way back again.
North Country works as a portrayal of social injustice, yet it also works as a compelling character portrait. One of the best and most powerful pictures of the year.
You're supposed to watch a movie and play a videogame; they want us to watch a videogame (which is not fun) and feel like we're playing a movie (which is not possible).
The movie needed to be sexier and edgier than it is.
The movie is fun for all ages, and besides - who could resist this charming, insecure, heroic little clucker?
King Kong is an adrenaline-pumping joyride that you won't soon forget. However, what really makes this a masterpiece is that Jackson understands every emotional beat of the story.
In some ways it is a very good picture, yet it also should have been better than it is...You can feel The Chronicles of Narnia trying too hard to be the Next Big Thing.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: While the harmfulness of McCarthyism is a significant part of the film, it approaches the subject by examining the power of the media.
The movie should have been called Aeon Sucks.
If you're a fan of Adult Swim %u2013 or of cutting-edge humor %u2013 then "Mission Hill" is something you need to discover.
This is a vibrant, funny film that doesn't feel like a period piece. (And I mean that as a big compliment.)
The most beautiful thing about this film %u2013 which is full of beautiful things %u2013 is that it's a love story through and through. Humanity, not sexuality, is the heart of this tale.
The Ice Harvest delivers a nice mix of humor, tension, and seediness.
The Harry Potter series just keeps getting better and more interesting.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The sentiments are right on the money, but the execution never quite filled me with holiday cheer.
These two characters - who seem like polar opposites on the surface -come together to create a great American love story.
Here's a film that is stuffed with cleverness and imagination - one that taps into some of the most primal childhood fantasies of adventure.
Director [Jim Sheridan] was a good choice: he understands the story's theme and he captures the gritty feel of [50's] world without ever falling into exploitation.
Jarhead is a powerful, darkly funny look at the toll that comes when preparedness collides head-on with boredom.

Rent may not be the same transformative experience on film as it was on the stage, but Jonathan Larson's creation is strong enough to withstand a shift in mediums with plenty of its appeal still intact.
An honest, intense look at the kind of day-to-day survival that too many Americans must contend with...This is absolutely one of my favorite movies of the year.
In a time when so many "family" films are lazy or send mixed messages, it's incredibly refreshing to see one that is as brainy, funny, and charming as Hoot.
Just My Luck is the cinematic equivalent of stepping on a crack and breaking your mama's back.
There is absolutely nothing hip or cool about Everyone's Hero, but it's so sweet, and so pleasant, and so nice that I found it impossible to dislike.
The film gets worse the longer it goes on, as Brian De Palma slowly loses confidence in his story and starts trying to compensate for it by engaging in overwrought melodramatics.
An entertaining and admirably ambitious movie that promises a feast of martial arts combat, which it delivers along with a poignant message of peace.
movie_title: Jet Li's Fearless (Huo Yuan Jia) (Legend of a Fighter) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: I laughed more in the first fifteen minutes than I have in the entirety of any 90-minute comedy this year. At the risk of sounding like a sicko, I liked this depraved movie a lot.
School for Scoundrels has all the raw elements needed to be a classic comedy, but it never finds the right rhythm. The movie is ostensibly about cruelty and calculation, yet its tone is too nice.
An excellent film that deserves to put Ryan Gosling in the running for an Oscar nomination.
I liked the movie thanks largely to Dane Cook and Dax Shepard. These are funny guys who really know how to (no pun intended) sell the material. And I bought it.
Only time will tell if it takes its place alongside Scorsese classics Taxi Driver, Raging Bull and Goodfellas; I have a feeling it just might.
It's hard to know where to begin with this sorry sequel, because when it was over, I felt like I hadn't actually seen a movie. Everything about it just evaporates immediately.

The Prestige quite brilliantly replicates the experience of a great magic trick. You know what you have just seen isn't possible, and while you recognize some of the trickery, you can't spell it all out. You walk away completely amazed.
The characters in this movie don't talk like real people; they all talk like overly clever screenwriters.
This is anything but a big-budget exercise in flag waving. Instead, it is a deeply provocative deconstruction of the very idea of heroism.
This is a genuinely nice movie that wears its old-fashioned values proudly, and I had a good time watching it. Flicka is for the teenage girl in all of us.
. Vikings has energy and a palpable passion for its subject matter that keeps you involved. It serves as a nice general introduction that may stimulate viewers to learn more.
Bah humbug! The Santa Clause 3 is a lump of coal in your stocking. It's at the top of the "naughty" list. It's about as appealing as a stale fruitcake.
movie_title: The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Wordplay gave me new respect for the intelligence of those who solve them well, and admiration for those who create them.
Borat is a full-throttle comedy experience. You don't just laugh at it - you howl, often uncontrollably. I can't remember the last time a movie so completely made me go insane with laughter.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The documentary is appropriate for family viewing, and it espouses positive values about having pride in your community as well as in yourself.

I wish that I could push aside a filing cabinet somewhere and crawl through a secret passageway into Malkovich's brain for 15 minutes, just so I could learn what he was thinking when he signed on for this movie.
Blood Diamond is unapologetically political, but if you're going to do this kind of thing, this is the way to do it. The film works as a message movie, yet it's also terrific entertainment.
A motion picture depicting the birth of the Savior ought to stir the soul, not just pass time during a frantic holiday season.
What I resent most about Bobby is that it's so obvious that it has no ability to be meaningful. It's like making a movie about how the ocean is wet. Who doesn't know that?
I wasn't always sure what I was watching, or who thought it up, but it was always amusing and never boring.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The 126-minute film would have benefited from a slight trim, but I still found a lot of interest in the story's depiction of broken dreams and broken lives.
There's scarcely a moment in the film that is plausible, but that's okay. This is fantasy, and it's fantasy that is entertaining and suspenseful throughout.
Casino Royale maintains Bond on the same level quality-wise; it's good but not the great film I keep waiting for.
Last King powerfully explores the duality between congeniality and brutality.
While I wish it had been more solid in its story, I still like the movie and recommend it. There's enough here that's great to offset the shakier stuff.
The course A Good Year takes feels like it's on rails: there's only one possible destination and only one way to get there.
There may have been some room for improvement, but the movie still has a lot of things to recommend it. Stranger Than Fiction is funny and poignant at the same time.
The Return doesn't have enough scares to be a good thriller, and it doesn't have the depth to work on an arty level. This isn't a bad movie; it's just painfully thin.

Babel is the kind of movie I would recommend to a specific audience. If you don't mind sitting and soaking up the little details and absorbing a theme as deep as it will go, then you may agree that this film is quite rewarding.
You're not going to get a lot of intelligence, or a lot of logic, or a lot of mental stimulation. But if it's thrills you're looking for, M:I 3 delivers.
The Illusionist is cleverly conceived and executed. It's the kind of movie that absorbs you, holding you in its spell for nearly two hours.
All in all, I would categorize The Wicker Man as an interesting failure.
The film is concerned only with getting to the action, with no intention of exploring the horror of an unexpected tragedy or its impact on the people involved.
A charming film, nicely animated and containing sufficient laughs to be worth taking your family to see.
The Da Vinci Code is baloney, but as a film, I have to admit that it's entertaining baloney.
It's gratifying to see the X-Men movies be about something rather than just trying to be mindless action thrill rides.
One of the things that is most intriguing about The Break-Up is how it shows the cruelty that people can inflict upon one another as soon as love fades.
If you've enjoyed the other Pixar entries, then Cars won't disappoint. It's another grand slam from the masters of animation.
Younger viewers may find this new movie more exciting; anyone with a memory of the old Gregory Peck version will most likely feel a sensation of "been there, done that."
I kept waiting for it to get really funny and it never did.
Reeves and Bullock bring the right balance of emotions to their roles. They give The Lake House its humor, its drama, and its undeniable romantic spirit.
It's a flawed film, but most people go to Adam Sandler movies to just unwind and have fun. It works at that level.
I can't necessarily say that I'd be more inclined to listen to the show [on the radio], but I was surprised by how much I enjoyed it on the big screen.

The movie is probably about as good a Superman epic as you can get without taking some crazy, universe-shaking chances. This one's a safe-but-solid start; maybe the next one will take it to a new level.
A clever, funny look at the way we sometimes risk selling our souls in the name of success.
I'll admit that the film is intermittently amusing, but it also reeks of the dreaded "bigger, louder, more" syndrome that has undone many a sequel.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Like the main character, the movie is okay at first but eventually wears out its welcome.
Clerks II is a perfect example of what a sequel should be. It takes characters and situations that were created in the original, then expands and deepens them.
I was wondering whether Summer 2006 was going to provide me with a genuine 4-star, this-is-what-I-love-about-movies experience. And then I saw Monster House.
There's an old slogan for a popular beer company: "Tastes great, less filling." Beerfest would certainly have tasted better had it been less filling by about 30 minutes.
Looking For Comedy in the Muslim World is full of Albert Brooks' trademark jokes and absurd scenarios.
movie_title: Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Like Garden State or Sideways, the film uses comedy to find the content in the lives of its characters. Little Miss Sunshine is funny, touching, and unexpectedly inspiring.

One important reason why Snakes on a Plane works is "supercool" Samuel L. Jackson. Quite honestly, I don't think the film would be as good if it were Josh Lucas, or Dennis Quaid, or Kurt Russell fighting the snakes.
Think about it too much and the whole thing falls apart; sit back, relax, and don't analyze it and the movie is pretty darn entertaining.
In all truthfulness, Zoom was better than I thought it would be...and by that, I mean that it didn't completely suck.
Watch it passively and you might wonder how it even qualifies as a movie; watch it with your full attention and you will see a charming and surprisingly meaningful look at adolescent angst.

Realistically speaking, this is a nice, inoffensive little movie that won't knock the socks off those of us who know the time-tested formula but will enthrall younger viewers who are unfamiliar with it.
All the cows have udders - even the male ones. In real life, only female cows have udders. What kind of sick, alternate cow universe does this movie take place in anyway?
I think they ought to just give Maggie Gyllenhaal the Oscar right now. She's that good.
Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby finds Will Ferrell in top form and in the right big-screen vehicle, delivering one of the funniest movies of the year.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: I say, bring back the pastel suits, the flamingos, and the Jan Hammer score. You can keep Phil Collins, though.
There's quite a bit of inventiveness here, which I found myself getting caught up in, even though it was a foregone conclusion where the film was heading.
Have you ever been approached by someone who was really drunk, and they tell you some rambling, incoherent story? Well, that's what watching this movie is like.
Pulse is a lesson in Horror Filmmaking 101 - a generic, uninspired slog through just about every single genre cliché ever committed to celluloid.
If Mel Gibson remade Apocalypto and cast it with the Geico cavemen, he might end up with something akin to 10,000 B.C..
The movie would almost doubtlessly have garnered Oscar nominations for its two stars had it been released theatrically.
Have you ever seen a movie that you knew was significantly flawed, yet you kind of liked it anyway? That's how I felt about Drillbit Taylor.
Couples Retreat is like watching somebody's boring vacation videos, except that they're filled with big stars.
The mixture of gruesome revenge picture and self-satisfied message movie is deeply off-putting.
A work of genuine imagination and intelligence that doesn't try to ram the same old feel-good platitudes down our collective throat.
Starts off strongly, which only makes its drastic eventual decline that much more disappointing. What could have been a really quirky, edgy teen horror comedy instead turns into a crushing bore.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This is the rare fright flick that is actually grounded in some genuine human emotion.
Paranormal Activity goes on the short list of films that totally, completely freaked me out.
This Is It avoids the kind of messianic fervor that characterized Jackson's career. The man's work is simply allowed to speak for itself. There could be no more fitting tribute.
This is a little movie well worth checking out. The performances are very natural, and the themes are enticingly provocative.
If you like horror movies that actually have some artistic merit to them, this is definitely one of the more noteworthy pictures of the year.
It falls a bit short of the high bar it has set for itself, yet I respect the film's willingness to aim that high. And it does get enough right to be worth seeing.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A boring, stupid, overlong, obnoxious, soulless piece of Hollywood "product."
The film has a profound and compelling premise. Regrettably, it seems intent on being about everything but that premise.
A cool, philosophical mindfreak.
A tiny little piece of awesomeness.
Shorts is constantly pinballing back and forth, from one thing to the next, in such a hyperactive fashion that one wishes it would just slow down a bit.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Watching New Moon is like being trapped in a room for two hours with a moody teenage girl who won't stop whining about how her boyfriend dumped her.
Painfully pretentious and shallow.
The Book of Eli has something extremely thoughtful to say and it was designed to make you think about what it is saying. This film grew on me in a big way.
The first 45 minutes are great. The last 30 minutes are also great. The problem is the 45 minutes in the middle, which are bogged down with unnecessary visual effects.
You've seen this movie before dozens of times under dozens of different titles. What's the point in seeing it again under this title?
The songs here are not particularly catchy, and while the choreography and set design are tops, they do little to elevate the almost relentlessly somber mood.
Like too many horror franchises, a premise that was once scary has evolved into something campy and self-aware.

Beautifully and effectively crafted in every single way, the film looks unflinchingly into desperate lives and finds hope amidst the despair. This is truly a masterpiece of slice-of-life storytelling.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: While The Informant! has a lot going for it stylistically, the entertainment value is sorely lacking.
One of the warmest, funniest, and most insightful movies of the year.
Crazy Heart is more of a character study than a plot-driven film, but we've got a genuinely compelling character to examine here.
Invictus shouldn't feel like just another sports movie; it should feel like a life movie. What a missed opportunity.
Getting your uvula pierced would be less painful than watching Old Dogs.
A gruesome, edgy, ambitious, and sometimes funny horror tale that doesn't shy away from exploring adolescent cruelty.
This is a sad story, no doubt, yet also one that leaves us with a bit of hope. All in all, a profoundly affecting and meaningful movie.
Ninja Assassin could - and should - have been the Zombieland of martial arts flicks. Instead, it's just totally skip-able.
I'd be hard-pressed to recall another movie that so fully transported me to a world that doesn't exist. Avatar is one of the most exciting and thrilling moviegoing experiences I've ever had.
Extraordinary Measures skips over some of the most potentially dramatic stuff [in this semi-true story]. The movie undermines its own drama.
A funny, cleverly-conceived, heartfelt expression of a point of view that is not nearly my own.

The problem is simple: it's too short. The story introduces a series of gripping elements, then fails to fully capitalize on a single one of them. With a running time of just 88 minutes, how could it?
The Cell 2 takes one of the most original and disturbing horror movies of recent years and turns it into a generic torture porn flick.
Rarely in the history of cinema have so many genuinely funny people come together to make a film that is so painfully unfunny to watch.
If there's a problem for me with Inkheart, it is one of scope. This feels like it should be an epic movie, but it's not.
A great example of moviemaking on autopilot. The screenplay not only heads for the predicable finish line, it also makes sure to hit all the predictable stops along the way.

The bottom line for me is that Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen simply wasn't as much fun as the original. In their zeal to give us more of what they think we want, Bay and crew have sucked all the joy out of their own franchise.
Hal Ashby's cut of Lookin' to Get Out is a movie that deserves to be rediscovered.
Public Enemies is, at its core, a fascinating portrait of criminal narcissism.
The way the film exposes, tries, convicts, and administers punishment to homophobes - through humor rather than preachiness - had me laughing for 82 straight minutes.
I don't believe in magic, but I do believe in "movie magic," and this sixth installment has it.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: My problem with the film is that Larry Doyle (who also penned the screenplay) seems to have softened what his novel was fundamentally about.
G-Force is being shown in both 2-D and digital 3-D formats. I saw it in 2-D, and that's the preferred format because it's one less dimension for the movie to suck in.
The Answer Man is like a great big breath of fresh air on the first nice day of spring. It is a story with characters who feel real, as they try to find real answers to real problems.
The plot isn't entirely successful in achieving the farcical tone it aims for.
Superhero tales are best when they strive for some complexity; this one has an engrossing plot and some solid character development that grown-ups can appreciate.
I liked the Gerard Butler half of The Ugly Truth; the Katherine Heigl half, not so much.
Hilarious while also being poignant and wise, Funny People is, hands down, my favorite movie of the summer.
"The Mighty Boosh" is so weird, so unpredictable, and so incessantly funny that I became completely hooked before the first episode was over.
I Can Do Bad All By Myself may not be a model of tonal restraint, but it's well acted, it's funny, the music is phenomenal, and the religion is sincere.
movie_title: I Can Do Bad All By Myself (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A good example of how someone [like writer Diablo Cody] with a fresh perspective and an original voice can make even a genre picture better.
Ideally, you want to see the male and female leads end up together in a romantic comedy; if not, it all starts to become kind of creepy.
The fact that 9 looks so breathtakingly vivid and alive is reason enough to catch it on the big screen.
It has a great cast, an original thriller setting, and a compelling concept, and yet the central mystery is surprisingly limp.
I didn't dislike Extract by any stretch of the imagination, but it's not necessarily the kind of movie that's worth going out of your way to see, especially at full price.
Zombieland makes undead cinema fresh again. This movie is just ridiculously, insanely, enormously entertaining.
I loved (500) Days of Summer for many reasons, but for this one the most: I felt more during this movie than I have in any other romantic comedy in years.
I think this is a key work in Tarantino's career, because it shows that he can pull off a masterpiece without resorting too much to his well-established bag of tricks.
Smart, provocative, fun, and exciting...District 9 is everything that Transformers 2 and G.I. Joe tried - and failed - to be.
With a comedy like this, you want to be laughing constantly, not every 15 or 20 minutes.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: While it's not in the same classic league, the movie has a nice Back to the Future vibe to it.
I don't mind if something blows up every five minutes so long as I'm given a reason to care why something is blowing up every five minutes.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Meryl Streep and Amy Adams are great fun to watch, and Streep could well earn yet another Oscar nomination.
After the success of his original, director Rob Zombie warned fans that he had no intention of making a cheesy sequel. Oh, how I wish he'd stayed true to that promise.

The great irony of the new big-screen Land of the Lost adaptation is that the filmmakers have spent a reported $100 million to make a movie that looks like it cost $1.95. And you know what? In a weird kind of way, I actually appreciate that ethic
If someone offers you the choice between seeing Tooth Fairy or getting a root canal, opt for the root canal. It'll be less painful.
A disposable piece of action fluff that never satisfies our hunger for fun.
Jonah Hex is a no doubt a bad film. That said, it has enough good elements to make you realize that it could have been awesome.
A smart, engrossing, and entertaining crash course in the study of What It All Means.
A Star is Born totally lives up to its reputation. The performances are great, and the story is the sort that completely sucks you in.
This is another home run for Pixar. A perfect conclusion to a perfect movie trilogy.
Why try to be clever when you can have someone land face-first in a pile of animal feces instead? Ah, feces - an appropriate visual metaphor for Grown Ups.
I enjoyed Eclipse about as much as someone outside the target audience can, but that still isn't enough to merit an outright recommendation.
Knight and Day works due to the charms of Diaz and Cruise, and it figures out how to exaggerate action without making the audience feel insulted.
Producer Robert Rodriguez has assembled a team of filmmakers to create what feels like the only genuine Predator sequel to date.
The thing the film does best is to put a human face on the issue, to show us individuals (and couples) who were directly affected by the passing of Prop 8.
Anyone who cherishes Robert Altman's work definitely needs to see this defiantly kooky comedy.
This is not only the best movie ever made about dreams, it is also one of the best films of 2010, and certainly one of the most entertaining pictures I've seen in a decade.
Doghouse is in no way substantive, but it is kind of an enjoyable goof, if you're in the mood for such a thing.
A major dud - a picture that isn't smart, isn't fun, and is really just a great big waste of time.
Dinner for Schmucks has a certain rhythm to it. I chuckled pretty regularly, then every so often something hilarious would happen, and I'd be full-on laughing.
For whatever imperfections it may have, the combination of Gru, the minions, some cool animation, and a lot of wit make Despicable Me worth taking the whole family to see.
I really enjoyed being dropped into this family's world for two hours. The Kids Are All Right is one of my favorite movies so far in 2010.
Not Will Ferrell's best, but still solid.
I don't mind exaggerated action sequences (in fact, I kind of like them) but Transporter 2 doesn't surround them with anything else.
Alien Autopsy is breezy and funny, with an energy that really keeps you involved.
Make Me Young captures the weird delusional effect anti-aging addiction has. Apparently, many people don't care if they look like complete freaks so long as they have no frown lines.
movie_title: Make me Young: Youth Knows No Pain (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Like Dandelion Dust is a movie that pulls you in and holds you, anchored by strong performances and a recognition that to love a child is to love oneself.
Easy A is a Clueless for the 21st century. It's smart, funny, and relevant to the target audience.
The Player can be admired even more now than it was at the time, because it so succinctly diagnosed the sickness that still causes Hollywood to churn out too much soulless "product."
The A-Team really didn't need to do anything other than to be fun, but it can't even get that right.
While the movie itself is no great shakes, the 3D is awesomely fun.
A fun B-movie. You're not likely to remember it a year from now, but sometimes lightweight entertainment is okay, especially when it's done with a wink, a smile, and a severed head.
I can't quite recommend it unless you just want to see any new movie about zombies that comes down the pike. You haven't seen this one before, but you have, and you've seen it better.
A nice little late-summer surprise, a horror film with a shred of intelligence and uncommonly good performances.
The Expendables is admirable for bringing these actors all together, but shameful for not having the integrity to do anything of value with them.
A gory, self-aware joyride that is insane in all the right ways.
An energetic ode to youthful preoccupations, as well as a fun 21st century romance.
I felt affection for the film growing as I watched. It pulled me in with its warmth and its performances.
The weightiness and the catastrophic implications of the conspiracy don't sit well with what is essentially a Death Wish-inspired revenge fantasy.
Here is a fright flick that is completely original, that takes you to uncomfortable places and abandons you there. If you care at all about horror, do not miss Splice under any circumstances.
As dull as the story may be, the fighting scenes are admittedly impressive.
You can constantly feel The Time Traveler's Wife reaching for emotional depth, yet it never gets there.
The fundamental problem with the film is that it doesn't know whether it wants to be old-fashioned or cutting edge.
Mildly amusing, although not the timelessly anarchic, Hangover-style comedy it clearly wants to be.
movie_title: I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Consistently engaging, with an appealing sense of relevance for today's audiences.
Shutter Island is a hypnotic and disturbing thriller. A near-masterpiece.
Why someone would want to lay bare their parents' marital issues for the world to see is beyond me, but that doesn't detract from the film's insightfulness.
I was really hoping that Kevin Smith would mix all his 80's inspirations together and come up with something new - kind of like Quentin Tarantino does with his influences. That doesn't happen.
The Crazies is creepy and it made me squirm with discomfort.
Alice is a really good time, as well as a great example of how 3-D can be effectively used as a tool to immerse us in imaginary worlds.
A genre picture that reveals some strong qualities before going just a bit off the rails during the home stretch.
While not exactly topical in the provocation department, it is nevertheless a smart, exciting, and relevant thriller.
Cynically conceived, unfunny, non-romantic sludge.
An animated movie with the courage to take itself seriously and entertain you by being genuinely good, as opposed to tricking itself out with pointless hipness.
The whole movie is kind of old-fashioned but also kind of modern at the same time, and I think that contrast is a big part of its appeal.
On an action movie/creature feature level, it delivers satisfactorily. On a plot/characterization level, it's a complete bore.
Hot Tub Time Machine represents an example of the phenomenon known as Great Title, Middling Execution.
Somehow, in an act of sheer alchemy, this silly, preposterous, absurd story has been turned into one of the funniest movies I've seen in many months.
The weaknesses of the picture suggest that there really isn't anywhere else to go beyond this, but as long as they stop now, the series can always be remembered as a pleasurable one.
These characters had a great run, but based on this sorry sequel, there's nothing interesting left to do with them.
Once again, it is proven that "SNL" sketches are probably best left in New York, live, on a Saturday night.
No Time For Sergeants is ripe for re-discovery by a new generation, and ripe for re-visiting by those who remember it fondly.
With so many stars and so many subplots jammed into two hours, the film has all the emotional depth of an episode of "The Love Boat."
Whiny and self-indulgent.
I laughed quite frequently and recommend the picture on that count, but Greek's insights into the "sex, drugs, rock and roll" mindset are what really turn it into something special.
An exercise in tedium.
While the plot is not as tight as it could be, Iron Man 2 still delivers in every other way.
The film is strange, disturbing, gross, and shocking. I loved it!
The Back-Up Plan represents a major comeback for Jennifer Lopez. Unfortunately, she's come back to making crap.
The Nightmare on Elm Street reboot has more in common with the later, lame-o sequels than with the one it is technically remaking.
The Losers is a 14 year-old boy's example of freakin' awesome: it has lots of shootouts, lots of explosions, and lots of gratuitous close-ups of Zoe Saldana's butt.
The movie has a high cool quotient for sure, but it also has some substance underneath it all. This is an enormously entertaining film that offers plenty of style, humor, and excitement.

I wish the film had hit a little harder or had a few unpredictable plot elements, but as far as Christian movies aiming to make mainstream headway are concerned, this is certainly one of the better ones I've seen.
You know all those referential spoofs we've been getting lately (Epic Movie, Scary Movie, Meet the Spartans, etc.)? Well, Doomsday is like one of those, except played completely straight.
It's not the most exciting movie I've ever seen, but it is a solid thriller with good performances and a workman-like construction from Tony Scott.
It's no surprise that Up was chosen to open the Cannes Film Festival. This is a work of art.
When I have children, this is the kind of movie I hope they will like. It's intelligent, it's meaningful, and it doesn't condescend to kids. In fact, it actually encourages kids to think.
Not just a comic book movie but a virtual dissertation on the nature of good and evil, as well as the thin line that sometimes separates them.
Given that we have a gorgeously-animated, beautifully-constructed interstellar fantasy like Wall-E currently in theaters, why would anybody waste their time on Space Chimps?
Unlike Old School or Anchorman, this isn't a Will Ferrell movie that you'll want to watch over and over or quote back and forth with your friends.
I tapped my foot, I smiled, and I found myself undeniably amused. If that's the kind of experience you're looking for, and if you dig ABBA, this crazy, sloppy, mixed-up movie might just be for you.
This is the worst kind of sequel - the kind of that reeks of having been made purely for the paycheck. It's time to seal this Mummy back up into its crypt and keep it there.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: In 2-D, Journey to the Center of the Earth would be okay, I guess, but you'd be more apt to notice the cardboard characters, or the thin plotting, or the way each grave danger seems to be easily solved. In 3-D, however, it's a complete blast.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A surprisingly funny and astute satire of the two-party political system.
There's a very strong spiritual underside to The X-Files: I Want to Believe. It gives the story a lot of emotional weight, while also making the creepy stuff that much more disturbing.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Pineapple Express pulls off the amazing trick of elevating the stoner comedy into something resembling art.
If you read Entertainment Weekly from cover to cover, devour the bonus features on your DVDs, and watch the E! network religiously, then Tropic Thunder is a comedy custom made for you.
Watching the computer-animated Star Wars: The Clone Wars, I felt a most unusual mixture of delight and regret.
Most sequels are worse than the originals. A few are better. Here's one that is exactly as good as the one that inspired it, and that's enough for me.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: I had a really good time watching The Rocker. I laughed, I tapped my foot to the music, and I reveled in the extraordinary Rainn Wilson.
Terminator fans can rejoice in the fact that they got this show fundamentally right.
If The House Bunny catches on with audiences, it could do for Anna Faris what Legally Blonde did for Reese Witherspoon.
There's something admirable about a comedy that celebrates the provocative nature of art, even if that comedy doesn't quite provoke as much as it could have.
One has to wonder why director Robert B. Weide ("Curb Your Enthusiasm") chose to artificially pump up the comedy rather than find it naturally in the situations.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Forget politics: An American Carol sucks simply because it's ridiculously, painfully unfunny.
Nick & Norah's Infinite Playlist is everything a teen movie should be: smart, hip, identifiable, and with a touch of sarcasm.
The story goes from being a paranoid post-9/11 nightmare to being a goofy piece of sci-fi junk.
Slacker Uprising is a minor Michael Moore work, without a doubt. It's for hardcore fans only. If you're one of them, it's worth a look, but don't expect to be blown away.
It's terrific entertainment all the way around. Do yourself a favor. Go see it.
Hellboy II: The Golden Army hits just the right mixture of style, comedy, action, and character development. Here's hoping for a third installment.
The picture manages to juggle both the silly and the sentimental without falling flat.
This is the sort of thing the Coens do best: mixing sweet and sour to twist your emotions on a dime.
Every so often, a movie comes along that knocks the wind out of you. Snow Angels is one of them.

The thing that shocked me most was how the movie felt like some cheap-o straight-to-DVD thriller. The production values - from cinematography to editing to musical score - are little more than adequate.
Bangkok isn't dangerous so much as really, really boring.
Vicky Cristina Barcelona comes closer than anything to exploring Allen's famous quote (made in a time of personal scandal), "the heart wants what it wants."

After 75 minutes of carefully establishing the characters and situations, the film comes up with the single most preposterous ending I've ever witnessed in a motion picture, undermining everything that's come before.
Aside from the weak final act, this is a movie about black and white that refreshingly focuses on the gray.
Visually stunning, historically interesting, and very entertaining.
Of all the animated superhero DVDs that have come out in the last few years, this one is the best.

While by no means a perfect film, I still found a lot to enjoy here. There have been at least two dozen superhero movies in the last six or seven years. It's kind of nice to see one that looks at things from the other side of the coin.
21 is not the deepest or most emotionally resonant of the casino films, and it doesn't completely get the psychology of gambling, but it's a lot of fun nonetheless.
Superhero Movie is the living definition of "hit or miss." Parts of it admittedly made me laugh out loud, but for every joke that scored, there were two that didn't.
It wouldn't be at all accurate to say that I disliked Leatherheads; I simply found myself kind of stunned that all the good stuff didn't somehow add up to more.
It's just weird: the movie fixed the flaws in the book, but screwed up the stuff that was most effective on the page. Go figure.
Smart People has its finger on an idea that has become an adage: some folks are book-smart but life-dumb. I found the film fascinating.
The 1980 Prom Night was by no means a masterpiece, yet it begs the question of the remake: If you're going to make a slasher movie and you take out all the actual slashing, what else is left?

The movie is very wise, but also unbelievably funny, proving again that the line between comedy and tragedy is a thin one. Forgetting Sarah Marshall makes you laugh and squirm in recognition at the same time.

I'm totally in the target audience for this film, having long been a fan of both actors as well as the genre itself. But the fact is that this thing just didn't work for me, and I'm completely frustrated by that.
Isn't it amazing that a "stoner comedy" could be so profound?
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The comedy teams longtime "Saturday Night Live" vets Tina Fey and Amy Poehler - two of the funniest individuals on the planet, in my opinion - for a comedy that distinctly exploits their synergistic comic sensibilities.

The film nevertheless makes the crucial decision to set its story in the real world, to have its characters face real moral decisions with real consequences. And then, when Iron Man does show up for battle, this flick just soars.
You get the strong impression that no one involved wanted to risk being labeled "depressing," so they inserted a lot of lame comic moments into a film that doesn't need them.
What I loved about Speed Racer is that the Wachowski brothers didn't even try to make it look realistic. It blows past exaggeration into the area of the sublime.
Ultimately, What Happens in Vegas resembles a drunken night in Sin City; when it's over, you don't really remember what happened except that it wasn't good.
I probably would have stopped short of recommending Botched theatrically, but on DVD it's definitely worth a look.
Not the Greatest Movie Ever, but exactly what it should be: a solid, thrill-packed, immensely entertaining chapter in one of the most enjoyable adventure series in movie history.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This sorry sequel is so boring, so unimaginative, and so blandly by-the-numbers that it's almost like [an affront] to the very audience members who made the original a worldwide hit.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Periodically you see a film that is so jacked up on adrenaline that the audience gets a palpable contact high. Wanted fits squarely into this category.
I think Wall-E is a masterpiece. The folks at Pixar never rest on their laurels. They continue to push the limits of both computer animation and the storytelling possibilities that accompany it.

Perhaps Myers was so enchanted by his own desire to bring spiritualism to the masses that he forgot to actually bring the funny with it. Whatever the case, this is a shockingly laugh-free motion picture.
Get Smart is an example of getting the right actors and taking the right approach...It gave me one of the most fun times I've had at the movies all year.
The cast is good and the themes are compelling, but the execution is a bit of a mess.
DVD is the perfect place for a movie like Rails & Ties. Somehow it's easier to block out the often forced nature of the plot and just enjoy the rich performances and the humane themes.
It doesn't necessarily stand alone, although if you saw Get Smart and liked the Bruce and Lloyd characters, then you can get a certain level of enjoyment out of their pseudo-sequel.
movie_title: Get Smart's Bruce and Lloyd Out of Control (2008)

movie_review_blurb: In terms of being faithful to the comic and giving us the kind of big screen superhero entertainment that we want, The Incredible Hulk is definitely the more satisfying of the two.
You Don't Mess With the Zohan tries to mix high-brow satire with low-brow gross-out humor. The combination kills the story's pacing.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: There's an old saying about how a great musical will "leave 'em dancing in the aisles." Well this movie provides the kung fu equivalent of that.
I expected to laugh a lot harder and more frequently. Mama's Boy isn't what I'd call a terrible movie. Instead, it's a movie that assembles a lot of interesting elements that never gel.

After several years of "torture porn" horror flicks, Funny Games sets the counter back to zero, reminding us that torture isn't fun, isn't stimulating, and isn't something we should be getting off on.
Sex and the City never feels like a cash-in. Instead, it plays more like a labor of love for everyone involved.
A mediocre scare show that just happened to have one of the best trailers of recent times. At two minutes, The Strangers is terrifying; at eighty-five, it's lackluster.

While there are certainly ideas behind it, the film lacks the bloated self-importance that plagued the director's last two efforts. This time, Shyamalan seems content merely to entertain us, and that's enough.
The script is really a marvel of invention as it finds myriad ways to sink the characters deeper and deeper into the abyss, and this is where many of the film's biggest laughs come into play.
Doesn't tell its story clearly, and buries its most compelling aspects beneath action scenes and romantic subplots that detract from them.

Oliver Stone's take on Bush could be spot-on, or it could just be armchair analysis. All I know is that I was heavily involved in his vision. This is great, ambitious filmmaking from a director who is not afraid to delve inside his subjects.
Slasher movies are not my cup of tea. At the same time, honesty requires me to acknowledge that Friday the 13th is a really well-made and effective example of something that I don't like.
One of the most gut-wrenching portraits of family dysfunction ever to hit a movie screen.
Unlike many recent thrillers, it's not disposable. Days after seeing it, the film is still on my mind.
Coraline is just dazzling to look at, the kind of film where the frame seems to be bursting with things to discover.
An exercise in screw tightening, with the viewer (like the characters themselves) being bombarded with one gasp-inducing thing after another.
Regardless of how the live-action movie turns out, this DVD may actually be the definitive screen version of the story.
While perhaps not the most original or groundbreaking sci-fi/horror picture ever made, Alien Raiders at least succeeds in executing a simple-but-effective formula.
The film has a stunning look, abundant intelligence, and a blessed retention of most of the ideas that made the graphic novel a classic in its genre. Watchmen gave me a big old nerd-gasm.
This new version may appeal to the target audience of young kids, but for adults, it's a bit of a slog to get through.
I hesitate to call the film "touching" because that's kind of the antithesis of R-rated humor. So instead I will say that I Love You, Man locates comedy in the truth, and I laughed consistently.
I really loved the Watchmen film, and this DVD (as well as the Complete Motion Comic DVD) make for a really wonderful way to experience this extraordinary world.
movie_title: Watchmen: Tales of the Black Freighter and Under the Hood (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The DVD shows one of our most innovative and technically skilled comedians at his very best.
movie_title: Ricky Gervais: Out of England - The Stand-Up Special (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The ongoing advances in animation make it easier for filmmakers to create worlds we can get lost in, which is exactly what happens here.
The movie has all the thematic depth of a really great arthouse film wrapped in the action and excitement of a first-rate Hollywood action picture.
The series' core values are faithfully reflected in the film.
movie_title: Sesame Street Presents: Follow That Bird (1985)

movie_review_blurb: If you laugh at all - which I admittedly did - it is sometimes laughing at the political/social incorrectness of [the main character], and sometimes laughing at the sheer audacity of the film.

Fast & Furious represents a drastic drop in quality for the series. The reason is simple: it abandons the central premise of the franchise, which seems a betrayal of the very thing that made the other entries so enjoyable.
Despite some definite tendencies toward the formulaic, He's Just Not That Into You actually has half a brain in its head.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: If, for example, Alvin and the Chipmunks is a children's movie, then The Fox and the Child is a children's movie for children who'd prefer to hang out at the local arthouse cinema than at the multiplex.
When I did laugh, it was because of some weird little twist one of the actors gave to a line reading or some bit of physical comedy they tried. It wasn't because the movie itself was actually witty.
If The Exorcist were re-imagined by Bugs Bunny, this is what you'd get. Drag Me to Hell is a head trip for the ages.
Night at the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian is that most rare of exhibits: a sequel that's actually better than the original.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: No amount of explosions or shootouts can match the genuine, bite-your-nails suspense of a single life perpetually in danger from deadly cyborgs who will never stop coming until their objective is complete.
Nights in Rodanthe is the cinematic equivalent of a Harlequin novel with a pack of tissues shoved into the back cover.
As far as I'm concerned, Angels & Demons is the first bona fide dud of the 2009 summer movie season. A typical walk up the aisle to receive communion is more exciting than this movie.
Any chance to sit down and watch these brilliant cartoons again is a cause for celebration.
movie_title: The Looney, Looney, Looney Bugs Bunny Movie (1981)

movie_review_blurb: The first Star Trek movie that feels fully realized. It's smart enough to be accessible to everyone, while retaining enough respect for the franchise's legacy to please diehard fans.
If the [potentially-intriguing] details of Wolverine's backstory are sometimes skimmed over, the movie at least delivers plenty of bang for your buck in the action department.
It's still relatively early in the year, but this is definitely one of my favorite films so far in 2009.

Gene Siskel used to talk about the Idiot Plot - a plot that could be resolved in five minutes, were all the characters not complete idiots. Obsessed represents the dictionary definition of the Idiot Plot.
While the miniseries is undoubtedly a richer and more fulfilling dramatic experience, the film still manages to be exciting, thought-provoking, and highly entertaining.
This is a fun movie, as well as an interesting peek into what entertains audiences in a different culture.
I found City of Ember to be one of the most pleasant moviegoing surprises of the year. Imaginative, exciting, dramatic, and even fun.
While The Pink Panther 2 certainly has moments of hilarity, they are fewer and farther between this time.
Look closely and you will see that Taken is not a harmless piece of action fluff. It is a fraud, and a mean-spirited one at that.
Watching Max Payne is painful to the max.
That noise you hear is the soundtrack of We Own the Night, which is playing next door in the multiplex of your memory. Yes, there are undeniable similarities between the two pictures.
High School Musical 3 is like Grease meets Up With People in the United Colors of Benetton. Not a combination that fills me with joy.
Life Through a Lens does an excellent job of showing how this extraordinarily talented woman came to the forefront of modern photography.
movie_title: Annie Leibovitz: Life Through a Lens (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Zack and Miri finds a love story in a most unlikely place, which makes the romance that much more romantic while still leaving plenty of room to indulge in the potty mouth. I call that a winner on all sides.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Despite some occasionally sloppy filmmaking, I think the picture is worth a look. It raises important ideas and issues, asks important questions. No one could argue against that, right? Bueller...Bueller...Bueller...
The film is nothing less than riveting. What hooked me above all else was the chance to peer into a different era where trust went a lot further than it does today.
Raw, powerful, haunting, and unforgettable.
movie_title: Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son About His Father (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Madagascar: Escape 2 Africa is better-looking, funnier, and has a better story [than the original].
It's a well-made but thematically flawed film based on a book that was ingenious in conceit but generically written. The strengths of one are the flaws of the other, and vice versa.
Has a very high high laugh-per-minute ratio.
With the possible exception of Licence to Kill, this is the worst Bond movie ever.
Even if the historical value is only of minor interest to you, Frost/Nixon remains a great human tragedy about two men who meet on a televised battleground, knowing that it's do-or-die time.
Four Christmases boasts one of the most impressive casts ever assembled to make a movie that is, at best, only mildly amusing.

I'll give it credit for being at least moderately entertaining, with a handful of effective moments of adventure and suspense. At the same time, it's really quite a shame that the film wimped out on driving the message home.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Milk combines grade-A acting, an astute screenplay, and innovative, passionate direction into a package that entertains even as it drives home some important ideas.
There is nothing new or ambitious about Yes Man. It is intended to be a textbook Jim Carrey silly comedy, and honestly, that's just fine by me.
Some movies go off on tangents. This movie is nothing but tangents.
Revolutionary Road is a very well-made film indeed, and if it stings a little, that is only a testament to how strong a work it is.
Amusement might end up being the most ironic title of the year, because there's absolutely nothing amusing about it.
Notorious is a well-made, compelling, and ultimately humane film, even if you don't like rap music.
Last Chance Harvey is nothing you haven't seen before. It's just done with older actors, a bit more poignancy, and a bit more class
Nothing new or groundbreaking here, just a lot of talented people coming together for a well-made and entertaining Western.
Thanks to Kevin James' earnest portrayal of an earnest guy, I was won over by the film's goofy charms.
Gran Torino gets laughs when it wants to be funny, earns your empathy when it wants to be affecting, and makes you think when it speaks its mind.
Defiance plays more like an action movie than the award-worthy prestige film the studio is making it out to be.

This particular viewing experience is not like being on the edge of your seat, or laughing yourself silly, or being scared out of your wits. Benjamin Button washes over you in an almost hypnotic way. Call it cinematic mediation.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The Wrestler offers Mickey Rourke a chance at redemption with the role of a lifetime. It's safe to say that he body slams it.
Few may have paid attention during its theatrical run, but DVD should offer a whole new life to a smart, engaging film that genuinely has something worthwhile to say.
As the end credits rolled, all I could think was, I've got to see this again, soon!
The Women is not perfect, and the best way to enjoy it is as a showcase for some of the top female acting talent of the day.
If you like hypothetical, debate-fueling ideas, then Doubt is one of the year's must-see movies.
Amusingly clueless - the cinematic equivalent of your crazy uncle who tries unsuccessfully to incorporate hip-hop lingo into his speech so that the kids will be impressed.
Brown Sugar takes an old tale and tells it in a fresh, modern way. The music's pretty good, too.
When the end credits started to roll, an awed numbness came over me; I was more moved by the film than I had expected, and I knew I had seen something great.
In the Bedroom takes a story that's been told before and makes it fresh by re-telling it realistically.
Guillermo del Toro brings a carefully crafted style to Blade 2 that elevates it beyond most other films of its kind.
I think it's a safe bet that Ice Age will be a front-runner for next year's Best Animated Film Oscar.
Panic Room is like the Energizer bunny of suspense; it just keeps going and going and going.
They took a risk here, hoping to make a wildly offbeat and hilarious comedy unlike anything else to ever hit a movie screen, and they failed.
This is the kind of movie that Bluto, Otter, and the Delta House boys would have trashed a theater for showing.
The movie is good and worth seeing - I just would have expected this kind of talent to team up for something more ambitious.
The movie understands - and depicts - the self-destruction inherent in trying to make somebody else pay.
It made me laugh. And in a film like this, that is the only defense for liking it.
This is one of the creepiest and most disturbing movies I've ever seen.
I smell what The Rock is cooking. It's junk food: there's no nutritional value whatsoever and it doesn't fill you up, but it sure is fun to eat.
One thing's for sure: if you had only a week to live, you wouldn't want to waste 100 minutes on this.
The emphasis on the human element makes this a real feel-good movie.
The performances are quite good, the screenplay is full of observant moments and sharp one-liners.
Was it worth the wait? Absolutely.
It's about growing up, being more responsible about sex, understanding that it is an act that has weight, meaning, and significance.
Two really hysterical moments in a movie that is otherwise embarrassingly unfunny.
Films like Big Daddy and The Waterboy aggravated me by being actively obnoxious; Mr. Deeds is merely bland.

I think Anchorman has the potential to achieve Austin Powers-like status as a highly quotable movie.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It might not sit well with purists, but I for one was glad to see a new spin put on the story.
The message is old hat by now, but I, Robot is a genuine Will Smith Movie. What more do you need?

Like Spider-Man 2, this film works in a very specific genre and seems intent on finding the layers underneath.
In his desire to repeat a previously winning formula, Shyamalan this time delivers a dud.
An empowering idea is woven with great subtlety into a series of poop jokes, sex jokes, and pot jokes. Maybe some people will miss it. I didn't.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is intense, not for the scenes of action, but for the way evil and decency fight it out on the conversational battleground of two men.
Outfoxed manages to be political without being sanctimonious.
movie_title: Outfoxed: Rupert Murdoch's War on Journalism (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Obviousness is what does The Princess Diaries 2 in. Everything in this plot marches along to a prefabricated beat.
Although the story may look by-the-numbers, it makes some interesting detours in its characterization.
Style alone isn't enough to make a movie good, but it can add an atmosphere of fun and imagination that sweeps you into the story. For me, that's exactly what happens here.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The film is undeniably flawed, yet the things that work do so beautifully.
Good acting, solid direction, and some genuine cleverness carry you right over the plot holes.
Marginally better than the original, but viewers who are not acquainted with the video game will probably feel unimpressed.

Hero is one of the most visually poetic movies I've ever seen.
The inconsistency in tone leaves Without a Paddle up a certain unnamed creek.
Zach Braff should promptly quit his TV show and devote himself to making movies full-time.
Watching One Number 2, I was amazed by the seemingly endless creativity it contained.
What makes Open Water an exemplary thriller is that it's rooted in humanity.
De-Lovely features a first-rate performance that ought to earn Kevin Kline an Oscar nomination.
The film has many problems, but here's the biggest: It's rated PG-13 and it should have been rated R.

movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: I recommend it as a family film that kids will enjoy and adults will find unexpectedly pleasant.
The story is believable and identifiable; the characters seem like genuine people, not pawns in a screenplay.

I have some real affection for The Honeymooners because I liked the core cast so much. I just wish that everything else was on the same level.

movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Bewitched has more giggles than belly laughs, but it's not the same-old same old, and the massive appeal of Will Ferrell and Nicole Kidman is undeniable.

Why anyone thought it was time for Herbie to make a comeback is beyond me, but here he is.

My recommendation is tempered by the fact that this started off as a great movie and ended as little more than a piece of pleasant fluff.
Dark Water is much more ambitious and classy than the advertising would lead you to believe. It deserves to find an audience of discerning moviegoers.
We know what comic book movies are capable of being. They can have greatness in them. Fantastic Four has nothing more than okay-ness.
Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is, pardon the pun, the ultimate eye candy. It's every bit as enjoyable as sinking your teeth into a great big Hershey bar.
Raunchy humor is easy to do but hard to do well; this film creates characters we believe in and care about, then adds the raunchiness on top. It gets the formula just right.

It's ironic that a movie whose central characters are two of the world's greatest storytellers should be so careless in telling its own story.

Here's a B-movie that knows it's a B-movie, yet is intent on being a really good B-movie. And it is.
At only 77 minutes, Deuce Bigalow: European Gigolo is about 76 minutes too long.
Sisterhood is likely to fit different kinds of moviegoers, even if it doesn't look that way on the surface. You just have to be willing to try it on.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Although there is some undeniable entertainment value here, the plot of Four Brothers ultimately proves to be pretty standard.

There's nothing groundbreaking here, yet the film is light and fun, and there's a positive message for kids.

A film of beautiful simplicity that left me spellbound...Nothing short of magical.

A tiny bit of the freakiness of the original is lost...but the pros outweigh the cons.

movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

An involving look at a bizarre piece of criminal history. Also, a very welcome return to form for Johnny Depp.
A humane film that recognizes the powerful role faith can play when you don't know where to turn.
This is a McDonald's meal of a movie, slapped together and designed to taste just like every other McDonald's meal you've ever eaten at any point in your life.
A must-see documentary for comedy fans! More than a simple recounting of Lampoon history, Drunk Stoned gives a strong sense of the players involved.
movie_title: Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead: The Story of the National Lampoon (2015)

movie_review_blurb: If you're a fan of hardcore bonkers cinema, this needs to shoot directly to the top of your must-see list.
movie_title: Attack on Titan: Part 1 (Shingeki no kyojin) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: You know how people say 'yadda yadda yadda' when telling a story, assuming that the listener can fill in certain gaps on their own? Well, Hidden is a whole movie full of 'yadda yadda yadda'.
While it may not be Guillermo del Toro's best film, Crimson Peak nonetheless offers enough phantasmagoric appeal to draw you in.
It's amazing that a movie about such a dark subject can play so thrillingly and vibrantly.
Full of chess game suspense. The movie offers a tense look at the hazards of mediating between enemies.
If you're a connoisseur of blurry images of floors and feet, then this is the motion picture you've been waiting for.
An energetic, continually engaging biopic. If you don't know the N.W.A. story, you'll be fascinated by its many twists and turns. If you do, you'll admire the respect with which it's told.

This is one of those rare cases where the exhibition format is as much a part of the movie's success as the storytelling is. The extra dimension is quite crucial, as the whole thing is designed around giving the audience a vicarious experience.
The film is a different spin on the vampire myth, but the sluggish pace and gaps in logic prevent it from having the impact you really want from a story of this type.
With great cheer and good spirit, Batkid Begins tells a true story that will restore your faith in humanity.

The Martian highlights the book's best qualities, tones down its worst, and adds its own style, which is accentuated by some effective, yet non-intrusive, 3D work. A fast-paced, consistently enthralling adventure.

Deathgasm combines the visual flair of Edgar Wright's Scott Pilgrim vs. the World with the manic, gory energy of Sam Raimi's Evil Dead 2. In the horror-comedy pantheon, this movie most definitely rocks hard.
The Duke of Burgundy is like Fifty Shades of Grey as staged by Masterpiece Theater.

The really remarkable and effective thing about Everest is that, on a visual level, it's thoroughly convincing. There is not a single moment here that looks like it was computer-generated or shot against a green screen.
Intelligent and provocative. Despite the heavy subject matter, Sicario works just as well as a thriller as it does a social-issue drama.
An epic adventure filled with eye-popping lunacy!
movie_title: Attack On Titan: Part 2 (Shingeki no kyojin endo obu za warudo) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Instead of focusing on the part of the story that's potentially affecting, writer/director Andrew Librizzi overcrowds his picture with subplots that go nowhere and extraneous characters who could have easily been chopped out.
One of the most skillfully executed thrillers you're likely to come across. The film is a great example of how intelligence in storytelling creates far more suspense than generic attempts at shock.
A stunningly tedious work. If a friend tries to convince you to see this movie, run away as fast as you can and never speak to that person again.

Dope is, at its very best, a throwback to that time when the joyful hip-hop of Kid 'N Play bumped up against the social consciousness of N.W.A., and all of it mixed together to create something whose force couldn't be denied.
There are moments here that are so over-the-top loony, you might just find yourself clapping your hands and giggling in delight. And then there's all the other stuff.
A beautiful, meaningful, deeply touching film. Pixar's best work to date.
A crazy, imaginative concept executed for maximum awesomeness.
Envisions itself as a modern-day Frankenstein, but quite honestly, even Tim Burton's satiric Frankenweenie is a more thoughtful, incisive look at the act of playing God.

Terminator Genisys plays like the worst piece of fan fiction ever written. Every imaginable sort of cheap gratification is thrown up on the screen, to the point where the film eventually begins to feel desperate.
There are enough pyrotechnics and human/alien fight scenes to mostly hold your attention, although the film never delivers a whole lot more than that.
An intriguing, if flawed look at the nature of obsession.
While Tangerine does a brilliant job of establishing a verite feel, there's so little actual story that it becomes difficult to get involved at anything deeper than a surface level.
Magic Mike XXL isn't quite as psychologically curious as the original, but it certainly delivers a good time for both genders. (You heard me right, fellas.)
The Suicide Theory is funny and disturbing, and a picture that's tough to take your eyes off once you start watching it.
It's sort of a decent movie, and sort of a letdown. Neither one all the way, but both simultaneously.
Brightly colored, inordinately silly, kind of charming, and yes, a bit one-note. Still, you know what you're getting, and if that's what you want, here it is.
A provocative and monumentally nerve-wracking thriller.
We've had so many superhero movies in the last decade that it's amazing one can still feel surprising. Ant-Man does. In that sense, it's a triumph.
Many modern romantic-comedies are shallow and stupid. Trainwreck is one that has something substantive to say. The film is incredibly satisfying as both a comedy and a character study.
Fantastic Four is Catwoman-level awful. It wastes a great cast and cool source material.
An entertaining movie that celebrates the simple happiness a fancy pair of sneakers can bring.

Gillis clearly had some ideas for practical effects he wanted to create; the plot is just an excuse to do them. There doesn't appear to be much sincere interest in telling a story. For this reason, Harbinger Down plays like the world's longest demo reel.
Innerspace is a movie that sucks you in from the get-go, then keeps you hooked with the way it effortlessly moves from sci-fi to comedy to action, then back again.
This new Vacation reboot lacks the thing most crucial to the success of any given entry in the series.
It has beautiful visuals/character design, some truly funny comedy, and stylish fight scenes. Those things add up to a solid anime adventure.
There's not much substance here, but it doesn't really matter. Shaun the Sheep Movie is filled with funny slapstick hijinks and clever bits of humor.
It's a little too self-referential, and unless you're a walking encyclopedia of all things DC, this has the effect of becoming occasionally difficult to follow.
