A celebratory film that serves to remind viewers of the joyful figure Chris Farley was, in spite of his own demons.
Jake Gyllenhaal's performance is definitely worth seeing, although Southpaw as a whole doesn't quite live up to the high standard he sets.
It's an undeniably silly picture, but it's lovingly silly, which makes it go down a lot more smoothly than you'd expect.
Writer/director Keith Miller has made a film that never feels forced, never seems artificial. James "Primo" Grant is electrifying in the lead role.
Ineptly written and flatly directed, the film takes real effort to get through, as it practically dares the viewer to pay attention.
Very effectively shows both the upside of crowdfunding and the struggles of making good on a successful campaign.
The film is well-acted, beautifully photographed, and thematically rich. Russell Crowe may have a second whole career ahead of him.

The Overnight has a handful of scenes that make you do the laugh/gasp combination, so crazy are the happenings in the plot. At the same time, there is something oddly touching about the movie's portrait of marriage.
While hardly revelatory for diehard fans, there's nonetheless a lot of fun information provided here.
The sillier scenes of Bill Murray traipsing through a dangerous part of the world are fun, but when the story tries to get at something more serious, it falls apart pretty quickly.
So much is made of the Marvel Cinematic Universe, but what DC is doing with these animated features is much more organic.

An old Hollywood tale as only the Coen Brothers could tell it. If you love movies from the '40s and '50s, you'll see affection buried within the often uproarious parody of the on- and off-screen cinematic world at that time.
Pride and Prejudice and Zombies is one of the best adaptations I've ever seen. It perfectly captures the unrelenting awfulness of the book it's based on.
There are sections of Where to Invade Next that are important to see. As a whole, though, it doesn't represent Michael Moore at the top of his game.
Nina Forever would be funny if it wasn't so disturbing, and it would be disturbing if it wasn't so funny.
Zoolander 2 will probably disappoint people looking for a carbon copy of the original, but its refusal to be one is probably its best quality.
Despite some notable flaws, Deadpool is just what superhero cinema needs. It's a shot of adrenaline directly into the Marvel nervous system.
A passable Western entertainment, thanks to the actors and some good technical qualities, including production design and cinematography
Snowtime! explains the topic of war in a "safe" manner that tempers things with a healthy dose of fun and laughter. It's like a really good Newberry Medal-winning book.

One of the more notable horror films of the last few years. The Witch holds you in its grasp with a chilling exploration of how evil chooses some people to be its victims and others to do its bidding.
Spellbinding! A vital, wondrous piece of history is beautifully preserved.
movie_title: The Last Man On The Moon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Lacks the clear vision to know how to distinguish itself from a hundred other similar movies.
Entertaining and heart-warming, if not entirely original. It's the cinematic equivalent of one of those inspirational posters featuring kittens and sayings about how you should 'hang in there.'

A pale imitation of the masterpiece that spawned it. Whereas the original had a freshness and a beauty that made it accessible to martial arts fans and non-fans alike, the sequel will leave even the faithful unimpressed.
movie_title: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon: Sword of Destiny (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A dull, predictable melodrama that only pretends to be about autism.
Fueled by strong performances and some genuinely riveting twists and turns, it's a solid genre film that delivers the goods in a largely fresh way.
Zoe Bell deserves her own Kill Bill, her own Die Hard. Camino is basically an above-average Steven Seagal flick with a much more appealing lead.

The first-person action scenes are a lot of fun, but everything else is so routine by this point that you may find yourself mentally going on autopilot whenever someone isn't fighting off hordes of infected.

Armed with a pitch-black sense of humor, a confidently-executed nightmarish style, and a dazzling turn from Lauren Ashley Carter, the movie works its way into your psyche and gradually frays your nerves.
If you like to see people pushing themselves to the physical brink, parts of the movie will absolutely hold your attention. If only the plot was that compelling.

One of the worst superhero movies ever made. It is worse than Batman & Robin. It is worse than Catwoman. It is worse than last summer's Fantastic Four. A lugubrious experience that squanders every ounce of promise.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's not conventionally a good movie; there's little plot to speak of, and 83 minutes of psychedelia becomes a touch repetitive. However, it's still a captivating curio.
Keeps you watching and wondering, while simultaneously challenging your own viewpoint on life in the modern day.
movie_title: All The Time In The World (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Whereas other pictures of this type tend to focus on the thrills, this one focuses on the idea that lives are at stake. The Finest Hours' appreciation of the "leave no man behind" ethic is refreshing.
If you want a meaningful Christian message, you'll absolutely find one. If that's not your cup of tea, you can still enjoy a really amazing feel-good story.
Krisha is bold and powerful. This Great American Indie will knock you on your ass in the best possible way.
The Brothers Grimsby needed more structure to achieve its full potential. That makes it a mixed bag. But boy, are there ever some amazing moments here.
Everything about 10 Cloverfield Lane is wildly effective, except for the part that actually connects it to Cloverfield.
Stimulating and thoughtful, if occasionally a bit confusing, this is a worthy piece of animated fare for adults.
A choppy, inconsistent film that often feels assembled from the deleted scenes of other movies.
Zootopia is to 2016 what Inside Out was to 2015 - a next-level animated feature that gives kids something of substance while simultaneously showing them a really good time.
While perhaps not as deep as it could have been, the movie is nonetheless a compelling examination of an unrepentant cheater.
The novelty wears out long before Tokyo Tribe is over. That's because there's nothing really happening here except for the execution of the novelty.
I'm not saying Dirty Grandpa is terrible, but I fully expect a terrorist organization to claim responsibility for it any minute now.
The Intern is a smart, funny, and surprisingly touching film, anchored by first-rate performances from DeNiro and Hathaway.
It starts off as a perfectly sweet and touching family film before making an abrupt left turn into something much darker and less appropriate for young children.
Everything about Jem and the Holograms seems specifically designed to be annoying. The film is deeply misguided and not half as clever as it thinks it is.
A monotonous bore. Lost in the Sun clearly thinks it's saying something profound, but what it says has been said before, many times, in much better pictures.

The franchise has always relied on megalomaniacal villains, ticking clocks, and narrow escapes. Spectre spins those things in a slightly more offbeat way that may irritate some Bond purists, but which plays as both homage and reinvention.
Entertainment offers some genuine insight into its subject matter. Coupled with an astonishing central performance, it is a work that continually fascinates.

Love the Coopers is significantly flawed, but it also contains enough ambition to rise slightly above the norm for this sort of thing. As the old saying goes, it's just good enough to make you wish it was better.

A satisfactory - if unspectacular - conclusion. Anyone who has been invested in the saga will likely have sufficient interest in how the complex story resolves itself, but it's odd that the franchise goes out on its weakest note.
A drug-fueled romp through New York City that manages to be both extremely R-rated and touchingly sweet.
Submerged has a great premise, which it promptly proceeds to screw up in every manner conceivable.
the performances from Redmayne and Vikander are so good - and so authentic - that the film is impossible to ignore
A stunning, soul-stirring, not-to-be-missed film. Brie Larson is beyond superb. Young Jacob Tremblay matches her note for note.
There's probably a better film to be made about the Krays, but Legend has two Tom Hardys and an Emily Browning doing exemplary work. In this case, that's enough.
The performances carry it to a point, but then you realize that Youth isn't saying anything new, nor is it saying anything old in a fresh way.
If Mother Teresa were here to see the film, she would probably say, 'You made this piece of garbage about me?'
Krampus is undoubtedly slight, but it's also a lot of fun as it rails creatively against the warm fuzziness of most cinematic Christmas fare.

The smartest thing Sylvester Stallone did was to not write and/or direct this film. Ryan Coogler brings a fresh set of eyes to the project. Creed works both as part of a larger franchise and on its own massively entertaining terms.
The Big Short will anger you as much as it makes you laugh. That sweet-and-sour quality makes it one of the year's most vital, important films.
13 Hours is a rousing action movie that powerfully suggests Hilary Clinton should be exonerated of any wrongdoing in the Benghazi scandal. Or not.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Richard Gere is brilliant as ever. Too bad his strong work is in the center of a plot that can't quite seal the deal.
If you're going to base a horror story on something so gruesome, you can't wimp out. The Forest isn't the worst thing ever made, but it absolutely wimps out.
Diablo is the first new film I've seen in 2016. I'll be surprised if I see one that's worse all year.
The Hateful Eight is Quentin Tarantino's weakest movie - and yes, that includes Death Proof. There's still plenty of good stuff here to make the film worth seeing, though.
There's so much in this film that you probably need to see it more than once to digest it all. And believe me, you'll want to.
The performances and thematic elements are more than sufficient to make The Lady in the Van a treat.
A powerful, unforgettable motion picture that packs a wallop you'll need some time to recover from.
A soulless special effects extravaganza. Quite possibly the least pleasurable Peter Pan story in any format, ever.
Will Smith is excellent, and the story absolutely drives home the point that the NFL is perfectly willing to sacrifice the health and well-being of the very players who line its executives' pockets.
The movie delivers in every conceivable way, on every imaginable level. Star Wars: The Force Awakens is a PhD. level course in Getting It Exactly Right.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A beguiling story of two people from different worlds who come together powerfully.
A smartly written, expertly performed comedy that offers laughs, big and small, from start to finish.
Riveting from its first second to its last. With a smart script, perfectly paced direction, and superb acting, this is a work that manages to be as entertaining as it is important.
Joy is not the best movie Russell and Lawrence have made together, but it is, for the most part, a witty and engrossing look at a sister who's doing it for herself.
This is a movie custom made for people who became outraged when Starbucks made their Christmas coffee cups red.
Nothing will ever top the original, of course, but this sequel is certainly leagues better than the others.
Entourage is certainly satisfactory viewing for anyone who enjoyed the show. But let's keep it real: the movie will play better and more naturally on HBO than it does in a cinema.
Even whacked out of your mind on weed, this would still be painfully laborious to sit through.
movie_title: The Coed and the Zombie Stoner (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The movie may well appeal to Mormon audiences because the plot directly incorporates the tenets of their religion. They may also pick up on thematic cues not apparent to non-Mormons. All other audiences will see it as a generic, unconvincing thriller.
A funny, charming, feel-good movie that rises above a few clichés.
A thoroughly captivating film you can't easily shake off.
Not Christopher Nolan's best film by a long shot, yet also proof that 'not Christopher Nolan's best film' is still better and more thrilling than many directors' finest work.
Perpetually feels a few good jokes away from being really funny.
Feels as though the plot could do even more with its material.
Dolls is purposefully over-the-top and crazy, like a Looney Tunes short re-envisioned by Freddy Kruger. They don't make horror movies like this anymore, and it's a damn shame.
Dumb & Dumber To defies traditional film criticism. I can only tell you that I laughed, and at times I laughed really hard.
It's always great fun when a movie is this unpredictable.
The Mule is not perfect, and it sure isn't pretty, but it has a wildly original premise for a thriller, and that's enough to make it kind of a gas.
May not work on a stand-alone level, but if you've become invested in the series, it's an important, thoughtful bridge between what has already happened and what is yet to come.
It would not be fair to call this movie "so bad it's good" because, quite frankly, it's so bad it's awful.
Smart, funny, and electrifying in its storytelling. Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons are nothing short of magical.
A flawed, but undeniably thoughtful, treatise on how art and commerce collide in current pop culture.
Foxcatcher, with its layered performances and emotionally precise storytelling, is a riveting drama that leaves you spellbound and more than a little shaken.
The Babadook burrows under your skin, continually prodding you with increasingly disturbing ideas. You don't just walk away from this movie; it follows you.
Everything here is either too weird or too preachy to make an impact, unless you're really, really into being lectured to for 95 minutes.
Joyful and entertaining! Pass the Light offers a simple, heartfelt message of acceptance and tolerance, wrapped in an appealing coming-of-age plot. This is a genuine feel-good movie.

Often unbearably tense and always psychologically and emotionally captivating, American Sniper isn't interested in patriotism for patriotism's sake; it's interested in the cost of patriotism on those most invested in defending the right to have it.
Delightfully entertaining. The first live-action movie Tim Burton has made in a decade where you can tell he actually gave a rip about the material.
A film that amazes, entertains, and inspires admiration, even when it's not perfect.
A fascinating look at what happened to many Sudanese refugees, but also at how people who come from underprivileged parts of the world experience the United States.
Cheesy as can be.
An unforgettable movie experience. David Oyelowo gives the performance of the year.
Entertaining and far funnier than I expected, although when Johnny Depp is the most subtle thing in your movie, you know you've gone a little too far over the top.
A terrific, powerful film about a woman navigating two wildernesses: the physical one and the emotional one.
This is the movie I've been waiting for Chris Rock to make his entire career. It's his stand-up sensibility, perfectly translated to film.
Frank, like its central figure, is deeply weird, but in that special way that you simply can't avert your eyes from.
A lively, exciting beat-the-clock thriller. Frequently sharp and witty.
By far, 2014's biggest disappointment.
By inserting so much filler into the second movie, this finale is saddled with the need to pay it all off. Consequently, the unfocused story meanders all over the place.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Despite some good things around the fringes, Candyman: Farewell to the Flesh is an admirable, but not quite fulfilling, follow-up.
John Wick is little more than 101 minutes of Keanu Reeves running around shooting people in the head because they [spoiler redacted]. That's literally all there is to it.
Shot in a 1970s, John Cassavettes style with hand-held cameras and lots of beautiful film grain, Listen Up Philip is often funny and fascinating.
There are some slow spots, and because it so closely mirrors a horror classic, there's not a lot of originality or surprise.
The film kind of slogs along, never achieving anything close to the hypnotic, edgy buzz that fans, myself included, are certainly looking for during another trip into Sin City.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Adam Sandler fans who are members of blended families may love it the most. All others will wish Blended had the courage to include more identifiable human moments and fewer screwing rhinos.
A haunted house movie with a kinky twist. May feel slow to those accustomed to the hyper horror movies of today.
It aims high and doesn't quite hit the mark. Simply put, The Calling needed to go more in depth with its ideas.
As a movie, so it blows.
So dramatically and emotionally authentic that it makes you feel as though you're using some special kind of magic to peer right into the lives of real people.

You know that old expression "If it looks like a duck, and it quacks like a duck, then it must be a duck?" Well,The Longest Week looks like a Wes Anderson film, and it quacks like a Wes Anderson film, but it most definitely is not a Wes Anderson film.
Marijuana legalization is a hot button issue, ripe for boundary-pushing humor. Don't Legalize It oddly pulls back at the very moment when it should be charging forward with all its might.
movie_title: Trailer Park Boys: Don't Legalize It (2014)

movie_review_blurb: There's a thin line between cleverness and outright stupidity. No Good Deed jumps right over that line, pulls its pants down, and figuratively moons the audience.
Gloriously bonkers! The Scribbler is fearless in its willingness to go right over the edge, which makes it a treat for fans of science-fiction madness.
An engaging and thoughtful work of horror, one that admirably puts carnage in the back seat so that something more emotional/humane can do the driving.
A unique portrait of an artist in turmoil.
The bad news is that this is not the next Hunger Games. The good news is that it's no Divergent either.
Can someone who films people having sex be a real artist? The answer is yes, and here's a great introduction to one of them.
The performances and laughs are enough to make This Is Where I Leave You enjoyable, provided you can overlook the shallowness and frequent sitcom compulsions.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Press materials for The Song describe it as "the sexiest faith-based movie ever." While that's technically true, it's also an incredibly low bar to clear. The film is completely generic and doggedly formulaic.
Fury works on an action level in a big way. Its human element is even better. The film is a powerhouse.

Every joke calls attention to itself as though lit by a flashing neon sign, and the film makes no pretense of creating characters or a story that you can get invested in. In fact, it takes great pains to prevent you from becoming invested.
The intentions of Believe Me are admirable. The execution, though, is unconvincing and not especially funny.

This is a prestige film, a dysfunctional family drama, a courtroom thriller, a comedy, and a romance all balled together. Quite frankly, I'm surprised it doesn't try to be a science-fiction adventure and a musical, too.
Sometimes the movie is funny, other times eye-roll inducing.
One of the smartest, most precisely observed portraits of a relationship to hit the screen in the last decade, and also one of the best whodunnits.

There's probably a brilliant, award-worthy film to be made about the inhumane way the medical practice dealt with the mentally ill in the past. This one isn't it, but it is nonetheless a solid, sturdy piece of entertainment.
Feels like the work of a computer program that analyzed dozens of popular movies in different genres, then self-generated a screenplay that tried to incorporate elements from all of them.
An engaging document of how - and, more importantly, why - this particular album had such an impact.
A dull, lifeless chiller that botches a rather brilliant premise. Where is Frank Darabont when King needs him?
The movie jumps right in without taking the time to properly introduce us to the people we'll be following for 87 minutes. By the time I finally figured everything out, I no longer cared.
The Boxtrolls is the movie equivalent of its own characters: quirky, weird-looking, beautifully unusual, and almost impossible to not love.
Overlong at 131 minutes and frequently monotonous in its carnage, The Equalizer fails to deliver the basic thrills one would expect from a Denzel Washington action picture.
This is a film that should either be a fun caper comedy or a thoughtful dramatic exploration on the dangers of engaging in fraud. By trying to be both, it ends up being neither.
Ingeniously structured, masterfully executed, and enormously entertaining.
A two-hour blast of fun that cements Melissa McCarthy's status as a Comedy Master.
Even if this isn't Steve Martin's best role or his best film, it holds up pretty well, offering a glimpse of a comic genius at a wonderfully experimental stage of his career.

The combination of a brilliant lead performance and a respectably honest portrayal of Alzheimer's make Still Alice affecting, even during the times when it feels as though it needs a little more plot.
Self-consciously arty dreck of the most agonizing variety.
An insightful peek into how the intersection of ambition, creativity, and ego can yield both brilliance and heartache.

Has a lot of the same problems as its most recent predecessors. The dialogue is flat, the action scenes are over-edited so that it's not always clear what you're looking at, and situations often get so implausible that it becomes a distraction.

It wants to be a faith-based film, a historical drama, and an action/adventure movie at the same time. Those three things are blended together awkwardly, leading to shifts in tone that can be jarring.
It Follows is bold, provocative, original, artfully made, perfectly acted, and creepy as hell.
Dial a Prayer is earnest and sincere, and it has a stellar performance from its lead actress, yet lacks the punch to make the kind of inspiring impact it's clearly aiming for.

The film has one story that kind of works, but is continually interrupted by one that doesn't. That has the effect of keeping The Longest Ride from ever achieving the meaning and relevance it so clearly aims for.
Bolstered by a compelling story that features one of the most intriguing elements in Batman mythology, the film ranks among the best in the series so far.
For much of its running time, it delivers a perfectly breezy, entertaining story, but then the third act trips everything up.
Proof that action pictures are best when they forge a path all their own.
Alex of Venice is a very human story, told with insight and meaning. It also establishes beyond a doubt that Mary Elizabeth Winstead is one of the most important young actresses on the screen today.
The only thing more annoying than internet connectivity problems is seeing them simulated onscreen.
The craziest, most breathtakingly bizarre motion picture you are ever likely to see. Imagine Mutual of Omaha's Wild Kingdom as reimagined by Stephen King.
Contains an excess of self-impressed quirkiness that serves no real purpose and goes nowhere.

After the Ball is one-third Cinderella, one-third The Devil Wears Prada, and one third Twelfth Night. If you're going to attempt to duplicate the success of such works, you've got to be a little sharper than it ends up being.
Intelligent and provocative, with more than a little relevance to the world we live in.
Sufficiently fun to be worth a look for superhero fans, although it's kept from greatness by the very nature of the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
Tautly paced, beautifully acted, and insanely unsettling.
A fascinating and creepy experience that will have you praying you never know what sleep paralysis feels like.

Aloha is the new Gigli. It's got a great cast, comes from a respected filmmaker, and was clearly subjected to so much reediting that you can scarcely even tell what the point was supposed to be anymore.

San Andreas doesn't aim very high. It's nothing more than a popcorn movie, designed to offer two hours of mindless thrills. On that level, it's quite passable. Then again, there have got to be some new ideas that disaster movies can be infused with.
An engaging work, one that finds Spike Lee adapting his considerable skills to a new genre. It's not his best movie, but it's definitely one of his most unlikely, and therefore most fascinating.
Tomorrowland is like something a science fiction-obsessed 12-year-old would come up with following a trip to Disneyland. And I mean that in the best possible sense.
5 to 7 is the Before Sunrise of infidelity.
For whatever it lacks formally as a film, Pitch Perfect 2 wins you over with its joyous, infectious spirit.
Echoes of War may not be the most dazzling movie of its kind ever made, but the solid acting and engaging ideas make it worth seeing.
There's half a really amazing action flick here. However, you can't help but wish that it had gone full-tilt in its lunacy, rather than just partway.
The emphasis is on creating a fun adventure that doesn't take itself too, too seriously, and on that count, the movie definitely succeeds.
It's like Midnight Run with far fewer laughs and a lot more period jokes.
It's not a great movie, but there are enough laughs and clever ideas to make it a passably entertaining comedy.
A wonderful, inspiring look at how the best art, regardless of the age group at which it's aimed, always comes with a special personal touch that makes it indelible.
movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Like Jurassic Park, The Dark Knight, and, yes, The Road Warrior before it, Mad Max: Fury Road sets a new gold standard for action cinema.
A Most Violent Year is a morality tale, told with grace and insight. Everything about this picture fires on all cylinders. I was thoroughly absorbed from start to finish.

Island of Lemurs: Madagascar is only 40 minutes long, so there isn't a ton of depth; the movie is a nice overview, at best. But it's a fun overview for the whole family - one that may inspire you to learn more.
A classic. Has laughs in just about every single scene.
The movie often plays like a mid-2000s Jennifer Lopez rom-com forced against its will to be a hard-R guy comedy.
Everything about this movie is fun and entertaining. It's the kind of family film that shows everyone a good time, regardless of age.
Americons is like The Wolf of Wall Street without the skill, depth, nuance, humor, or poignancy.
Watching Annabelle is like watching a movie you've seen a dozen times before, just with different actors and slight variations on the same scare tactics.

Cake is an odd duck. It has a brilliant lead performance from its star, yet that performance is surrounded by tiresome clichés and contrivances torn straight out of the Independent Filmmaking 101 handbook.

The Humbling is going after something interesting - the idea that an actor could spend so many years in fiction that he loses his connection with reality. Sadly, the film fails to explore that concept to its fullest extent. Plus, you know, Birdman.
There is only one conceivable explanation for the existence of The Boy Next Door: Jennifer Lopez said, "What can I do to drive the final nail into my film career's coffin?"

Audiences looking for a fresh take on this type of story will be sorely disappointed by its refusal to deviate from the norm. But those in the mood for a sweet, uplifting, faith-based film will find it a pleasant way to spend an hour and a half.
Black or White comes at the issue [of race] from so many angles simultaneously that the overall impact is muted.

To make a movie about Aryans, you really need to have some sort of psychological insight into what makes them tick. Supremacy lacks any such insight, which makes it watchable, although never especially impactful.
There's an expression in journalism: "burying the lede." It refers to the act of delaying the most important or enticing facts until late in the story. Project Almanac buries its lede.
A touching, deeply affecting look at the ongoing impact of loss.
movie_title: Matt Shepard is a Friend of Mine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Two years from now, when you're home with the flu and it pops up on cable, you may well kill two hours watching it. That's really the only circumstance under which this ridiculous mess is likely to be acceptable.

Old Fashioned is excruciatingly dull. It's like watching a movie in slow motion. I had to force myself to stop looking at my watch, because it was discouraging how little time had gone by whenever I checked.
A no-holds-barred blast of mayhem, perfect for viewers who like their horror straight-up bonkers.
Flawed though it may be, there's still enough here that works to make the film a passable way to spend 106 minutes

Were it not based on a massive best-seller, no one would have made such a thematically reprehensible movie. If you think rape is a turn-on, this is the film for you. Personally, I'm perfectly happy not to be included in your ranks.
While the message is nice, the screenplay feels like it was written by a third grade Sunday school class.
Almost traumatically intense. The film continually cranks up the danger, creating a scenario that becomes more and more harrowing with every passing minute. A superb chiller.
Great fun! The film works as both an original spin on the zombie myth and as a satire of the undead genre's tropes.
Beautifully acted, smartly written, skillfully directed, and gorgeously photographed
Liam Neeson undoubtedly possesses "a very particular set of skills." That just isn't enough this time.

Some scenes march fearlessly into the darkest of dark comedy recesses, while others are played quite broadly, to let us know that we shouldn't take all this nastiness too seriously. The latter half of that equation is deadly for dark comedies.
The film feels like a 100-minute prison rape joke.
Uncommonly annoying. Chappie tries to combine the silly sweetness of Short Circuit with the grim, violent satire of RoboCop, and that proves to be as disastrous as it sounds.
Faults is a hypnotically offbeat movie, mixing pitch-black humor and thematic ambition in a way that's difficult to resist.
A smart, often wickedly funny look at two people trying to be true to themselves while being utterly false to everyone else.
New Year's Evil really is not a very good movie. But as a time capsule? Well, I'd be lying if I said it wasn't entirely watchable on that count.

Wild Tales is both great entertainment and great cinema, in that it sucks you in while also making you appreciate its skillful, inventive execution. This is, in every conceivable way, an exhilarating film.
Hot Tub Time Machine 2 plays like a film in outline form, where the bullet points are all on the page, but no one has connected them together yet.
The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water finds a reason to come off the TV and onto the movie screen. More than fifteen years since his debut, he feels fresh once again.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: If you've ever noticed Dick Miller in a movie and thought, "Hey, I recognize that actor!", you'll find this look at his amazing body of work both engaging and entertaining.
There is a lot of laughter and a lot of pathos in Hello, My Name Is Doris. Sally Field delivers one of the finest performances of her career.
A sophisticated and scary horror picture with way above-average effects.
If you're of a certain age, it may speak to you. If you're beyond that age, it'll most likely seem innocuous, but also very, very obvious.
Were it not for three well-known lead actors, this film probably would have turned up on the Lifetime channel instead of in theaters.
Battle Scars tells two stories concurrently. One is really good, the other incredibly weak. The problem is that the second story continually intrudes upon the first one.
Matt Reeves' film engages the mind and the senses in equal measure, resulting in top notch entertainment.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Stylish, well-acted, and unique.
Stylish and substantive, making you shudder on a regular basis.
The Big Sick is one of the best romantic comedies of our time. A work of 100% sincerity.
If you can handle hardcore reality-based horror, buckle up and prepare for a ride that will leave you shaken.
Christopher Nolan steps in a new direction this time, delivering a picture that engages the intellect and the senses, if not exactly the heart.
Atomic Blonde is appealingly different, which, storytelling issues aside, makes it a pleasure to immerse yourself in.
This impressively ballsy, stingingly funny horror-comedy grabs you by the throat in such a way that you never want it to let go.
The set-up is really fascinating. Unfortunately, once you get past it, everything goes downhill quickly.

Running a scant 75 minutes before the end credits roll, it's almost as though the movie knows it's garbage and tries to show the audience some semblance of mercy by getting itself over with as quickly as possible.
A searing look at the impact of racial injustice.
If you're attempting to create a series based on a complex mythology, omitting key details of that mythology is a pretty big step in the wrong direction.
Deeply touching. The Glass Castle mostly finds just the right note [for the material], feeling very authentic in both the lighter and the darker moments.
Excellent lead actress Amandla Stenberg is let down by an uneven tone and a flawed story.
Original and entertaining. The movie occasionally feels like an entry in the Saw franchise as directed by Michel Gondry.
This is about as bland and unsatisfying as a dysfunctional family comedy can get.
It's not entirely successful, yet to dismiss it as mere schlock would be unfair.
The best major studio horror movie in years. The film is certainly scary, but also funny, exciting, and even a little heartwarming.
Touching and entertaining. The surprising element of All Saints is its religious message, which isn't as obvious as you'd expect.
Anti Matter feels like an exercise in trying to be clever, rather than a well thought-out tale.
Temple is an endurance test to see how much of nothing a viewer can take before daydreaming, playing a cell phone game, or nodding off.
Spider-Man: Homecoming isn't really a Spider-Man movie. It's a Peter Parker movie, and that turns out to be an incredibly good thing.
Jackals is little more than just a series of violent, familiar events strung together.
Charming and frequently funny. It has a truly inspiring message about perseverance for children.
Ghost House is very excited to show you a foreign land. It's also excited to display some horrific visuals. What it's not very interested in, though, is telling a worthwhile story.
If you're going to make a movie about one of the greatest singer/lyricists of all time but you can't get the rights to their story or any of their music, don't even bother.
The heist is fun, but the detailed inside look at the workings of a speedway really makes Logan Lucky special.
It's perfectly understandable if your initial reaction to a documentary about typewriters is "pass," but don't write the film off so fast. There's more substance here than you'd anticipate.
The Hitman's Bodyguard is one of those right-down-the-middle movies. It's neither great nor terrible.
A solid thriller. Wind River represents mature, substantive filmmaking at its finest.
A hypnotic sociological study of Baltimore's history as told through its rat population.
You'd think franchise fatigue might start to set in by now. Nope. The movie is just as satisfying as its predecessors.
The Little Hours is one wild and crazy movie. Hysterically funny, plain and simple.
Wickedly entertaining, and disturbing in all the right ways.
A mature, contemplative, and deeply satisfying work.
As good a faith-based film as has yet been made. It's designed to appeal to Christian audiences, but well-done enough to have mainstream appeal, too.
Going in Style is a textbook example of how not to make a heist movie. It's stunning how the film gets even the most basic steps wrong.
The decision to do Smurfs: The Lost Village without any live-action sequences was a smart one. Solely utilizing computer animation feels like a much better fit for the material.
This series jumped the shark a long time ago. The Fate of the Furious jumps several sharks.
A landmark genre picture.
Unforgettable feels like it time-warped in from 1992. It easily would have been one of the worst pictures of that year, and it's definitely one of the worst of this year, too.
One of the most unsettling horror movies of recent years. Scary and poignant.
The movie is urging us to be weary of something we already know to be weary of - a fact that keeps it from becoming as provocative as it wants to be.
Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 takes everything that worked so well the first time around and amplifies it, establishing itself as one of the most satisfying sequels of recent years.
Director Guy Ritchie is so intent on making his version Not Your Father's King Arthur that he loses all the things that are inherently interesting about the legend to begin with.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A vital and spellbinding documentary that dissects a fascinating moment in American history.
When Snatched lands a joke, which it does from time to time, it garners big laughs. The movie just isn't consistently funny, despite some bright spots.
One of those movies that every horror buff needs to see.
Ben is to Willard what Aliens is to Alien.
It's thrilling when a science-fiction story aims this high. The series is on solid ground with Alien: Covenant.
The studio and filmmakers have vomited up a loud, unfocused, utterly nonsensical Transformers mess.
In a long, distinguished career full of great performances, Sam Elliott gives one of his best here.
This nifty little B-movie is surprisingly satisfying.
Rough Night has its flaws, but it's funny enough to generally overcome them, and the chance to see so many wonderful actresses displaying their comedic skills is a pleasure.
Trey Edward Shults. Make sure you remember that name. Burn it into your brain. It Comes at Night solidifies what a major talent he is.
A riveting and even inspiring look at two prominent adversaries who came together to do what was right. Magnificently accomplished performances from Spall and Meaney.
There are great movies you admire, and then there are great movies you admire that also make you deliriously happy. Baby Driver is the latter.
A real charmer. The film serves as a fine modern-day example of slapstick comedy.
The Mummy is the perfect movie if you love mindless big-budget special effects extravaganzas but absolutely hate having fun.
Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie perfectly captures the goofy spirit of its source material. Plus, it has a theme song performed by Weird Al, so how can it go wrong?
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The beautiful message of Wonder Woman is that attributes commonly associated with women - compassion, empathy, and protectiveness - are the most awesome superpowers of all.
The magic of Vincent N Roxxy comes from the performances. If there was any justice in the movie world, Zoe Kravitz's work here would propel her onto the A-list.
This misguided comedy has zero perspective on the low-grade titillation that made the series weirdly popular.
Wakefield is a must-see for fans of Bryan Cranston.
While admittedly atmospheric and stylishly made, the picture does have some problems generating the kind of chills it clearly wants to elicit.
A sci-fi action/adventure with Scarlett Johansson and big-budget effects ought to be a lot more fun than this.
Experimental, bold, creatively dangerous, and over-the-top crazy.
Even if it can't match its predecessor, The Golden Circle still offers enough lunatic fun to prove reasonably satisfying.
Star Wars: The Last Jedi successfully combines the thrill-a-minute fun that's always been part of the saga with a fresh spin on the light/dark theme embedded into the epic tale's DNA.
There are forty minutes of A+ movie here. Then the story you came to see is tossed in the garbage can and replaced with a different one.
A riveting, urgent bit of cinematic storytelling. One of the best films of Spielberg's illustrious career.
It's time for the Barden Bellas to either exit stage left or be dragged off by the hook.
Jessica Chastain has what may be the very best part of her career with Molly's Game. Given her impressive filmography so far, that's saying a lot. She's on fire in this role.
There's a great movie hiding somewhere in Hostiles - one that's a little shorter and got some nuance. The one being released is a good movie with a few flaws. Good's still good, though.
While it may not be the most original animated movie ever, Ferdinand differentiates itself with an interesting message about animal cruelty.
In the Fade is a real stunner that lingers in the mind long after it's over. Diane Kruger gets the best role of her career so far .
A crackling kidnapping tale, but also a spellbinding look at how being wealthy beyond measure affects one's view of the world.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Bening and Bell sell the material, creating an unlikely partnership that earns your compassion.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Certain words come to mind after seeing Proud Mary: oof, ugh, and blecch. It's a shambles, bearing the hallmarks of significant post-production troubles.
I watched the entirety of The Road Movie with my mouth agape. I'm not entirely sure how this film exists, but it does, and it's kind of awesome.
As funny as Paddington 2 is - and it's really funny - the movie's big heart is perhaps its finest quality.
This is a shallow movie based on a fascinating piece of U.S. military history. It isn't the worst war picture ever made. The real-life heroes deserve better, though.
Disaster movies are often silly fun. Geostorm is way too heavy on the silly, which makes it not as much fun as it could, or should, have been.
The kind of film that could change minds and open hearts.
How do you take an utterly fascinating true story and turn it into something dull and predictable? See Winchester to find out the answer to that question.
Good, gory fun for fans of splatter cinema.
The problem with The Hurricane Heist is not that it's stupid. The problem is that it isn't stupid enough.
When a film doesn't know how to deal with a tough subject honestly, it does so with dishonesty instead. The Leisure Seeker is one of the most dishonest pictures of its type ever made.
An exploitation masterpiece.
Explicit and boundary-pushing. Engrossing for audience members unafraid of edginess.
Exciting, provocative genre cinema.
The movie oozes eerie atmosphere and sinks its teeth into you.
The film undermines its own drama by waiting until the final seconds to inform the audience of what we're supposed to have spent the last 110 minutes caring about.
I've been a horror movie buff for decades. I have never seen anything quite like what I saw in the last fifteen minutes of this film.
Director/co-writer Ryan Coogler has delivered a picture that earns its spot as one of Marvel's best yet.
If you can see the humor in making a Number 2, don't miss this uproarious tribute to toilet action.
From a storytelling point of view, The Gruesome Twosome is a mess.
Why this saga went from the tale of a young woman's introduction into the world of BDSM to a straight-to-DVD level kidnapping thriller is a mystery.
Basmati Blues clearly wants to be a Western take on a Bollywood movie. In reality, it's a "Bollywoof" movie, which is to say, a Bollywood wannabe that's a real dog.
Spot-on in terms of tone and performance, Game Night never goes off the rails, even in its most outrageous moments. The only goal here is to generate laughter, and boy, does it ever succeed.
A sweet, charming little picture. Danny Pudi is winning in the lead role.
Everyone involved in the making of Just Getting Started should be charged with war crimes. Okay, that's obviously just a joke, but my gosh, what an endurance test this movie is.
Denzel Washington turns in one of the most interesting performances of his career. The film itself isn't quite on his level, but he makes it worth seeing
The LEGO Ninjago Movie isn't quite as joke-packed as its predecessors, although it offers plenty of laughs nonetheless.
It's no masterpiece, but it makes a complex story breezy and engaging.
A dreary, overly self-serious faith-based film, with little to distinguish it outside of some swearing.

The desire to tug at your heartstrings starts to feel desperate after a while. The Stray doesn't just want to make you cry, it wants to reach right into your eye sockets and squeeze your tear ducts until there's not an ounce of moisture left.
A brainy, emotional, and captivating survival tale.
A bit of a mixed bag. Has several good jump scares and a few hard-to-ignore flaws.
There's no conceivable way that a Blade Runner sequel could be more satisfying to anyone who loves its predecessor.
A scattershot mess that's unsatisfying, despite showing signs of real potential.
Happy Death Day is as much a dark comedy as it is a horror film. And it's a pretty darn funny one, at that.
Provides blood-dripping horror entertainment, while also delivering a character-based story worth becoming invested in.
Only the Brave might be the best movie ever made about firefighters.
A sharp, observant, and respectful look at young women who are willing to consider reshaping their entire lives to serve God.
There's not really anything here you don't already know. Nevertheless, the film is dramatically compelling, with excellent performances.
An impressively spot-on spoof.
A monumental achievement in documentary filmmaking. Profound and transformative, it utterly absorbs you for every single second of its running time.
The movie has a freewheeling quality that previous Thor entries lacked. Also, Jeff Goldblum gets to go 'full Goldblum.'
The plot is slapped together, with an excess of music montages used to pad everything out. Seriously, A Bad Moms Christmas has enough music montages to make Rocky IV jealous.
If you can't relate to this movie, you probably somehow went from childhood right into adulthood, completely skipping over adolescence.
Coco continues Pixar's streak of pushing the boundaries of how deep an animated family feature can go.
Woody Allen's most unpleasant film.
This adult fairy tale is perhaps the riskiest film of Guillermo del Toro's career, but those risks generally pay off. A visually spectacular fantasy romance.
The Disaster Artist deserves to stand alongside Tim Burton's Ed Wood as an appreciation of someone whose creative enthusiasm somehow managed to shine through their total lack of talent.

A real rarity - a family-friendly picture that isn't corny, assumes kids are sophisticated enough to grasp its themes without condescension, and contains an uplifting message that viewers of all ages will be inspired by.

A riveting, impressively detailed, frequently hilarious look at a unique form of American idiocy - namely, the misguided belief that it's easy to get away with bad behavior when the spotlight is shining on or near you.
A 115-minute cinematic scream of rage. The picture is as weirdly cathartic as it is entertaining.
There's an abundance of authenticity up on the screen, which ensures that you don't know what's coming until it happens, and you don't know how hard it'll hit you until it already has.
Call Me by Your Name is a work that I admired for its technique and performances. I did not, however, enjoy the way it made me feel.
The good news is that Justice League is a big step up from Batman v Superman. The bad news is that it's also a big step down from Wonder Woman.
Were there no sordid behavior on Louis CK's part, it's possible that I might have recommended the film. But in this case, separating the art from the artist is impossible.
A big, crazy genre picture that isn't afraid to go for broke.
A lazy, uninspired sequel that, thanks to Mel Gibson's participation, leaves a sour taste in one's mouth.
The film as a whole is a bit flawed, but when you put such a glorious piece of acting into the recreation of a captivating piece of history, it's hard to go too far wrong.
Tries to cram in so many old-Hollywood ideas that it causes the plot to lose focus.
movie_title: Won Ton Ton, the Dog Who Saved Hollywood (1976)

movie_review_blurb: Yes, it's a ripoff of Alien. And that's okay because it's a darn good ripoff.
The half-baked philosophizing and predictable outcome make the picture an endurance test for your patience.
This pitiful sequel is destined to go down as one of the most epic cinematic disasters of modern times.
A fun, effective popcorn thriller, perfect for summer viewing. It provides a steady dose of thrills and an A+ Blake Lively performance.
An appealingly offbeat and intelligent teen comedy.
Hunt for the Wilderpeople manages to be touching without turning sappy, and funny without relying on cheap humor.

The Legend of Tarzan is indicative of a trend that's been plaguing cinema for a while now. This is a prime example of a Franchise Starter. It is not designed to be one movie, it's designed to be at least three movies.
Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates is many things: a showcase for labored sex gags, a massive waste of talent, an exercise in tedium...
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Secret Life of Pets is the kind of movie that will make a lot of people happy. It sticks to a subject many of us are very familiar with, then uses that subject to create jokes that will ring a bell with any pet owner.
Takes two cool things and combines them in a really pleasurable, family-friendly way.
movie_title: LEGO DC Comics Super Heroes: Justice League - Gotham City Breakout (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A meticulously-told true story that gives you a portrait of the complexities, big and small, that make undercover operations risky.

Ghostbusters has hilarious performances, superb effects, a killer soundtrack, phenomenal 3D, and sharp jokes. Put all those things together and they add up to 116 minutes of great ghostbusting fun. This movie is a blast.

Television has changed so dramatically since 1984 that the film has lost a lot of its direct relevance. There's still fun to be had, it's just that the sting isn't as great as it likely was when it initially aired.
One of the stupidest and most offensive movies I've seen in more than twenty years as a film critic.
The issue is that Beyond tries to be a "hip" Star Trek story. Star Trek can be many things; hip is not one of them.
A spooky, visually creative picture that sucks you in with its atmosphere and good old-fashioned "boo factor."
The first one to really get a semblance of the first movie's charm back. It's easily the best of the sequels.
Anyone who thinks political correctness has run amok needs to see this film. Anyone who thinks it hasn't needs to see it even more.
It strings the audience along, promising to give more explanation to things that have already been explained in the previous movies.
It's exactly the kind of picture you'd expect to be released on Labor Day weekend: dumb, shoddy, and forgettable.
A movie that has some undeniable inspirational appeal, but also one that's so sluggishly told that the appeal is moderately blunted.
This is the kind of film that just makes you nuts for ninety minutes, which is the highest compliment it can be paid.
A joyride that offers some solid thrills and a couple of good laughs.
Exquisitely acted and creepy as hell. Christopher Lloyd gives one of the year's most essential-to-see performances.
movie_title: I Am Not a Serial Killer (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A treat for viewers of all ages, Kubo and the Two Strings is nothing less than an animated masterpiece.
Nothing more than a 105-minute salute to mindless gunfire and punching.
With a gripping true story and a handful of accomplished performances, War Dogs turns out to be the biggest, nicest surprise of the 2016 summer movie season.
An astoundingly misbegotten film. Thoroughly incompetent.
A film that combines rampant sermonizing with muscular dudes beating the crap out of each other. It's every bit as bizarre as it sounds.
There's not a ton of depth to The Mind's Eye, but as a punchy, gruesomely funny horror movie, it succeeds quite well.
While far from perfect, Suicide Squad is a step forward for the DC Cinematic Universe after the utter disaster that was Batman v Superman.
A beautifully-acted movie that probes some of the darker elements of the human psyche with style and undeniable scariness.
There are more than enough big laughs to satisfy. And underneath it all is a pretty sincere message about how it's okay for parents to make mistakes sometimes.
Sausage Party is like a Pixar movie that's gotten hopped up on crystal meth and Viagra.
A mind-blowing document of creation and deception. Every second of the film leaves you captivated.

You probably won't understand everything on the first viewing, but you'll likely understand enough to make you want to go back and watch it again. A provocative science-fiction film can ask for no higher compliment.
Two hours of pure, wonderfully silly entertainment.
This gloriously goofy little film lets you be the central figure in a rollicking adventure full of danger, mayhem, and carnage. Pop some Dramamine and go for one heck of a wild ride.
If you want to see DC superheroes taking each other on, this is a far more entertaining option than Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice.
It's pretty clear that the film's arguments against Shaken Baby Syndrome are highly questionable. Once you start peeling back the layers, they begin to unravel.
13 Cameras is the kind of thing that messes with your mind and starts to do some damage.
Criminal is intermittently entertaining, but when you squander a cast like this and a cool sci-fi premise, intermittent entertainment equals overall disappointment.
Never quite hits the sweet spot in balancing action and humor. The film clunkily moves back and forth between them, rather than getting them to work in unison.
TCM 2 works because it's a complete original. You never know from minute to minute where it's going to go, and that unpredictability keeps you riveted for every single second.
Sharp, funny, and infectiously nostalgic. Everybody Wants Some!! is filled with moments where you relate to the youthful, carefree spirit Linklater so carefully evokes.
Holidays has one story that's a dud, two that are okay but would have been better longer, and five that are solid. That's more than enough for a recommendation.

As with many prequels, it exists largely because a Hollywood studio wants a franchise, not because someone had a great story that they were passionate about telling. The movie sadly feels too much like the "product" it is.
For whatever it lacks formally, Dolemite is a fun, fascinating piece of cultural history.
Part of the reason why it works so well is that you gradually realize there's something far more substantive going on, and that makes the bits that work hit even harder.
A 90-minute bore. Many of the scenes take place either on the phone or via FaceTime, so you don't even get the pleasure of seeing these talented actresses onscreen together sometimes.
If you want a well-rounded horror film that has more going on than a serious ick factor, this one comes up a bit lacking.
Exciting and ingeniously conceived, this is Marvel working at the top of its cinematic game.
The film feels like a fairy tale as re-imagined by the staff of your local Hot Topic.

Sundown is effective as the story of a kid who is too easily influenced by his friend and who makes a very stupid mistake in pursuit of a girl. It is not effective when it turns violent or starts including an abundance of homophobic and transphobic humor.
Beyond the Gates is wicked, witty fun that reminds you how insanely entertaining the horror genre can be.
A celebration of motion pictures and their power to impact people. Inspiring and endearing.
movie_title: Raiders!: The Story of the Greatest Fan Film Ever Made (2016)

movie_review_blurb: James Wan's ability to take standard chiller conventions and find unexpected ways to execute them ensures that, despite a few weaknesses, The Conjuring 2 holds you in its grasp.

Now You See Me 2, like its characters, uses misdirection to distract an audience. It goes in ten different directions simultaneously, all in the hope that it will seem like you have seen something that you really haven't.
A pitch-perfect spoof of both the modern-day music scene and a social media-obsessed culture that believes you only have worth if everyone's watching your every move.
Suitably goofy and surprisingly entertaining. Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows effectively demonstrates how a movie series can fix itself when it's broken.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Finding Dory might not hit the emotional highs of Nemo, but it's right on track with everything else. An immensely satisfying family film.

Tries to be a continuation of the previous two chapters, while also serving as an origin story for characters who appeared in the first wave of X-Men pictures. This leads to a muddled story that feels like it's going forward and backward simultaneously.
How to Be Single shows that rom-coms can be artfully made and intelligent, rather than dumb and pandering.
It captures a lot of what's so enjoyable about the mobile app, which is really all it needs to do.
Neighbors 2: Sorority Rising adds a very cool feminist twist, but that twist can't disguise the fact that the movie really isn't all that funny.
The Nice Guys is like James Ellroy by way of Abbott & Costello. Frequently hilarious, often surprising, and consistently fun.
A weird mashup of cliches that don't go together and appear to have been assembled by someone with no understanding of actual human behavior or motivation.

Works slightly better as a hostage drama than as an expose of Wall Street corruption, but that's okay, because the performances are so good and the pace is so quick that you don't really have time to quibble until after it's over.

One of the most riveting and remarkable documentaries I have ever seen. If you have even the most remote interest in politics or human behavior, Weiner is a movie you cannot afford to miss under any circumstances.
A funny, honest, and moving slice-of-life film that has an undeniable ring of truth.
Both an admiring recreation of the Miracle on the Hudson and a poignant reflection on how an ordinary, yet supremely competent man declines to exalt himself as a hero.
A compendium of every indie movie cliché about unhappy, confused twenty-somethings.
A rousing, uplifting tribute to three unsung American heroes. Splendid performances give the film full power.
If you like watching dull characters and unconvincing CGI beasts engage in generic fighting on bargain-basement sets, this is the movie you've been waiting for!
Patriots Day is a tense movie that honors human strength during the darkest of hours.

The Bye Bye Man is one of the most amateurish wide-release movies I've ever seen. Why anyone thought this thing was in good enough shape to warrant an opening in more than 2,000 theaters is a mystery.
A funny and insightful film. The story of how McDonalds became McDONALDS is enough to make you never want to eat at McDonalds again.
The Red Turtle is an elegant reminder that hand-drawn animation has a unique grace that no CGI animation can replicate, regardless of how well it's executed.
The patented "Shyamalan twist" completely derails what is, for a time, a very well-crafted chiller.
A new spin makes any formula worth watching one more time. Watching a movie just go through the motions, as this one does, is a one-way ticket to zoning out.
To paraphrase the comedy Tropic Thunder, you never go "full McConaughey." In Gold, Matthew McConaughey goes full McConaughey.
At my screening, two guys sitting a few rows down from me smoked what appeared to be marijuana throughout the movie. I'm not condoning drug use, but they probably had the right idea.
Robert DeNiro does what he can, but the bottom line is that he's seriously miscast.
The film is funny and insightful, outrageous but still grounded.
Rings spent nearly a year-and-a-half sitting on a shelf. For all intents and purposes, it could have just stayed there indefinitely.
An exceptional lead performance from Zoe Kazan makes the film stand out from the crowd.
A really cheesy soap opera with intermittent scenes of smutty sex. It's certainly better than the first one, albeit that's a low bar to clear.
A fun, frenetic action picture.
Regardless of your age, gender, or other defining characteristics, if you are even remotely interested in Batman, you can have a grand old time at this funny, charming picture.
if you have an appreciation for horror-thrillers that push boundaries, The Belko Experiment is an admirably messed-up work of nihilism.
Mean Dreams may not be particularly original, but with an effectively somber atmosphere and first-rate performances, it's a sufficiently entertaining little thriller.
Indie horror doesn't get much more stylish or creepy than The Devil's Candy.
The movie knows precisely what it takes to deliver mayhem that makes you smile and lean in so that you can savor every awesomely chaotic second.
In the way it explores the inescapable nature of violence and its long-term effects, Logan is the Unforgiven of superhero cinema.
A provocative, probing - and yes, often funny - look at the role humor plays in coming to terms with the darkest, most troubling events mankind faces.
This is a funny, inventive, and gorgeously animated adventure showcasing some colorful characters and a bold, original setting.
For anyone in search of an action extravaganza with a nice touch of humanity on the side, this is a can't-miss movie.
One of the boldest, most audacious major studio movies to come along in quite some time. From the opening titles to the end credits, Get Out holds you in its grasp.
A heartfelt, poignant movie, and further proof that animation is a viable means with which to tell complex human stories.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Fist Fight is a mixed bag. The film is amusing without ever becoming the side-splitter it obviously wants to be.
King Solomon's Mines is frequently laughable. Nothing about the film is convincingly done.
Land of Mine is absolutely riveting from start to finish, both on a thematic and a visceral level. It tenses your muscles and engages your mind simultaneously.
While the monster battles are undeniably entertaining, The Great Wall comes to a screeching halt whenever it focuses on the people. The characters are frustratingly paper-thin, as is the plot.
The twisted tales range from "pretty bad" to "mediocre."
Paterson, represents director Jim Jarmusch doing everything he does well to the best of his abilities.
This isn't a terrible movie. But a middling one? Most definitely.
Imperfect though it may be, the movie explores a 'What would you do?' moral issue with enough inquisitiveness and entertainment value to make for a reasonably engaging two hours.

You could be forgiven for completely writing off the movie. But don't. In what ranks as one of the year's happiest surprises, this is a terrific old-school fright flick that delivers both chills and substance.
Whoever cut that theatrical trailer should be given an Oscar. They made a confused, frustratingly muddled picture look coherent.
Fascinating and sometimes funny. This is one of the most candid behind-the-scenes documentaries of recent times because the interviewees have no reason to suppress their true feelings.
movie_title: Doomed: The Untold Story Of Roger Corman's The Fantastic Four (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Puts a cool, inventive, modern-day twist on the whole concept of a Godzilla flick.

Both exhilarating and frustrating. Exhilarating in that it's a rare mainstream Hollywood film filled with strong female characters, frustrating in that the storytelling around those characters is needlessly muddled.
It tries to be both a political allegory and a horror movie, never quite finding a way to meld the two together smoothly. Consequently, this is a film more easily admired than enjoyed.

Dropping Madea into a comic Halloween adventure should have been a recipe for fun. Dropping her into one that recycles jokes and celebrates the virtues of beating children proves to be the exact opposite of fun.
movie_title: Tyler Perry's Boo! A Madea Halloween (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This is the kind of not great/not terrible picture that will work better on a casual home viewing than as a big screen experience.
Substantive and satisfying, with something beautiful to look at in every inch of the frame.
movie_title: Long Way North (Tout en haut du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A family film this charming is always a treat.
The Magnificent Seven has no real substance, meaning, or depth. It simply is what it is: a breezy Western adventure with a bunch of name actors. On that level, it works.
Upbeat and meaningful. Effectively showcases how the band's work has touched lives everywhere.
In spite of some stabs at freshness in presenting the found footage requisites, Blair Witch is largely stuck going through the motions established by its predecessor.
A gripping, provocative, and scary look at a whistleblower whose revelations shocked the world.
Works extremely well as both a nail-biting recreation of a horrific accident and as a celebration of the American worker.
A perverse film, both in its humor and its horror.
Captivating! Over the course of 87 minutes, you come to really care about this girl, not just for what she accomplishes, but for who she is.
Shut In is a very bad movie anchored by a very good lead performance.
A Monster Calls is a masterpiece of imagination. Movies like this don't come around very often, and when they do, they're worth cherishing.
A brilliant, deeply human adaptation of a masterwork.
Rogue One feels more like a movie with Star Wars stuff in it than an actual Star Wars movie.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: What begins as an intelligent probe into the world of lobbying ends up a generic thriller that's more about the "surprise" twists than about the actual subject matter.
A first-rate cast and some moments of sharp humor give it enough kick to be a good time.
La La Land fills your soul with joy and happiness. A dazzling work that you want to see again the very second its over.
Great fun! Doctor Strange has everything you'd want or expect from a Marvel adventure, but it also feels fresh and new.
A sensitive and occasionally stinging look at how death disrupts life.
A profoundly haunting and powerful film that examines grief in its most raw form. Natalie Portman is extraordinary.
Mesmerizing and entertaining. A movie that rattles around in your head for days after you see it.
The picture works better as a portrait of a man worried about what his wife might be withholding from him than it does as a WWII story.
What begins as a light, jaunty look at how sane people deal with disturbed-but-important bigwigs morphs into a scattershot mess.
A great deal of imagination has clearly been pumped into the movie, ensuring that it's continually enjoyable to watch.
A darkly compelling look at what a tortured soul can do. Isabelle Huppert is superb.
Lion tells one of those amazing true stories that only a pure cynic could fail to be captivated by.
This irredeemably awful film should only be viewed under threat of grievous bodily harm. And even then, you should give your choice some careful consideration.
While there's much to admire, the film also falls victim to the pitfalls that plague many found footage movies.
A fine example of next-level stupidity. In fact, if they gave Oscars for stupidity, it would win them all.
The most daring, original, and innovative horror movie I've seen in more than a decade.
Has a nice Twilight Zone-style vibe to it, yet the story tips its hand too soon, thanks to some clues that might as well have been lit by neon signs.
Incredibly moving. Even if you don't have a three-story screen in your home, the film still works marvelously.
Seeing a movie in which three other actors play the Stooges is akin to watching an Elvis impersonator. Sure, it looks like a duck and it quacks like a duck, but it most certainly is not a duck.
The most frustrating thing is that The Lucky One is the kind of movie in which the lead character has to be an idiot in order for the story to progress.
May not have the same laugh-per-minute ratio of Jason Segel's previous films - or those of producer Judd Apatow, for that matter - yet it's a very charming, insightful picture that won me over.
An earnest, good-hearted movie.
The Perfect Family is a tiny treasure, a rare story that's willing to look at what faith means and how it truly applies to our everyday lives.
A movie about a gospel music competition should be fun and inspiring; Joyful Noise is lumbering and dull.
Marvel's grand plan turned out to be a good one. This is a hugely entertaining time at the movies.

I found The Cup to be a pleasant-enough viewing experience. At the same time, I was never as riveted as I have been by other, similarly-themed films. It makes you feel good without ever truly stirring the soul.
Dark Shadows is a great big mess, utterly lacking in inspiration.
Battleship is ultimately too derivative for my taste. I'd be lying if I said I didn't have a tiny bit of fun with it, though.
Did a third installment in this series need to exist? No, but it offers enough new variations on the formula to make me glad it does.
A Necessary Death will make you squirm and think in equal measure. For my money, that makes it a picture worth paying attention to.

Slick and stylish, with an overriding desire to show you the grittier flip side of a famous fairy tale we usually see portrayed with more lightness. I surrendered to its pleasures, in spite of its shortcomings.
With its too-short runtime, sloppy sense of plotting, and poor CGI, Piranha 3DD feels like a cheap-o, direct-to-DVD sequel that somehow got a more prominent summer release.
The similarly-plotted Attack the Block, which isn't technically a comedy, is leagues funnier than The Watch, which is.
A bold film for people who aren't afraid to laugh at a movie that cheerfully breaks all sense of civility and decorum.
This is an amazingly brave piece of filmmaking, in that it stares directly into the abyss - and then pulls out one hell of a satisfying ending.
Savages has the components to skirt greatness, only to repeatedly trip over its own feet.
Despite an occasional lack of narrative clarity, Patang has enough visual elegance and observant family dynamics to make it worth seeing.
A fascinating and surprisingly intimate look at the person inside the superstar.
It's everything you could ever want from a Jim Brown prison movie.

I've heard a lot of griping that critics are objecting to the idea of a too-soon reboot more than to the movie itself. Let me make it clear that this critic (and longtime Spidey fan) is objecting to the sluggish pacing and sloppy storytelling.
A sweetly kooky ode to the intensity of young love. The movie balances broad comedy with occasionally surreal quirk, while still holding the emotional center.
The movie may not totally succeed in what it wants to do, but neither should it be dismissed.
Even though it's not entirely successful, there is an undeniably oddball charm on display.
It's like someone ate an '80s record collection, puked it up, and then ran it through a film projector.
An intense and thought-provoking piece of sci-fi, with enough moments of sheer horror to give audiences a jolt and enough intelligence to keep them thinking afterward.
The whole movie has such an air of giddy adventure that I had a good time with it. Journey 2: The Mysterious Island is charming, in spite of its imperfections.
A clever and outrageous comedy that hits far more than it misses.
Corny, obvious, and shallow as a puddle, it traffics in outdated stereotypes, overused cliches, and ham-handed emotions. Trust me: your 80 year-old grandmother will love this movie.
Insightful and often very funny. A thoroughly enjoyable documentary.
movie_title: Comic-Con: Episode IV - A Fan's Hope (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A briskly-paced documentary that does what every good cinema verite-style film should: it illuminates its subject so that you are compelled, whether that subject is of natural interest to you or not.
An example of what makes indie filmmaking great: deeply personal storytelling done with enormous conviction.
Meryl Streep is phenomenal. Everything about The Iron Lady that ISN'T Meryl Streep is pretty much a letdown.
War Horse is like a cross between The Black Stallion, Saving Private Ryan, and Slacker. If my description sounds unappealing, please know that I compare it to those other pictures very favorably.

Newlyweds is funny, but never at the expense of its ideas. Whereas most relationship comedies these days are contrived and dopey, this one strives to be more truthful, and it succeeds. A solid, insightful human comedy.
Contraband generally succeeds well at what it wants to do. It is a gritty, exciting film, with some cool action sequences and a cathartic conclusion.
This powerful, provocative movie breaks your heart and sends a chill up your spine simultaneously.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Coriolanus illustrates that the Bard's works are still as relevant as they are open to new interpretations. And this is easily one of the best interpretations I've seen.
Red Tails is simply not as triumphant as it should have been. It gets some things right, but the stuff it gets wrong is difficult to get past.
A poignant tale of a person who just wants to be happy, to live in freedom, to be herself.

As directed by Stephen Daldry, this adaptation of Jonathan Safran Foer's novel hauls out memories and images from 9/11 in an attempt to create fake sentiment and to accentuate its own sense of self-importance. Quite frankly, I found that offensive.
There's not a lot of breathing when you watch this movie. It makes you hold your breath at regular intervals, and scarcely gives you time to exhale.
This is an ingenuous, albeit imperfect, film.
I'm sure writer/director Danny Buday was trying to make something profound, yet he displays a chronic inability to generate momentum.
The "let's find a Christmas tree" plot is more in the vein of the original than the outlandish Guantanamo Bay plot was, and the Cho/Penn chemistry remains charming.
Effectively written, directed, and acted, Rampart is a grimly fascinating portrait of a guy who swore to uphold the law, but ended up staring into the abyss that is himself.
It's gory, sick, depraved, funny, self-knowingly silly, and entertaining if you're in the right frame of mind.
Despite a familiar plot, the solid acting and first-rate action scenes combine to make a movie that, while perhaps not terribly original, is certainly involving and entertaining.
Wrath of the Titans is the visual equivalent of white noise. I don't think I watched it so much as I just looked at it.
Not just an earnest race drama, but also a fascinating example of how social issues were addressed cinematically in an earlier era.
Movies are supposed to whisk you away, to make you get lost in their stories. I never got lost in From Time to Time because I was continually aware of the pieces being assembled before me.
I maintain that, while it may be a failure, it's an ambitious failure.
In book form, The Hunger Games was smart, provocative, exciting, and fun. The movie is all those things too. Everything comes together to bring a terrific story to life in a different format.
It is smart, silly, straightforward, conceptual, satiric, raunchy, and character-based, all at once. I laughed often and I laughed hard.
Overlong and excruciatingly unfunny. It ends up telling the same old jokes in the same old ways.
Rather than trying to entertain us, director Tom Six goes all out in an attempt to make us sick, to offend our very sensibilities. He has succeeded. And screw him for that.
Funny and charming.
A monumental act of stupidity and vapidness.
While not without its flaws, Wanderlust is a funny and intriguing adult comedy. Smarter than you might expect.
This is a movie that packs in a lot of very cool action while still addressing its themes intelligently. It's one to seek out.
With its visual gimmickry, attention-seeking camerawork, and in-your-face special effects, Ghost Rider: Spirit of Vengeance spends so much time trying to be badass that it forgets to be good.
Made with equal parts style and compassion, this is one of the best docs you're likely to see this year, football fan or not.
It isn't that John Carter is bad, it's just really mediocre. And mediocrity is deadly in this genre.
The performances are amateur (at best), the formula is predictable, and there's nothing scary going on here.
Few things are as cinematically woeful as a movie that tries to say something profound but only ends up stating the obvious. 360 is as fine an example of this as you will find.
The film gets at a universal truth: everyone knows how to deal with their own crazy family, but dealing with the crazy family of your significant other takes some real adjustment.
It is an imbecilic film. Look that up in your Funk and Wagnalls.
Riveting as both character study and morality tale. Another milestone performance from Denzel Washington.
The longer it went on, the more eager I was for it to be over.
What could have been an appealing, offbeat romance is instead little more than Twilight for the arthouse crowd.
A lazy movie that gives us too little of what COULD be funny and way too much of what will NEVER be funny.
Polished, tightly-paced, and extraordinarily entertaining, Skyfall is a total blast. It gets every major thing you could want from a 007 movie exactly right.
Nature Calls promises a silly good time, only to display little interest in fulfilling that promise.
A lively, intelligent, and even fun examination of how one man inspired America to change forever.
