An intelligent, funny, insightful film that offers a frank examination of sex. It's not prurient or titillating, just truthful.
Gorgeously photographed and filled with first-rate special effects, Life of Pi is a wonderfully unique and special film. The 3D represents a new gold standard.
I found it extremely difficult to become emotionally invested because the style kept intruding, pulling me out of Anna's journey and making me concentrate on the filmmaking choices.
A terrific holiday movie. Edward Burns' most invigorating, heartfelt picture in years.

Rise of the Guardians is kind of like The Avengers, except that instead of superheroes, the characters are people your parents lied to you about when you were a kid. It could become a perennial family favorite.
Hopelessly dumb and often unintentionally funny. As with everything about this nutty series, I couldn't shake the feeling that Stephenie Meyer's creation is just kooky in all the wrong ways.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: While undeniably flawed, Hitchcock remains a breezy, entertaining show-biz tale.
The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey is like 90 minutes of flirting, an hour of foreplay, and no sex. In other words, it's fun, but not entirely satisfying.
Like most of Apatow's movies, it's a half-hour too long and filled with too many side characters. Also like most of his movies, it's often very funny.
A masterpiece of imagination. Offers wall-to-wall goofy fun for fans of martial arts flicks, fantasies, or just good old-fashioned cinematic nuttiness.
movie_title: Bai she chuan shuo (The Sorcerer and the White Snake) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Cabaret is in some respects a typical feel-good musical, yet it's also so much deeper than that.

While it may not be the scathing indictment of the "business" of selling meds that it could - and probably should - be, Side Effects still gets credit for asking some of the right questions and delivering a few intelligent thrills.
I never thought I'd use the word "sweet" to describe a zombie flick, but that's exactly what Warm Bodies is.
Painfully unfunny, inordinately stupid, and about as entertaining as a colonoscopy. If there's a worse film in 2013, I'll be very, very surprised.
Powerful and shocking.
Visually dazzling, superbly acted, and massively ambitious. I'm going to be obsessed with this visionary saga for a while.
Consistently engaging, funny, and touching. This is the kind of picture in which two hours of running time whiz by in a flash.
I know that I, for one, will never look at my satellite dish the same way again. On second thought, yes I will.
Forget Texas Chainsaw 3D. For $11.75, I'll hold a chainsaw three inches from your face for an hour and a half. I'll even make you popcorn.
Django Unchained is everything you want from a Quentin Tarantino movie, with a few new things added in. Powerful, dazzling, and insanely entertaining.

The combination of strong mystery, eccentric characterization, off-kilter humor, and sporadic, yet effective, action makes Jack Reacher feel different from the garden variety tough-guy-solving-a-crime thriller.
This is one of the most gut-wrenching and emotional pictures I've ever seen. I walked away from it physically exhausted.
A lush, engaging take on the tale, filled with strong performances of both the musical and the dramatic variety.

Powerful and gripping, the movie is not only a fine document of the hunt for Public Enemy #1, but also a testament to the dedication of those in every corner of the military, government, and intelligence community who refused to give up the search.
Everything about it feels designed by committee, almost as though studio suits were more responsible for the film's creative direction than the actual filmmakers.
Steven Soderbergh has made a movie that works as both intimate character study and party film.
This fourth chapter is proof that the series has run out of ideas, it's all been done, there's nothing new to add, just pack up and go home.
Smart, scathing, and wildly, wildly funny, The Campaign marvelously exposes the idiocy that is holding our political system hostage.
While it may lack narrative sense, this is, without a doubt, one of the most unpredictable and hypnotic viewing experiences you could ever hope to have.
A thoroughly delightful movie that will entertain kids and adult horror buffs alike.
I'm willing to overlook a film's flaws a little bit if it's clearly aiming high in what it wants to do. Shuffle is indeed flawed, yet it is also intriguing and different.
It's a real eye-opener, a gutsy piece of investigative journalism mixed with a splash of performance art.
It moves like a bullet, has some effective chase sequences, and gives you Michael Shannon as one of the year's most memorable bad guys.
Searching for Sonny is a masterclass in how NOT to make a mystery. Or a comedy, for that matter.
When it was over, I had the strong desire to run to my Nintendo Wii and play some Tetris. And isn't that exactly the reaction a movie like this should want to induce?
movie_title: Ecstasy Of Order: The Tetris Masters (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The film is an observant examination of cognitive dissonance, the torment felt by a person who is simultaneously holding two completely opposite values.
Better than you'd expect but not as good as it could have been, The Possession is an average film that contains a few undeniably great moments.
Upon viewing this dubious exercise in sexual humor, I can only conclude that it was inspired in equal parts by the sexual revolution and heavy cocaine use.
movie_title: Stop It, or You'll Go Blind (1975)

movie_review_blurb: An awesomely crazy survival-horror joyride.
When The Words focused on its core subject, I perked up. When it went off on lackluster tangents - which it does for more than half of its running time - I grew impatient.
Filled with flawed ideas, subtle bigotry, and amateurish technique, Last Ounce of Courage tested my last ounce of patience.
The plot is content to stay at surface level, never truly working for big laughs when easy ones can be grasped instead.
This is a skillfully-made documentary with a point of view and a tender touch.
movie_title: The Right To Love: An American Family (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Director Paul W.S. Anderson really nails the feeling of a character walking into a room and opening fire upon a horde of nondescript bad guys, then walking into another room and doing the exact same thing, ad nauseum.

Always intriguing and often quite funny, Paul Williams Still Alive is exactly the documentary this celebrity deserves. It's respectful of his extraordinary accomplishments while giving us an accurate portrait of who Williams is today.
Argo isn't just fascinating because it's a true story, it's fascinating because Affleck tells the story well, building tension while always maintaining a very human-centered approach.
Nobody Walks is like mumblecore with stars.
By revisiting an idea from his past, Tim Burton feels emotionally connected to his material - and, by extension, his audience - for the first time in years.
If I owned this movie on a real VHS tape, I'd record over it.
Genuine walk-the-high-wire-without-a-net, swing-for-the-fences filmmaking. Bold, challenging, and unique.
Its strengths make it worth paying attention to, while its weaknesses prevent it from becoming the first-class chiller it had the potential to be.
Ninety-five straight minutes of information and perspective that will clarify many of the lingering doubts you may have about your medical treatment. Briskly paced, always engaging, and never dry.
movie_title: Escape Fire: The Fight to Rescue American Healthcare (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Keeps you mentally hopping, daring you to guess where it is headed, then cheerfully pulling the rug out from under you each time.

End of Watch is like an episode of "Cops" where the cops are also the people who make "Cops." That concept may not sound good, but it somehow did produce one of the most intense police dramas I've ever seen.
It's highly respectful of the work on which it is based, yet also a solidly entertaining effort in its own right.
movie_title: Batman: The Dark Knight Returns, Part 1 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Trouble with the Curve is a father/daughter relationship drama, an inside baseball movie, and a romantic comedy all wrapped together. That's at least one thing too many.
An important film that every athlete - or parent of an athlete - should see.
I felt like I'd wasted almost an hour-and-a-half of my life on a film that wasn't even going to bother giving me a complete story.
When corporations and organizations put money before people - and they do - everyone should wake up and pay attention. Doctored is a thought-provoking call to arms on that front.
An effective and entertaining portrait of how a young, starstruck man gets sucked into the dysfunction of the world's biggest movie star.
Just as I couldn't stop turning the pages of Larsson's novel, I couldn't take my eyes off Fincher's movie.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This is one of the most insane action movies I've seen in years. Something intense is happening almost every single second of its 132-minute running time.
Wonderful entertainment, anchored by two brilliant actors acting brilliantly together.
A witty and funny mumblecore mystery.
A master class in ineptitude.

Instead of trusting the performances and the potential of the material, it has been loaded with all the same jokes you find in a typical Adam Sandler comedy: fat jokes, gay jokes, crotch injury gags, etc.
Nicely balances the live performances with the documentary footage, creating a movie that moves briskly while simultaneously explaining and showcasing its subject.
Solid performances keep it entertaining, even if one does occasionally chuckle at the outdated discussions of sexual mores.
I Am Number Four could just as easily have been called 'Frankenmovie.' It takes bits and pieces from a lot of other films and simply assembles them in a different order.
A very good idea gets overwhelmed by an apparent need to throw in everything but the kitchen sink.
Comedy has always relied on the follies of clueless people. Caddyshack 2 doesn't have such follies in its plot, yet they permeate every single frame.
Hall Pass, despite its come-ons, is more interested in making men-are-horny-and-incompetent jokes than it is in exploring the myriad complications of its plot device.
Hits the sweet spot of being entertaining, informative, and deeply moving.
movie_title: The Elephant In The Living Room (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Finding a movie that can so successfully pull off romance and otherworldly mystery is rare. When one comes along, it's something that shouldn't be missed.
Rango is like Chinatown meets A Fistful of Dollars meets a Geico commercial. And it's totally awesome.
There's some fun to be had, even if Cannes Man never achieves the bulls-eye brilliance of Altman's The Player.
We all know a guy who is obsessed with military firepower and who spends way too much time playing first-person shooters on XBox 360. Battle: Los Angeles is a movie for that guy.
Enthusiastically acted and sharply written. A big old lovefest in honor of the classic alien visitation movies that we all hold near and dear.
Millions of adults grew up watching Yogi Bear cartoons, but instead of playing to those memories, it does as little as possible to technically qualify as a "Yogi Bear movie."
Crazy-good fun! Thor has that quintessential Marvel-movie feel that made the Spider-Man, X-Men, and Iron Man pictures so enjoyable.
While you certainly get plenty of bang for your buck in the gore department, the thing that most sets this movie apart is that it finds an actual emotional core for the story.
Watching Fast Five is like being savagely beaten for two hours and ten minutes by the staff at Advance Auto Parts.
Funny, touching, and beautifully acted, Win Win is definitely a victory in humanistic storytelling.

I've liked most of Perry's previous films, but this one didn't quite connect with me to the same degree. I think that's because you'd have a hard time finding a single scene that doesn't run on too long.

This sequel's requisite film geek character keeps espousing the idea that reboots are nothing more than lame, tired rip-offs of the original. Scream 4 seems to have been made entirely to prove that point.

This is a movie that introduces a very provocative idea, only to progressively water it down until the audience is left with a generic romantic comedy virtually indistinguishable from all the other generic romantic comedies.
Like a campfire story told well, it understands that the basic ability to catch you off guard is more effective than a lot of unnecessary flourishes.
Action cinema for audiences who crave something deeper than what you typically get.
Whether you choose to perceive it as a goof, a satire, or a little of both, Rubber is undeniably audacious.
You get your money's worth with excitement, yet when all is said and done, the movie has some actual thematic depth to it.
A movie that gets a lot of mileage out of good old-fashioned wish fulfillment. Consistently entertaining.
A wonderful film for anyone who still has a passion for watching the skies and wondering what's out there.
A picture that makes passionate love to your eyeballs while leaving your heart untouched.
Gets better as it goes along, although I was never rolling on the floor with laughter.
Bridesmaids is about as far from a dopey Kate Hudson/Katherine Heigl rom-com as you can get. It is smart where those other pictures are dumb, perceptive where the others are cliched.
This is one occasion where too many cooks in the kitchen actually ended up making some pretty tasty junk food.

If you hated not knowing what Murray whispered to Johansson at the end of Lost in Translation, you will hate Somewhere. Conversely, if you loved the fact that you don't know what he whispered, you will appreciate the beauty that Somewhere contains.
Very entertaining, with some of the most majestic CGI visuals ever put on film.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Even if you've never logged on to Facebook, you can still get caught up in the way The Social Network looks at issues of friendship, rivalry, inspiration, and the cutthroat nature of business.
Beautifully shot, sensitively directed, and elegantly scripted, it is a horror movie with the kind of substance and depth that 99% of genre fare lacks. It lingers in your mind and your heart.
The emotional action in The Town is just as gripping as the physical action.
When the entire movie is predictable, clichéd, and routine, what's the point in going out to see it? Hint: there is none.
It's everything a Jackass fan could want: projectile vomiting, male genitalia, and poop, all flying at your face in three dimensions.
It's kind of distressing how willing the movie is to tread the same old ground. It even goes so far as to replicate one of the original's best money shots.
I won't say that Pretty Maids All in a Row is a good film by any traditional measure. It is, however, a genuine curio.
movie_title: Pretty Maids All in a Row (1971)

movie_review_blurb: While it may sound dry on the surface, Stone packs his movie with enough provocative insights to keep the audience invested.
Hereafter is an entertaining film. That said, it would have been even better had it picked any one of the plot strands and focused exclusively on it.
Atmospheric and inventive. A little indie worth looking for.
Slightly predictable, but also warm and entertaining.
Megamind is fast and funny, with excellent use of 3D.
Unstoppable doesn't try to be much more than a runaway train movie, and it's an effective runaway train movie. In fact, it's everything you could want from a runaway train movie.
Watching Due Date is kind of like taking a really lengthy car trip. Every so often, you see something awesome, but then there are long stretches of monotony in between.
The best-looking and best-acted film in the series so far. Drags a bit in the middle act. Otherwise, a solid wind-up for the grand finale.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The cast is terrific and the basic premise is pleasing, but a wavering tone robs Lottery Ticket of some of its power.
Rabbit Hole is beautifully made and acted, with a life-affirming point of view that makes it an intensely rewarding experience.
Like its predecessor, the movie has enough dazzling visuals and awesome action to generally compensate for a story that often feels a little thin.
True Grit is done with such inventiveness that I was in moviegoing ecstasy.
The film has an amazing ability to portray its main character's personal life with such authenticity that the boxing scenes become more than sport - they become a fight for life.
Fraudulent where it should be smart, impotent where it should be sexy, and dull where it should be exciting, The Tourist is a big star misfire of epic proportions.
The performances offer much to admire, while the story fails to provide the chilling intensity it so clearly wants to generate.
I couldn't shake the feeling that it might have been conceived and filmed as a comedy, then edited so that it plays like a thriller.
Horrible plotting, hilariously insipid dialogue, often-awkward performances - these things add up to a film you can joyfully ridicule with your friends.
Not a great film, but in a time when most romantic comedies are trite and predictable, this one at least tries to deal with an actual relationship hurdle.
A total delight that should please fans of classic Disney storytelling no matter what demographic they're in.
Visually creative, well-acted, and immensely immersive, it sends you out on a high, not on a low.
Mere words can barely describe the sheer inanity on display.
I suppose some people may respond to this nostalgic ode to innocence and chastity, but I found it insufferable.
I think young children will enjoy the movie very much, while adults will probably opt to go out into the kitchen and wash dishes while the tykes watch it.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: One of the gutsiest movies I've ever seen. How often do you sense a film is not just walking the high wire but jumping up and down on it?
Unspeakably awful.

Turning what should be a meditation on faith into a demon-possession flick probably seemed like a safe box office bet, but it also robbed The Rite of the opportunity to rise above what we usually get in movies about exorcisms.
Everything about this installment feels way past its expiration date. I wouldn't be surprised to find there was mold growing on the actual film prints.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's only real point of view is that the best things you can aspire to in life are to be "hot," to land a cute boy, and to become a famous pop star.
movie_title: A Cinderella Story: Once Upon A Song (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A wonderful celebration of Fishbone's spirit. It's one of the best rock docs I've ever seen.
movie_title: Everyday Sunshine: The Story of Fishbone (2011)

movie_review_blurb: If you pass on seeing Warrior simply because you don't like MMA, you're denying yourself the chance to see a solid, well-made, emotionally gripping movie.
Strong acting, atmospheric direction, and a nail-biting premise add up to a movie whose impact is hard to ignore.
Make Believe has it all: likable "characters" we want to follow, a subject that both astounds and amazes, and a mounting sense of suspense as the competition reaches its conclusion.
A daring work. More than once, I got little chills running up my spine from the audaciousness with which director Nicolas Winding Refn tells the tale.
I'm not sure I've ever seen a sports movie quite like this, and that's a major compliment.
Mixing humor and painful subject matter is, naturally, very difficult. The beauty of this movie is that it does so with ease.
The movie tries to generate suspense where none exists; creepy music and clanging metal sound effects play over top of scenes where nothing is happening.
A reasonably entertaining drama that holds your attention, even if it doesn't tell you anything new.
If you are willing to be taken to the edge of horror, this is a picture you'll want to pay attention to.
The Thing is imaginatively splatter-y, which kept me hooked.
Batman: Year One adapts Frank Miller's tale with excellent animation and first-rate voice work from a talented cast, finding a nice balance between human moments and exciting action sequences.
Has enough jump-out-of-your-seat moments to make it worth a look if you're a fan of the franchise - and if that's primarily all you seek. A decent-but-unremarkable sequel to a landmark in the genre.
The jokes and visual gags are very amusing, largely avoiding needless pop culture references and instead finding clever sources for humor.
If you're hungry for a romantic comedy that's really entertaining and doesn't insult your intelligence, here it is.
Tower Heist is goofy in a really, really delightful way.
One wonders why the filmmakers felt the need to turn a fascinating true story into a cliche-ridden, formulaic family film.
Whenever I see a great film, I get a literal high off it, almost like a drug. The feeling can last for days. The Artist gave me one of those highs.
It looks and feels like the movie you initially fell in love with, yet it offers little of the pleasure or magic that won you over in the first place.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The cinematic equivalent of a glass of flat champagne.
The film takes some shortcuts in the storytelling department that end up undermining the drama.
Hugo is a master filmmaker's gift to children. It teaches, in an age-appropriate way, why movies are important and why it's essential that we take care of them. One of Scorsese's best!
You are not likely to meet a more intriguing, unusual person in any other documentary you'll see this year.
Happy Feet Two is great to look at, but it goes off on odd tangents that prevent the plot from catching hold.
The Muppets marks a triumphant return for these beloved characters. This movie made me feel good all over.
The picture has more of a "greatest hits" feel, rather than the feeling of a comprehensive, vivid portrait of the man's life.
It's smart, funny, heartbreaking, heartwarming, wise, and, despite some sad moments, genuinely optimistic. I experienced more feelings watching it than I usually get from ten movies.
It is very focused on the idea of Not Pissing Off The Fans By Getting It Wrong. As a relative outsider, I found that this mentality sucked all the life out of the film.
A masterfully-made, superbly-acted movie with admirably big ideas to explore.

Howard the Duck, Gigli, Showgirls, From Justin To Kelly. What do they all have in common? They're all widely considered to be among the worst big studio movies ever made. You know what else they have in common? They're all better than Jack and Jill.
An indispensable portrait of decay, of the way a life can be taken over by too much reliance on an emotional crutch.
It's official: Cop Out is no longer the worst movie in Kevin Smith's filmography. Red State is a disaster.
The acting? Eh. The plot? Eh. The sharks eating people in 3D? Oh, yeah!
A generic time killer that doesn't leave any kind of lasting impression.
Perfectly fun action, effects, and 3D use marred by some lazy storytelling.
Even though the picture is far from perfect, I was never less than amused. The terrific cast and some individual bits of comedy were enough to keep me invested.
I didn't believe a second of it, but I certainly had fun watching it.
If you have any sort of interest in stand-up comedy, this is as fine a documentary as you will see on the subject.
In the hierarchy of comic book movies, it's hovering somewhere near the bottom.
There is plenty to admire and enjoy about Jig. The filmmakers were given unprecedented access to the Irish Dancing World Championships, and what they found is captivating.
While not likely to become the ultimate in "I hate my job" fury a la Office Space, it offers enough bitter laughs to be fun.
Enormously fun. A film about 8mm that deserves to be seen on the big screen, in glorious 35mm.
Doesn't have a unified plot, but tells a handful of mini-stories very well.
Both frightening and inspiring.
By combining a healthy respect for the property with a playful sense of fun, it ends up being one of the most intelligent, effective superhero pictures yet.
It's very close in quality to the first one. And the first one was pretty darn awesome.
Adheres to the old maxim "if it ain't broke, don't fix it," yet somehow manages to break it while not fixing it.
Unsettling and quite unlike any other horror flick you're likely to have seen.
Mildly diverting if you're curious, but don't expect to be blown away.
A Good Day to Die Hard is the Superman IV: The Quest for Peace of the Die Hard series. It is Jaws: The Revenge, The Next Karate Kid, and that movie where Jason Voorhees kills people in a spaceship.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Phase 7 is slick, smart horror.
Midnight in Paris finds exactly the right groove for its story and stays there. It's a winner.
The emphasis is not so much on laughs, but on exploring familial relationships. It achieves some degree of success on both those counts, but the degree wasn't quite high enough for my taste.
I'm right down the middle on this one. It's not great, but it's not terrible either.
It has a terrific cast of actors doing committed work; it also has a screenplay that tries so hard to be quirky that it tires itself out.
It's got laughs and chills in exactly the right measure, just as good, old-fashioned B-movie entertainment should.

While Something Borrowed obviously wants to explore themes of competitiveness and betrayal in female friendships, it seems to feel compelled to hit pre-programmed chick flick beats at regular intervals.
Despite a few stray moments that ring false, this is an intellectually engaging, emotionally satisfying drama.
One wonders why time and effort was put into this sorry wannabe, considering that maintaining the tone of the source material clearly wasn't of much interest to anyone.
No one is ever going to mistake this slight little comedy for greatness, but it possesses a go-for-broke attitude that's darkly fun.
Cold Fish is artful and unnerving and, at times, repulsive. Its merit lies in an unrepentant willingness to be all of those things.
If you've been underwhelmed by many of summer 2011's big event movies, treat yourself to one that actually exceeds all expectations.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: If you can ride over a short rough section, you ultimately get an enjoyable collision between two disparate cinematic worlds.
I'd like to see Timberlake and Kunis together in a smarter romantic comedy someday. They deserve better than this creaky script.
Slightly flawed, but ultimately worth seeing for its unique feel, period detail, and compelling central character.
Merely translating the events of the novel would have been easy, but Deathly Hallows Part 2 - like all its predecessors - invests the story with a cinematic life all its own.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Atrocious is a primer on how NOT to make a found footage horror movie. The title is depressingly accurate.
The film is rather unfocused, so eager is it to touch on every facet of the problem, but there's no denying that it raises some provocative issues
movie_title: The 904: Shadow On The Sunshine State (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The Bay works as both horror and environmental activism. This is a fright flick with a purpose.
Jack the Giant Slayer delivers some primo giant-y goodness. I can now say I've seen a giant pick a booger out of his nose and eat it in 3D. So I've got that going for me.
Gross, funny, and full of superb makeup effects, this is a ghoulish treat for fans of the severely demented.
Lots of fun. DC has upped the ante on this series with War.
This is a flawed film, but it's also one that's not completely without merit.

Any entertainment value comes from peripheral things, like wondering what excuse they'll find to get Shannon Elizabeth into a tight, low-cut dress, or why every single light source in this film, no matter how small, emits a blinding lens flare.
When so many of the great works of art are at stake, we should be biting our nails, not looking at our watches.

An early frontrunner for Craziest Movie of 2014. This is an unapologetic exploitation flick, executed with tongue-in-cheek style. It's got blood, boobs, and butts galore, plus a lot of outrageously gimmicky uses of the third dimension.
Hilarious and poignant. The LEGO Movie isn't here to sell you plastic building blocks, it's here to make you remember why playing with them is an essential and magical part of life.
One of the most original, entertaining, and creepy zombie movies of recent years.
Plenty smart and entertaining, and in an era where cinematic romances tend to wade in the shallow end of the pool, that's a notable accomplishment.
Every bit as funny, thrilling, and darkly captivating as it was twenty-four years ago.
For whatever the flaws - and believe me, there are a few - Odd Thomas is just such a goofball charmer that I happily succumbed to its pleasures.
If this sounds like the recipe for a slick-but-vapid action picture, oui, it is.
Chlorine is lacking in just about everything: wit, dramatic momentum, cohesion, etc. A wildly underdeveloped film.
Hairbrained has a lot of good stuff. There is nothing egregiously wrong with the film. It just needs more of that good stuff.
Shows promise.
A satisfying, inspirational experience.
Only in a Lars von Trier film would you find yourself asking the question, What was more daring: the aspect ratio change or the penis montage?
A few things could have been improved upon, but it's at least ambitious and has an interesting twist.
It's a kick watching the familiar wrestlers make cameos, but 84 minutes is a little long for this kind of thing.
Moves like a bullet and jolts the hell out of you on a regular basis. This is the kind of film that, when it's over, makes you want to sit down and calm your nerves for a while.
Walking with Dinosaurs 3D has gorgeous, meticulously detailed CGI, but also way too many stupid jokes about poop and puke.
Stirring, spiritual, and thoughtful, with superb special effects and a genuine curiosity for the wonderful mysteries of faith.

What made these soldiers participate in such deplorable activities? Boys of Abu Ghraib attempts to answer that question. The explanations it comes up with may not be definitive, but they certainly make for a powerful, hard-hitting drama.
Notable for its effective performances and for the sincerity with which it tries to capture the confusion of young adulthood, but it often chooses simplicity over depth.
Slumber Party Massacre is not a great film - the plot is thin and the performances occasionally a little awkward - but there's no doubt that it maintains its shock value.
The uninitiated will need to read Veronica Roth's book to understand what's so great about Divergent, because the movie is aggressively mediocre.
A sweet, gentle, and humorous movie with winning performances across the board. It leaves you with a warm feeling inside.
It does right enough by the characters to please older fans, while also having enough appeal to capture the interest of children previously unacquainted with them.

Need For Speed gets nothing even remotely right. Not the characterization, not the story, not the dialogue, not the action, not even the sense of mindless fun a videogame offers. It is a massive pile of dreck.
An empty shell of a movie that goes nowhere, invokes no warm feelings, and accomplishes nothing.
Seems perfectly content to be a retread of the original, visually and stylistically. The film sticks so closely to the playbook that it never finds a way to become fun on its own terms.

While it most certainly has some very good qualities, it is ultimately undone - at least for general audiences - by a completely unsubtle desire to do more than simply tell a meaningful story; it wants to rock the world.

Often has something akin to the tone of a 1970s-era paranoid conspiracy thriller. Marrying the slam-bang adventure of a comic book with something more cerebral was a brilliant idea, one that is very entertainingly executed.

Few things are as exciting as watching a filmmaker move outside of a well-established comfort zone, and Labor Day serves as proof that Jason Reitman is an ambitious director, as well as a true talent.
I, Frankenstein is like the worst piece of Mary Shelley fan fiction written by the guy behind the counter at your local Hot Topic.
The Christmas Candle is both a nice holiday tale and a touching mediation on the value of using one's faith to create everyday miracles.
Catching Fire is so much fun and does such a great job mounting the drama of the series' increasingly engrossing story. The film just makes you want more.
Getaway should be required viewing for any filmmaker considering making a car chase movie. It offers a virtual step-by-step tutorial on what not to do.
A sensitive and beautiful film - one that contains genuine insight into the power of human connection, be it romantic, sexual, or some combination of both.
The best animated film of 2013. It's got a timeless magic that may well help it evolve into a classic.
While not bound for classic status, the film still manages to capture a moment in time that changed our country.
Sweet, charming, and life-affirming. Excellent performances from Kate del Castillo and Luis Antonio Ramos.
Works as an accounting of a good band making an album during a bad time, but it works even better as an indictment of a business practice that screws the people who actually make the product.
For whatever flaws it contains - and there are many - the film now seems like an intriguingly eccentric little genre effort that marches to the beat of its own weird drummer.
S#x Acts is admirable for its intentions; the execution, on the other hand, comes up short.
Excruciatingly dull. There are so many movies just like Out of the Furnace, and a lot of them are so much better.
I'd say that Inside Llewyn Davis is one of the Coen brothers' best films, but most of their films are one of their best films.

Whether or not Saving Mr. Banks hews closely to the facts (which it only does to a point), it certainly provides a satisfying story arc that reinforces the idea that personal works of art resonate most highly with audiences.
Anchorman 2 is not just a sequel. It is an astute satire and an amazing piece of next-level comedy. When it was over, my mouth was sore from laughing so hard.

Needless padding is the enemy of competent storytelling. The Desolation of Smaug is frustrating because you sense how much Jackson is in love with Tolkien's material, and how much that love has caused him to lose sight of what this tale should really be.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Beautifully, inventively constructed, and filled with rich performances that are perfectly calibrated to the offbeat tone [director David O.] Russell was going for.
Funny and touching in equal measure. The warmth of Nebraska makes you feel all good inside.
While by no means top-tier horror, it's nonetheless original and amusing.
It's debatable whether the three acts of Die, Monster, Die! fit together well, but there's no doubt they collectively add up to one deliriously goofy B-movie.
Some serious plot issues aside, Ride Along borderline works because of Kevin Hart. He's hilarious here.
G.B.F. imparts a message many people will do well to hear. That it does so in such entertaining fashion makes it worth seeking out.

Snitch is not your typical Dwayne Johnson action movie. For starters, there's hardly any action in it. It also has more going on inside its head than you would expect. The movie turns out to be a very pleasant surprise.
a monumental work of compassion

If the story contains many of the well-worn conventions of the genre - and it does - it at least assembles them with a modicum of wit, along with some terrific performances that sell the material. The movie turns out to be breezy and fun.
A legitimately grown-up movie about love and relationships, as well as one of the most insightful ever made on those subjects.
Walter Mitty has a big heart, and I like it for that. But this is definitely a case where a little simpler would have been a lot better overall.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A twisted, sexy horror classic.
Offers too many repetitive sections in which Anwar and company seem to be waxing nostalgic rather than exploring the implications of what they did.
Crawlspace is kind of a mess, albeit a thoroughly fascinating one.
Wickedly funny, smart as a whip, and immensely perceptive, The Wolf of Wall Street shows that being addicted to money is every bit as damaging as addiction to substances, sex, or anything else.
Well-executed and humane. A suitably suspenseful tribute to the soldiers who put themselves in grave danger to keep our shores safe.

The Adventurer: The Curse of the Midas Box could somewhat aptly be described as National Treasure in Victorian England. That is to say, it has that distinct feeling of being a tenth-generation ripoff of Raiders of the Lost Ark.
movie_title: The Adventurer: The Curse of the Midas Box (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Dallas Buyers Club hits every note just right. The film engages both your intellect and emotions. Beautiful and inspiring!
A movie of quiet, but undeniable, power, with a naturalistic feel that truly pulls you in.
A weak satire that has no interest in skewering anyone or anything.
365 Days steadfastly avoids addressing the underlying issue, to the degree that it makes you wonder if the filmmakers even know what the real problem is.
movie_title: 365 Days: A Year In Happy Valley (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It's odd that a movie intending to celebrate the great screen detectives would be devoid of a real mystery

Not only is this sequel every bit as funny as the original, it is even more inventive. Success apparently allowed everyone to feel comfortable going for bolder, crazier ideas this time around, and that approach pays off.
It's got some good horror elements and strong performances, but it needed more development of the characters to reach its fullest potential for scares.

The wisdom of Clint Eastwood doing the film version of a Broadway musical seems questionable at best, but it works because, when it comes right down to it, he's a skilled storyteller and Jersey Boys has one heck of a good story to tell.

Exquisitely awful. I was reminded of M. Night Shyamalan's Lady in the Water, in that both are attempts at building a magical fantasy world by someone who has no clue whatsoever how to go about the task.
May be enough for horror buffs looking for a quick, disposable fix of Fangoria-style mayhem, but lacks the substance to match its unrepentantly bloody style.
There are some fun action moments scattered throughout, although they're largely negated by a screenplay that somehow manages to be overstuffed yet still thin.
You'll laugh yourself silly
Mutual Friends is often funny and true, and in the realm of movies about urbanites sorting out their love lives, that makes it a little treasure.
Whether you care about film criticism a little, a lot, or not at all, this is a movie with a profoundly inspiring message.
If you can see beyond the usual genre trappings to what's just behind them, you'll find something kind of special.
The Final Terror isn't the slasher classic that Halloween and Friday the 13th are.
While it doesn't make great use of its Opie-meets-Hova potential, the line-up is impressively diverse enough to satisfy music fans.
The most insightful, engaging political movie to come around in a long time.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Snowpiercer hits the sweet spot of working as entertainment while still having enough brains to keep you intellectually engaged. It's a movie for people who love movies that play by their own rules.
Deadly Eyes has a lot of underdeveloped characters and stilted dialogue that drags it down whenever the rats aren't on-screen. The performances are also, shall we say, a bit stiff.

The movie delivers some entertainment on the action level, and the actors are generally well cast. Ironically, the biggest flaw in Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles is the portrayal of the Turtles themselves.
A thoroughly absorbing examination of a bizarre - and possibly delusional - personality.
A film with something of value to say about the nature and importance of friendships. It's funny and honest.
An uncommonly intelligent fright film, one that unnerves you at a very deep, primal level.
The movie has an original premise, some awesomely gory effects, and just the right amount of tongue-in-cheek humor. Those things make it one of the most interesting early-'80s creature features.
movie_title: Without Warning (It Came Without Warning) (Alien Encounters) (1980)

movie_review_blurb: Containing some genuinely gutsy, unexpected twists, At the Devil's Door cheerfully plays with your expectations, pulling the rug out from under you whenever it damn well pleases.

Writer/director Andrew Levitas is clearly tackling very personal, heartfelt sentiments here, yet he chooses some of independent cinema's creakiest cliches to do so. That causes the bottom to fall out.

Guardians of the Galaxy is a total treat - funny, exciting, filled with great effects, and containing a few welcome moments of emotion. This is the Marvel movie I can see myself watching again and again.
Lucy is not just tongue-in-cheek. No, the tongue bursts out of the cheek, wraps all the way around the back of the head, and comes in through the opposite cheek.
Most definitely an improvement on the original. A nice, pleasant, surprisingly enjoyable movie for young kids - one that you won't mind watching with them or feel guilty about exposing them to.
This is the kind of film that lifts your spirits. If you've had a bad day or are generally feeling down, it will cheer you up. If you're already feeling happy, it will make you even happier.
The laughs are intermittent, not consistent, and the central idea is trivialized, not investigated for its full comedy potential.

There's a compelling idea at work here, as well as an admirable willingness to explore the darkest reaches of that idea. Those things are, however, continually undone by a misguided script and weak direction.

Video Games: The Movie is breezy and entertaining, but it's also obvious and simplistic. This is Video Games 101, when the people most likely to be interested in seeing it will want to learn something much more.
4 Minute Mile is watchable thanks to Richard Jenkins, but its overall blandness and familiarity will cause it to evaporate from your memory in a flash.
Grudge Match certainly has enough successful elements to be moderately entertaining, although it's hard not to wish it contained fewer distractions.
As clear-eyed a portrait of modern warfare as you're likely to see.
Anna has more than a passing similarity to Inception in overall concept and a few specific plot points. In fact, the temptation is there to call it Diet Inception.
Draft Day is a very enjoyable and engaging examination of a man working in a pressure cooker. It's a lot of fun, even if you don't give a hoot about football.

Some good performances and amusing insights are undone by a mockumentary format that doesn't fully support them. The stuff that works will ring a few bells for writers, though, and that may make it worth a conditional look.
The idea of a documentary about a penis museum is sufficient to entice a viewing out of sheer curiosity. You'll stay for the deeply humane portrait of men desperate to leave a lasting imprint.
Transcendence continually reaches for big ideas. It has a go-for-broke ambition that may mark it as ahead of its time.
The Other Woman is as insightful about infidelity as Kim Kardashian would be about nuclear physics. What a detestable piece of crud this picture is.
Torture Chamber is a wholly original, deeply disturbing movie with an incessantly spooky atmosphere.
Take off the beginning and end credit sequences and the movie is only about 65 minutes long. Obviously, this leaves precious little time for things like plot and character development.
Quite possibly the dullest slasher movie ever made.
The cinematic equivalent of an 11-year-old boy trying to make his buddies laugh by repeating the word "penis" again and again.
A visual experience through and through, one that offers eye-popping delights at every turn.
This is a film that leaves you with a deep appreciation for the fighters of the world, as well as the individuals who tirelessly work to eradicate a disease we'd all like to see vanish forever.
This is the 'Batman & Robin' of the entire Spidey series.
Son of Batman has an engrossing take on the Dark Knight. Oftentimes, adding a kid to the mix is a sign of desperation, but in this case it allows for some further examination of the character.
Intellectually and emotionally engaging. This is one of the best films you'll see this year, documentary or otherwise.

A film like this always raises the question of whether newcomers can enjoy it, as they are unarmed with an understanding of the characters' histories and all the references that are surely contained within the screenplay. In this case, the answer is yes.
A worthy, if more general, recounting of the West Memphis Three case. Excellent performances from Colin Firth and Reese Witherspoon.
Funny in its satire, inventive in its horror, and devilishly satisfying in its theme. There ain't nothing like it, as they say, and that makes it a very special bit of horror cinema.
Ravenous is unlike anything else, and even if it's not to my own specific taste, I have great respect for its unrepentant weirdness.
As cool as the fight sequences are, they'd be even better with more substance around them.
If you can get Angelina Jolie to play one of the most beloved villains in Disney history, why would you make this movie, which is so joyless and which lacks any real sense of playfulness or fun?
Quite clever, and the fact that you never really know what the film is going to toss your way is part of the fun. A solidly goofy romp.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The movie won't be everyone's cup of tea, but for those with a strong interest in cinematic scares, it is most definitely a gutsy picture that deserves to be seen and discussed.
A fascinatingly deranged horror flick, but also one that's really slow in its first hour.
Edge of Tomorrow is the best kind of sci-fi: smart, engaging, witty, exciting, and an entertaining joyride from start to finish.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Hits that sweet spot of being really exciting and just substantive enough to earn our engagement. In the comic book-movie realm, it sits comfortably in the upper echelon.
So bad that it's borderline fascinating.
Incredibly entertaining! The film does a very wise thing in staying true to the spirit of the original. It fundamentally feels like a Godzilla movie should.
An incoherent film that's kind of a chore to sit through.
Blue Ruin redefines the revenge picture. It continually creates moments of hold-your-breath suspense.
The big jokes are hilarious, and there are a lot of them. But the movie's throwaway bits are just as hysterical, sometimes even more so.
A beautiful, touching, truthful idea that deserves so much better than this generally obnoxious, unfunny movie.
Kids for Cash does what any great advocacy doc does: give you the cold hard facts to get you angry and make you want to pay attention so that something like this never happens again.
12 Years a Slave isn't always easy to sit through, but it is most definitely a vital and profound motion picture.
It won't bore you, but it's not likely to rock your world either.
As a fright flick, The Horror Show fails miserably. As a piece of camp, however, it's fantastic - a total trip from start to finish.
From Beyond is just as unnerving now as it was in 1986. A boldly ambitious work of cinematic terror.
Beautifully animated and utterly charming.
movie_title: LEGO Batman: The Movie - DC Super Heroes Unite (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The Hangover has now officially replaced The Matrix as the cinematic trilogy with the biggest awesome-to-sucky decline.
I enjoy a crazy car chase as much as the next person, but I prefer them to come wrapped in a context that makes me care about who's chasing whom, and why.
Only partway into the film do you find out what it's really about, and by that point, you're already hooked.
I don't think there's a better werewolf movie than this.
There's not much to distinguish it, except, of course, for the bugs. Oh, how marvelously effective the bug scenes are!
After Earth is the cinematic equivalent of Rebecca Black's "Friday" - a parent-funded vanity project gone horribly wrong and thrust out into the world for the rest of us to not enjoy.
Makes for a solid Family Movie Night feature.
In addition to being funny, the movie has a surprising sense of warmth and an abundance of charm.
I didn't care all that much about the implausibility or plot holes because the movie is start-to-finish fun.
The movie repeatedly chickens out when it should be, well, purging.
This is the End is like The Walking Dead meets The Real World, cast with an entire generation of hot comic actors. An example of meta filmmaking at its finest.
I don't know whether you could accurately call Phantasm II "good" or not, but as a gore-filled piece of '80s horror with a premise unlike any other in the genre, it's completely enjoyable.
Man of Steel is the Superman movie I've been hoping someone would eventually make. This is awesome popcorn entertainment that doesn't neglect substance.
How often do you find a sci-fi/horror hybrid that dares to walk the high wire? Not often enough, I think. For that reason alone, Lifeforce deserves to be rediscovered.
Before Midnight is about the nature of long-term relationships, and the way love deepens and grows but also finds itself subject to the complications of maturity. Smart, insightful, and poignant.
Doesn't belong in the top ranks of animated fare but, like its predecessor, it contains enough humor, charm, and warmth to make it a solid family film.
excruciating for anyone over the age of five.
movie_title: The Oogieloves in The Big Balloon Adventure (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Cohen & Tate is, at times, shockingly violent and, at other times, darkly funny. A solid, entertaining little thriller.
When I remember the summer of 2013, this is the movie I'll think of. A first-rate sci-fi adventure that made me feel all giddy inside.
Even if it isn't the most in-depth telling of Robinson's extraordinary journey, it is nonetheless a marvelously entertaining tribute to a very important man.
It is an expertly crafted thriller with a mastery of tension-building techniques.
A timeless comedy. Hysterical.
Urgent without being alarmist, important without being dry. See this film before you click "I agree" again.
Overblown, stupid, loud, unfunny, and completely maddening in its undisguised assumption that you'll swallow this nonsense whole.
What could have been an easy cash-in is instead a film that delivers the goods for kids and adults alike. It's a charmer.
Best Friends Forever isn't as deep as it thinks it is.

Olympus Has Fallen at least knew what kind of movie it wanted to be, and it stuck with that approach. White House Down wants to be *every* kind of movie. That prevents it from being fully satisfying on any level.
Some Girl(s) is engaging because of the fierce, uncompromising nature of the dialogue, as well as the first-rate performances.
World War Z is less intense than any given episode of The Walking Dead, but there are undeniably suspenseful moments nonetheless. It's atmospheric and brainy.
Bullock and McCarthy are so comedically in sync that iffy jokes become funny, and funny jokes become hilarious.

A skillful, well-crafted movie that nicely melds the horror material with strong characterization and a deeper-than-expected story. The Conjuring represents the horror genre at its best and most substantive.
I found myself growing incredibly bored by the film. Nothing was new or fresh enough to earn my interest.
If you believe in the artistry of horror - and its ability to be bold, provocative, and daring - then this is a movie that demands your immediate attention.
Often raucously funny and occasionally touching, with real insight into the behavior patterns of adolescents.
It may needlessly complicate exquisitely crafted source material, yet it's visually stunning, has enthusiastic performances, and is often quite funny.
If Siegfried dumped Roy and then launched a vendetta against Criss Angel, you'd have The Incredible Burt Wonderstone. It's a funny movie that is also more thoughtful than it initially appears.
The movie makes you feel as though you've just woken up from an all-time bender: disoriented, confused, and wondering why you just put yourself through it.
Two-thirds terrific and one-third routine.
Spring Breakers is a scathing indictment of a generation led to believe that being a bad-ass and having a screw-it attitude is admirable. It's an all-around stunner.
A movie that drudges up the painful feelings associated with 9/11 just to make its routine, by-the-numbers action seem more relevant than it really is? Thanks, but no thanks.
In spite of a few significant flaws, Detour builds to a conclusion that sends you out the door shaken and thankful to see light.
For film buffs who love to debate cinematic subtext, the documentary is both exciting and riveting. It's also just plain fun.
This is the second awful G.I. Joe movie. It is even worse than the first one. Perhaps there is not a good film to be made from this material.
There's a compelling idea in here somewhere, one that sadly gets bogged down in Stephenie Meyer's ongoing desire to focus intently on all the least interesting things in her own stories.
Only time can tell which movies become classics. No matter how many Ds you see it in, it's safe to say that this one has earned the label.
An uncompromising, hardcore, balls-to-the-wall fright flick.
Kinderblock 66 offers a piece of history I didn't know about, but which I'm so glad to understand now. Compelling and emotional.
A reminder that cinema can still challenge you, rather than just placate you.
Scary Movie 5 is so bad, it makes A Haunted House look like a Seltzer/Friedberg comedy.
Oblivion would have been better titled Thelma & Louise because, like the characters in that 1991 drama, it drives itself over a cliff.
Beautifully acted, intellectually engaging, and dramatically satisfying, Mud deserves to rocket to the top of your must-see list.
33 Postcards is merely the latest in a long line of films to throw in needless crime subplots as a way of shortcutting things emotionally.
Feels cinematic, despite the fact that it wasn't made for the big screen.
Craig Robinson deserves better. So do Kerry Washington, David Alan Grier, and everyone else who stands before the camera in this clunker.
Given all the scandal, mystery, romance, and tragedy that the tale contains, I couldn't shake the feeling that The Great Gatsby should have been hitting me a lot harder than it was.
Slaughter Nick for President tells a story so unlikely and so improbable that you will be delighted in hearing it, just as I was.
A simple, character-based story with some well-timed scenes of excitement is what made the first installment great. Star Trek Into Darkness is just good.
An enjoyable, frequently funny documentary. You'll never look at cardboard the same way again!
Iron Man 3 is a spectacularly fun ride. A superhero movie that is, indeed, super.
I found myself riveted by Running America. It has plenty of drama, but also a deeply inspirational quality.
It simply takes all the things you've seen in other wedding movies and recycles them, all while pretending you're dumb enough not to notice.
Watching Pain & Gain is like having a stand-up comedian scream his entire act right into your year. After a while, it just becomes obnoxious and oppressive.
The Numbers Station is watchable for the things it gets right, yet it is impossible not to think that a lot of pieces to this puzzle are missing.
It allows you to really observe its characters and to ponder the themes that fuel the plot. For that reason, it is a film that makes a deeply emotional impact.
And Now a Word From Our Sponsor may not be good to the last drop, but parts of it are finger lickin' good.
movie_title: And Now A Word From Our Sponsor (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Everything in the movie is corny, cheesy, bad, or some combination thereof. I'd call the performances wooden, but that would be an insult to wood.
A gonzo masterpiece. You will see such bizarre sights that you'll have no alternative other than to think WTF?
The pleasures are only sporadic. R.I.P.D. simply can't overcome its flaws or the fact that it too closely resembles the far superior Men in Black.

One of the strengths of Prisoners is that it forces you to confront the part of yourself that really would do literally anything for your child. It doesn't frighten you so much as it makes you frighten yourself.
Maximum suspense! Should be required viewing for any serious movie buff.
A remarkable, fascinating documentary.
A perceptive and often funny story with a refreshingly mature attitude about sex.
One of the best modern coming-of-age tales, told with depth and, more importantly, wisdom.
As admirable as it is thematically, The Dirties does bear the marks of a filmmaker who isn't fully formed yet.
The best biopics make the viewer understand why the subject is important to them, even if it's not. They find a universality in the topic that sucks you in. Rush never does that.
A milestone in cinema. Ask me in twenty-five years about the most magical moviegoing excursions I've had, and I'm pretty sure I'll cite the day I saw Gravity as one of them.
The Big Bus can be hit-or-miss in its humor. But the hits are fairly big and the misses are comparatively small.
House of Wax has gone down in the books as a classic, but now, finally, it can be appreciated in the form it was always meant to be seen in. There is no need to ever watch it in 2D again.
Don't be surprised if your child asks to watch Brave or Shrek again when it's over.
Perhaps the highest compliment I can pay the film is to say this: I really want to see American Idiot on stage now.
Captain Phillips delivers 134 of the most intense minutes of cinema you'll see this year.

Escape From Tomorrow is the kind of movie you watch with your mouth hanging open in disbelief of the ballsiness you're witnessing onscreen. A deliriously entertaining, you-gotta-see-it-at-all-costs motion picture experience.
Machete does, indeed, kill. This time around, he also sucks.
A funny, sweet story about a young woman coming to terms with her personal beliefs.
Anyone who thinks Carrie is just another horror remake will be in for a rude awakening. Or, should I say, a pleasant surprise?
Carpenter stages the action expertly, always getting maximum impact from the moments when Precinct 13 explodes into violence.
It recaptures that feeling of running home with a new four-color comic, opening the pages, and delighting in the out-of-this-world adventures detailed within.
An attempt to gain insight into the complex, complicated, and often contradictory ways each and every one of us behave.
Despite possessing some definite strengths, the film ultimately feels as though it's hewing to a well-honed formula.
Commie Camp, despite its narrative shortcomings, at least celebrates that kids like this exist, and that there's a place willing to nurture them.
Stranded doesn't tell a story so much as just present a series of sequential events.
Rather than finding a fresh approach to ethnic humor, it relies on tired old standbys that have lost their punch.

Sweet Summer Sun: Hyde Park Live doesn't try to explain the band or tell us anything we don't already know about them. It just allows us to admire one of the world's best rock-and-roll bands, rocking every bit as hard now as they did 44 years ago
movie_title: The Rolling Stones: Sweet Summer Sun - Hyde Park Live (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Smart, engaging, and fun. This is a case where a book has been turned into a film and, by and large, they actually managed to preserve most of what made it special.

The Counselor plays better when you realize it's Mr. Bean with Michael Fassbender instead of Rowan Atkinson. It's ahead of its time. In 25 years, there's a chance that it may be regarded as a modern classic.
a passionate, thoughtful, and inquisitive exploration of the meaning of life.
Occasionally predictable but still has a significant amount of suspense, a healthy dose of black humor, and a number of good performances.
Thank goodness comedy still has the power to make us confront the stuff decorum tells us to avoid.
A far, far better horror anthology than V/H/S. It's more imaginative, more entertaining, and more skillfully made.
Night of the Comet is that rare movie that's effective as both a science-fiction movie and a parody of a science-fiction movie.
Extremely silly, but good for a few laughs.
It has all the depth of a 105-minute Jay Leno routine on growing old.
An indisputable classic.
A terrific character study of a beloved superhero. The Wolverine proves that there's still a lot of good stuff left to mine in his troubled, heroic psyche.
It's like a Chinese version of The Wire.

Heavy Traffic may be a bit dated in terms of its distinct '70s tone, but that doesn't make it any less fascinating. If you're a fan of the animation genre, this certainly qualifies as essential viewing.
A stylish, tantalizing, and highly watchable film. Lindsay Lohan makes a scorching comeback.
2 Guns wants to keep you from guessing what will happen next, but it does this by confusing you rather than through clever plotting.
The best indie horror movie I've seen in years. Creepy and menacing.
Blood is just good enough to make me wish it was better. While occasionally effective, it is ultimately hindered by some incomplete storytelling.
We're the Millers is very raunchy in its humor, but very sweet in its nature. The cast is terrific, and enough of the jokes worked to satisfy me.
I have a soft spot for sci-fi movies that use the genre to investigate societal issues; this one does it extremely well. It's more provocative than political.
Visually impressive old-school fun, anchored by a charmingly confident performance from Louise Bourgoin.
movie_title: Les aventures extraordinaires d'Adèle Blanc-Sec (The Extraordinary Adventures of Adèle Blanc-Sec) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It is sincere, earnest, and well-intentioned. It's also just a little too slowly paced to maximize the impact of those qualities.
Rote and bland. A "safe" follow-up to a movie that rejected the very notion of safety.
A riveting, important film. It addresses crucial issues forcefully and unflinchingly.
A deeply compelling, often darkly comic, and undeniably brilliant film. Cate Blanchett sets the new standard for actors portraying wildly dysfunctional people.
They don't make 'em like this anymore, and that's a shame. It's one of the best grindhouse-type pictures of the '80s.
This is the best movie about addiction that I've ever seen.
Considering the story isn't that complicated, "I Come in Peace" really shouldn't be as muddled as it is.
Fascinatingly up-close-and-personal. It serves as a forceful reminder that we should never let the moviegoing experience die.
Perhaps the best compliment I can pay the film is to say that it made me want to go down in my basement and dig through all those old VHS tapes that I have boxed up.
While a 90-minute movie about a song might seem ripe for thinness, Sample This is never dull. Tightly paced and packed with unbelievable twists and turns, it's a truly fun experience.
An inoffensive but shallow cash-in on a temporary phenomenon.
90 minutes of incompetent filmmaking
An intimate study of human unhappiness and the addictive liberation that comes from casting it off. Kate Bosworth displays a level of depth heretofore unseen in her work.

Riddick delivers the bottom-line stuff viewers want from this series. Diesel is as charismatic as ever, the action is exciting and nasty, and the wicked humor helps create a vibe of tongue-in-cheek fun.
What a shame that director James Wan had to follow up a triumph like this summer's The Conjuring with a complete dud like Insidious: Chapter 2. A disjointed mess.
ultimately too earnest for its own good
A sloppy combination of borrowed ideas, phony literary aspirations, and uncomfortable misogyny.

Rather than feeling as though we're emotionally connected to [the lead character] during her descent, we're all too aware of the machinations of the screenplay, struggling to find ways to sink her and then bring her back up.
You're Next is simultaneously a home invasion horror movie and a commentary on home invasion horror movies. That it does both equally well is a real achievement.
A little self-serious, and occasionally unintentionally goofy.
It's really hard to go wrong with a Studio Ghibli film, and From Up on Poppy Hill is no exception. It may not be their very best work, but it's still good work, full of charm and fun.
I'd estimate that 75% of The World's End is enjoyable. The other 25% isn't bad, just repetitive.

It's clear I'm out of the demo for this one, which fetishizes interior design and home furnishings almost as much as the sex. But a substantive plot larded with more laughs would have made my thoughts much less conflicted.
Henry Jaglom has been making indie movies for decades. He's a devotee of unadorned camerawork and semi-improvised dialogue -- but some actors are better at improv than others.
Pirate Radio is a ribald, rocking romp. Dramamine not necessary.
Although talking shop and trading solos form the centerpiece of the film, Guggenheim does a fine job of weaving a narrative out of the three men's life stories.
It's an affecting, all too human drama that plays out against Ike Nobutaka's gorgeous art direction, where snow falls softly on the neon city, blanketing even decrepit dark corners in a sad beauty.

Director Tim Story's subtle nods to Spike Lee's Joe's Bed-Stuy Barbershop notwithstanding, this one has about as much novelty as a $15 fade. But if it's something of a shaggy dog, it doesn't need a trim...
Not another teen movie!
The Ladies Man is pointless and should never have been made. But check your brain at the door and it almost stacks up to a snifter of Courvoisier and a handful of butt.
This one used up all three of 'em in the first few minutes.
Ten years in the making, Zachary Levy's film is a stark and arresting study of a simple man trying to do good with what he's got.
Because it never develops its characters beyond types, it comes off as flat and forced throughout.
It delivers the goods in a fresh manner.
Transformers is the comic-book movie on steroids, a fusion of sound and fury and sci-fi plotting that leaves plenty of room for a franchise.
In the bigger is better world of Hollywood sequels, How to Train Your Dragon 2 comes up short. It lacks the novelty of the original and tries too hard to be "about" something more than fun.

A popcorn movie that delivers precisely what it promises. The dialogue is tepid and the outcome is preordained, but it moves at the brisk pace of a carnival ride, leaving you breathless and ready for another spin.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Once Lerman finds his footing, he carries the film with just the right amounts of nuance, charm and angst.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
In a year where animated entertainment has had an embarrassment of riches, The Wild Life is merely an embarrassment, and a pretty grand one at that.
A hell of a fun time at the movies.
Aardman continues its tradition of excellence in comedic animation with this charmingly well-woven caper.
The chemistry between the three leads is magnificent, and the film doesn't run so much as glide through its entirety; taking you, the audience, along for the ride.
A puzzling thriller with intensely fascinating characters, Dark Places is a film that will restore your faith in procedural mysteries.
An exemplary cast is wasted on this historical biopic that starts with promise, but devolves into boredom.
If The Bourne Identity and Resident Evil hooked up back in 2002, this is the baby that one of them would bring to the doorstep of the other, begging them to take it.
No Escape employs shoddy storytelling and lame white-guilt politics to tell a story that's better suited for a Lifetime collaboration with Michael Bay.
Not a perfect sequel, [but] good enough film to keep the franchise in play - thanks in part to some charismatic performances.
Everest has compelling performances and harrowing action - despite being a little under-developed in the first act.
Crimson Peak will make you believe in ghosts, but it will also make you believe in the magic of the movies yet again.
It should only be viewed if you want more of the same material you can watch daily on the majority of TNT's line-up.
While there isn't as much action as the commercials let on, In The Heart Of The Sea trades shallow thrills for an in-depth look into survival at all costs.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: 86 minutes doesn't feel long when you're watching a movie worth your time, but when that film happens to be Alvin And The Chipmunks: The Road Chip, it's an eternity of pain.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Road Chip (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Ratchet And Clank lives up to its name, as those are the sounds your mind will make when trying to wrap your head around how this movie got made in the first place.
Collision Course proves once and for all that this dying franchise is but a fossil in the more evolved world of animated cinema.
One of the best films of this year, no questions asked.
A film wrought with tension, Imperium explores the themes of domestic terror and racism with thoughtful examination, and powerhouse performances.
A shambling mess of a film that tries to be a found-footage horror film, but ends up being one of the most unintentional comedies of the year.
With thrilling action, stunning visuals, and some really well timed comedy; it's the best Adam Sandler film we've gotten in a while.
The Gallows should be the next production whose name is synonymous with bad luck at the theater.
With its feet firmly planted in a new timeline, Genisys does what the last two Terminator films couldn't: entertain.
Perhaps the greatest crime Let's Be Cops could ever commit is the fact that it exists.
Trips over itself while trying to sell its product very hard as a faith-based blockbuster.
Manages to end the film with an emotional finale that closes out the series in a bittersweet manner.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Minor griping aside, The Hobbit: The Battle Of Five Armies is a success that brings the Tolkien Estate's film dealings with Peter Jackson to a triumphant close.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Suffers from a limp story, but banks on good actors trying to make the best of the hand they've been dealt.
One of those amazing films that perfectly blends heart and humor, with a gigantic quantity of whimsy.
What looked funny in small, trailer-sized doses turns into an interminable death march when applied to an almost two-hour run time.
Nothing new or exciting for Spongebob fans. It's even more painful if you're not a fan.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Managed to win me over with a combination of British charm, clever writing, and well-executed performances.
A clever comedy that isn't a chore to sit through if you're outside of the target demographic. Oh, and your kids are gonna love it.
Sprints across the screen, and save for one glaring misstep, entertains from start to finish.
Lands in the bin of "try and fail" efforts of great directors with films like Popeye and Town And Country to keep it company.
A well-told love story that starts a little formulaic but quickly turns into something that's enjoyable to watch unfold.
Methodically paced, and anchored by two damned solid performances from Jonah Hill and James Franco.
Manages to score some select moments of goodwill, but ultimately hampers itself with a severely underdeveloped story.
Poltergeist doesn't aspire to anything greater than being a decent first draft of what had the potential to be an impressive remake.
With a script that wears its wistfully reflective heart on its sleeve... Dope is one of those gems buried in the summer box office.
Not only does it effectively manage to walk the line between the two, it also manages to re-introduce the world to the talent and promise of Ryan Reynolds.
Storks is a beautifully hilarious film that glides through comedy, action, and heartfelt emotion to deliver an immensely satisfying package.
Miss Sloane delivers solid drama and legitimate thrills, all thanks to the murderer's row of talent that make up their cast.
As a barely extended stand-up special that seems better fit as an HBO or Pay-Per-View event, Kevin Hart: What Now? isn't worth the prices most theaters charge for admission.
Do yourself a favor, and swipe left on this one.
It's a visual spectacle of action and fantasy that leaves the audience wanting more.
This is quite possibly one of the most boring movies that I've ever had to sit through, especially in the realm of animation.
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Wind River is a powerful examination of the human soul, while also containing scenes that'll take your breath away, as it shocks and awes the audience in waves.
While Patti Cake$ treads familiar ground, it does so with a confident stride and cinematic language of its own, much like its colorful protagonist.
A film that doesn't even earn the punctuation it forces upon its audience.
Kingsman: The Golden Circle is the big-ticket blockbuster we could have used a couple months ago, as it's easily one of the most enjoyable sequels / action pictures of the year.
If this is any indication of what a continued partnership would bring, Netflix and Stephen King should look for as many chances as they can to stay together.
My Little Pony: The Movie is definitely a hit, as it mixes nostalgic storytelling with modern entertainment, to create a truly magical comedy adventure.
There's some memorable one-liners, well drawn characters, and an ending that'll have folks debating what truly happened after the screen has gone dark.
Lady Bird is an enjoyable film, with a honest heart about it.
Molly's Game isn't perfect, but as it's Aaron Sorkin's first film as a director, it's a true testament to how much he's paid attention to the directors that have handled his work.
An emotional masterpiece that digs deep while keeping you smiling, and a pure example of why sequels can still be a good thing.
If you can get a reduced fare ticket to see The Commuter, it's a fun ride.
With a running time that clocks in under two hours, The Cloverfield Paradox uses its duration efficiently, mixing thrills and heart into a cocktail that makes for an effectively surprising film.
Sadly, The 15:17 to Paris is an all-time career low for Clint Eastwood.
It's an entertaining romp that can kill some time, and keep the kids excited with colorful panache.
There's a genuine sense of friendship, and comedy throughout, that make the film one of this summer's most surprising comedies.
Not only one of the smartest movies of the year, it's possibly the best film of the summer.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Fifty Shades Freed ends the franchise not with a whimper, nor a bang, but a Pinterest board of bad ideas involving storytelling, relationship advice, and general conduct.
If you can help it, don't stop here. This is Brat Country.
movie_title: Diary Of A Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A tremendous show of the human spirit, that uses technical magic to heighten its reality and put us in the middle of the action. The end result is nothing short of impressive.
Almost Christmas seems like a film that was taken out of the oven too early, leaving an underdone product on the table.
While there are some moments that actually entertain throughout the film, in the end it's not unique enough to exist, or even give a damn about.
There's some beautiful visuals and individual moments that can be seen be enjoyed, but if you're looking for a plot that makes sense, you may want to apply elsewhere.
Not a perfect film, by any means. But instead, it exists as an entertaining film that could mark the beginning of the next horror franchise to bring audiences into theaters on a regular basis.
The rare jukebox musical that finds a way to make sense of switching tracks at a rapid pace, without letting any story beats get lost in the shuffle.
If the Underworld franchise was ever any good, that era has long since past.
As a throwback to 90's children's fare, as well as a generally fun and kind-spirited time at the movies, it succeeds admirably.
Sadly, Nate Parker's The Birth of a Nation strikes a wildly uneven tone, in a beautiful, but confused, first film.
A Cure For Wellness is what happens when you mix the noir-ish shades of Shutter Island with the Hammer Horror overtones of Crimson Peak, and mix in a dash of Bioshock for good measure.
The film's disjointed plot and stock characters feel like a flat, lifeless knock off of better animated films that have come before it.
It's not that The Zookeeper's Wife is a bad film, so much as it's a wasted opportunity.
If cookies are for closers, The Boss Baby doesn't even get the set of Fisher Price steak knives.
Your Name stands as a testament to just how effective of a medium animation is when it comes to telling a story of deep emotion and lush symbolism.
Serving as a fantastic introduction to a familiar property, the film serves new and old fans alike, while also challenging that world to be something more expansive.
While this film achieves that goal to a certain effect, mostly through beautiful wildlife photography, it does hamper itself in certain areas, leading to rather uneven product.
A Dog's Purpose isn't a movie. It's a greeting card with fur and a borderline cloying narration.
Despite the mistakes that Rough Night partakes in, it manages to use its cast to great effect, maximizing the laughs that the film does manage to pull off.
As with all of Truffaut's great films, Baisers volés features an odd collection of minor characters and playful cinematic asides that present a complex view of the world.
