An obvious attempt to mix the high-drama of The Wrath of Khan with the mainstream appeal (read: box office) of Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home, and for the most part it succeeds.
Not since Lawrence of Arabia have we seen such an epic saga of adventure and heroism.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: On the surface, The Return of the King has everything anyone would ask for in a fantasy adventure: larger-than-life heroes, vile villains, cool monsters and battles galore.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The gore piles up into ridiculous overkill.
Recommended viewing for any kid who's ever dreamed of the big leagues.
I.T. has moments of real tension interspersed throughout, but its consistent theme -- that you can't trust technology because a bad guy might use it against you -- is a little bit silly.
Dragged down only slightly by a lack of resolution and less of the original's aura of hushed mystery, John Wick: Chapter 2 nonetheless delivers everything most fans could want.
Ultimately Get Out can't help but ask the question: How would all these white people feel if they could walk in a black person's shoes for a day? And that's something worth considering.
Getting worked up over this is like getting worked up over a Saturday-morning cartoon. Unlike its predecessors, this one doesn't even try to aspire to myth. It aspires only to merchandising.
Every vestige of the first Mummy movie's wit and charm is buried in an avalanche of noise and motion. It's exhausting.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: I can see how Mamma Mia! might be a fun stage musical. As a movie musical, it's a train wreck.
It's inoffensive and shiny and competent and kids will dig it, and I can already barely remember a single thing that happened.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating, beautifully acted study in philosophical tension.
You know how some movies feel like they were made by a committee? What Happens in Vegas feels like it was made by checklist.

I could just hear the producers in the board room, cigar smoke swirling around their fat heads as they barked into their speakerphones: "Those Hong Kong guys are too old! We need an American in here to capture the Western markets
The humor tends toward the mildly crass -- bare buttocks and inappropriate scratching are Schwimmer's go-to comedy staples -- and the story is ridiculous.
There is something, well, awesome about watching these vivid young women...get onstage after five days and ferociously sing earnest lyrics they wrote themselves.

Best of all, Waters and his team remember to make the movie about human beings; like E.T., this is a story about dealing with absent fathers that happens to be filled with adventure and outlandish critters.
Should I immediately watch DVDs of The Departed and The Shawshank Redemption to cleanse my palate?
Debaters is a real crowd-pleaser.
Doesn't produce belly laughs so much as steady smiles of recognition over how accurately it's nailing its target.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Surprisingly touching and humane, thanks to its restrained direction and strong performances and sweet-hearted script.
Imagine what it would take to make an audience prefer Dane Cook over Steve Carell, then double it.
...About as silly as a Curb Your Enthusiasm episode.
...it's hard to argue with the movie's general good spirits.
It looks like Billy Bob Thornton has gotten to this lucrative W.C. Fields place in his career where he fills his coffers by playing endless variations on the same character.
An ugly, stupid and meaningless thriller.
It's Over the Top via Nintendo, and it is stunning to behold.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A dry, vicious and deeply moving little comedy that sort of takes the structure of a teen sports movie, then undermines that structure at every turn.
Sporadically funny, but for the most part, Death is just thoroughly modest.

A really solid horror comedy: beautifully shot, decently acted, fast moving and creative with the disembowelments. And it manages the weird feat of making a flock of sheep bounding across a meadow seem vaguely menacing.
Overdramatizes Albert's 24-year career.
The actors barely comprehend their lines. The pop-culture references are lame. Nearly every moment falls flat. And it's boring.
The film is exquisite on every level, full of sadness and emotional surprise.
Raimi as a filmmaker is clearly having more fun than he's had in years. So will his fans.
Whatever Choke lacks in Fight Club-style slickness and epic-manifesto scope, it makes up for with filthy humor, likable performances and a surprisingly light touch.
The movie's lazy, formulaic story quickly becomes an excruciating waste of talent.
I'm pleased to report the new Land of the Lost movie keenly understands that what was once scary is now ridiculous.
A strangely relaxed and frequently funny installment. To my thinking, it stands right behind Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban as the best in the movie series.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Your 12-and-unders will dig it, and it might even serve as a sort of movie-Bookmobile and get them to read a little history, or at least a little Wikipedia. But otherwise it's utterly dispensable.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The movie's appealing as a rambling actor showcase: As with the better mid-range indies, you enjoy spending time with these people even if a few elements of the movie let you down.

Despite being foolish in most respects, Ghosts of Girlfriends Past keeps you on its wacky rom-com narrative train all the way to the end. But that's probably a testament to the power of Charles Dickens' storytelling more than anything else.
A grim, open-ended study in smooth surfaces, skin and 25-year-old pop-culture references.
I'm not sure how many lovable schlubs Rogen agreed to play in Judd Apatow comedies to get this dark little piece made, but I'm delighted he took the risk.
One gets the sinking feeling as Alien Trespass drags on that [director] Goodwin thought he could build a whole movie out of a few formal gags about bad editing.
This will personally go down as the flick that really made me realize how much I hate CGI stunts.
Fanboys kind of made me want to stop being one.
Lakeview Terrace grabs a fistful of hot-button story elements -- race, sex, politics -- and promptly mixes them into the thriller equivalent of tapioca.
Gilroy's technique can feel like complication for complication's sake, but stick with the story and the dramatic rewards are real, or at least the punch line's pretty clever.

Scratch the surface, and the movie's underpinnings are an insult to women everywhere -- the film is slick stupid propaganda for the myth of The One True Love that wastes the talents of fine actresses.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Taken is a stripped-down action flick offering a single bloodlusty pleasure: You get to spend 90 minutes watching a world-class leading man cut a totally justified swath of violence through an army of central-casting scumbags.
Inkheart takes a great idea and then refuses to do much with that idea -- including, I'm afraid, explaining it clearly to the audience.
The Spirit is a loony, embarrassing mess that takes the late Will Eisner's classic comics creation and beats it senseless with a giant toilet bowl (literally, at one point).
Vaughn and Witherspoon are clearly having a lot of fun snapping each other's synapses, and their sense of play gives the whole easygoing, formulaic enterprise a welcome jolt.
Let the Right One In could be described as a vampire horror romance, but that seems like too easy a label for this beautiful, unnerving little movie.
Levinson keeps the film locked into a sort of low-key middle-age depression.
Eastwood and [screenwriter] Straczynski also give the story roughly 50 endings, and the director can be too melodramatic or on-the-nose.

Like We Own the Night before it, Pride and Glory is the most depressing sort of not-that-great movie because it really wants to be an epic drama and a serious actor showcase, but it just can't close the deal.
Atheists should find it good for an easy laugh.
The coming-of-age molestation drama Towelhead is beautifully acted and accomplishes exactly what writer/director Alan Ball set out to accomplish.
The Rock charms you through the worst of it, but the effects are cheap, the dialogue is about as challenging as a Hannah Montana episode, and the pace manages to be both brisk and numbing.
The uneven filmmaking renders Minot's ideas impossibly trite. ...Ugh.
Good intentions and strong thespians aside, Seidelman's writing and filmmaking are bland, obvious and uninvolving.
What makes Surf's Up stand out is its look and texture.
Director Patrick Stettner chooses to film the latter bits of Gabriel's [Williams] mundane investigation as a full-blown psychological thriller, and it mostly works.
This comedy about four high-school girls getting revenge on a triple-timing jock strikes the poses of a teen sex comedy, but it contains no sex and hardly any comedy.

The house itself -- with a porch for a mouth, a carpet for a tongue and a chandelier for a uvula -- is terrifying in the family friendly way old Disney movies are terrifying, and the story packs a few genuine surprises too good to spoil here.
Even Clark's fans probably won't be surprised to hear the result is a low-key, pervy mess.
Serrill's disciplined, beautifully constructed film is so propulsive, so spiritually triumphant, it's absolutely one of the best sports docs ever.
Marsh has a knack for setting up twisted situations, and he nicely counterbalances the horror by filming everything in a straightforward, muted style.
A sort of wandering rom-com epic -- kicking romantic fallacies in the ribs while capturing something essential about the solipsism and dreams of young urbanites.

As in Mudede's column, the film's pleasures lie in the games it plays with language, in the way Seattle is rendered as a dreamscape both funny and frightening, in the way police work does battle with philosophy.

It's a lot of drama to pack into just more than 90 minutes, and Cuesta's low-key visual approach plays nicely against the film's roiling passions and over-the-top (some might say too over-the-top) final act.
More amusing than it is funny.
When the movie works, it really works.
Though "shock scares" usually feel kind of cheap, The Descent uses them as punctuation marks to enhance the larger sense of dread.
Transplanting so much of the original story to a 21st-century setting only amplifies how badly the story has aged.
The movie, as a whole, doesn't hang together.
A rough-edged but incredibly provocative fake documentary.
movie_title: CSA: The Confederate States of America (2005)

movie_review_blurb: By presenting murderers as actors and then filming those actors discussing their sins, the line between performance and soul-searching blurs in unnerving ways.
Mullan makes the journey more than worthwhile, but don't go in expecting profundity.

Whether it's a real case captured by an incurious filmmaker, a hoax perpetrated on an incurious filmmaker or an audacious bit of Blair Witch fakery, the movie gets you thinking about the nature of identity and the power of memory.
Other than its deliriously trashy intro and a loopy twist ending that questions reality itself, Basic Instinct 2 is way too restrained in every sense.
It isn't Lumet's best work, but it does play to Diesel's peacock strengths. In fact, he carries the movie.
In dramatic terms, constantly being told about Rochester's talent but never seeing it makes the movie feel as pointless as its subject's life.

Unfortunately, other than offering a couple of glib, single-scene explanations, director Tom Dey (Shanghai Noon) and writers Tom J. Astle and Matt Ember aren't interested in exploring what makes either of their leads tick.
This is a totally predictable exercise if you're not in the target market.
Too many great moments happen to list.
Odd, beautiful and ambitious.
If you're willing to do the work, Triad Election pays you in tragedy.
movie_title: Triad Election (Hak se wui yi wo wai kwai) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Accepted feels a little like a Montessori Real Genius. It's one of the few genuinely funny comedies in a dismal movie summer.

Trust the Man has some good laughs courtesy of its cast -- but they're basically papering over a script that's masquerading as urbane and trenchant, when it's really self-involved and didactic and more than a little foolish.

Despite dancing between a story and a story within a story, something seems simple and effortless about Ten Canoes. Director Rolf de Heer and his all-Yolngu cast offer a take on tribal life that's warm, funny and powerfully alive.
What pushes Mr. Brooks into 'silly' territory is the way co-writer/director Bruce A. Evans piles on way too many subplots that seem to set up future stories.
What a pleasant surprise that Shrek the Third mostly connects with a fairly tight story -- even if it feels less like a movie and more like a really good episode of a Shrek TV series.
It's weird to write that a movie chock-full of adultery, stalking, spousal abuse and hatred of the unborn is the feel-good comedy of the summer.
Savage little morality tale.
Fracture sneaks up on you. At first, it plays like it might be another in a long line of dullish legal thrillers. But then, in its modest, grown-up way, it keeps getting better and better.
If you enjoyed any of [writer-director Scott] Frank's previous work, or thought Brick was the bomb, you'll love this.
The Namesake doesn't reduce itself to simple ethnic politics and easy critiques.
O'Toole just keeps turning up the volume, and it's thrilling to watch.
Black Snake Moan is a gorgeous, life-affirming movie. On paper, it sounds lurid bordering on ridiculous.

A low-key personal portrait that helps you understand an illegal immigrant's desperate psychology. But mostly, it fills you with an aching empathy for this profoundly decent man, who numbly (even heroically) soldiers on.

It's fun-dumb and definitely not everyone's cup of tea -- I don't want to oversell it -- but Broken Lizard keeps it interesting by refusing to color inside the lines, creating their own silly little universe.

James Longley's Sundance-winning documentary puts the camera uncomfortably close to scenes of abuse, violence, terror, cynicism and racial hatred amid the rubble of U.S.-occupied Iraq. But at the same time, its texture is frequently beautiful.
The movie's biggest charm is its unpredictable, offbeat tone.
It's an ambitious, passionate, grief-stricken work of film art.
A compelling piece of journalism arguing O'Grady is one of hundreds of 'sexualized' priests shielded by an absolute bureaucracy that's been corrupted absolutely.
I haven't seen this much smug, awkward laughter and bathos since, well, Man of the Year.
I loved the little schematic diagrams that track Harold's too-linear existence. Zach Helm's script is very funny and occasionally shocking.
A soft-edged little movie. It also wants to be more idiosyncratic than it is. Which would be fine if the movie were moderately charming, funny or clever. It really isn't.
It furiously reveals the nonhuman suffering that's easy to overlook in a disaster this vast.
The story of Dito escaping and then facing his demons is meaningful. But that story is so buried in actorly noise that it feels false.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Keaton offers glimpses of a directorial gift, but this odd little piece feels like warm-up for something more compelling.
By gilding the lily so shamelessly, Ewing and Grady guarantee they'll preach only to the converted.
The teachers have moxie. The students have courage. Mermin's warm, funny, beautiful and deeply humane documentary certainly honors the latter.
It's hard to argue with the movie's knowledge-as-power message: To outwit the living artifacts, Stiller has to bone up on history.
I was stunned to learn that Beth Cooper was created by actual filmmaking veterans.
The errant subplots go nowhere. The movie has an episodic TV quality so pronounced, I kept expecting commercial breaks.
If you're willing to have your patience tested, Twohy and his cast reward it.
Wiseman may lack a bold singular vision, but he tries to make up for it with sheer density, effort and expense.
Vigalondo makes the most of a handful of locations while bouncing romantic farce off a (largely unseen) world-changing event.
Mediocre, slightly sloppy and a mild waste of a great cast.
It's weirdly refreshing that Kurtzman has used his clout to make a mid-list dramedy that feels aimed at the actual adults the cineplex rarely tries to court nowadays.
This movie asked me to accept a lot, and occasionally I did -- but even I drew the line at one of these "American Idol" wannabes writing "Don't Stop Believin'."
There's almost nothing to "Battleship" beyond its grindingly dull, digitally rendered naval warfare; the flick could easily be retitled "Flying Ordinance and Forgettable Stars: The Motion Picture."
Batmanglij and co-writer Marling do a calm job of muddying the relationship waters, playing with cult logic and patiently introducing side elements that cast a curious light on Maggie's claims.

It starts out as a fairly easy spoof of the pirate-movie tropes resurrected by Depp and Disney but quickly finds humor in Victorian science, awards shows, Jane Austen and Elephant Man cameos while mostly avoiding the easy pop-culture gag.
When the film tries to inject anything resembling high drama, it gets dumb in a hurry.

Scenes will wander from gross-out gag to sentimental schmaltz to pervy leer to cheap nostalgia within a 30-second span, utterly free of clear directorial guidance. Even worse, very little of it is remotely funny.

Waititi does a nice tonal juggling act, balancing eccentric characters, a 1980s setting, child-drawn animation and Maori-inflected restagings of Michael Jackson videos with the painful consequences of parental neglect.
The film's climax is a bit of a jumble, but by then Hillcoat has built his world so vibrantly that it hardly matters.

Stanton is gleefully committed to letting this universe run wild on a big screen. The film's best qualities are its gigantic, densely packed, slightly loopy world-building and its unironic senses of humor and fun.

To my thinking, this splendid low-key bummer of a ghost story was eventually undermined by the film's increasing reliance on shock-scares, in which something suddenly and noisily jumps into the frame, over and over and over.

"Zoo" leaves you wondering whether Crowe was spooked by the mixed reaction to "Vanilla Sky" and "Elizabethtown" and chose to play it safe, remixing echoes of his usual screenwriting devices, in pursuit of a surefire hit.
Law and Downey remain a lot of fun to watch together, and their chemistry covers a lot of silliness.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Arthur is sort of a dull hero, but the grandfather is classic, hilarious Aardman -- a thoroughly British eccentric prone to weird nostalgic/fatalistic utterances.

Niccol is practicing the old-school craft of making a barn-broad alternate-reality that forces you to think about the way we all consensually agree to participate in systems -- even when those systems are hopelessly screwed up.
Chandor writes monologues for seemingly every member of the ensemble, which gets a bit wearying, but is also how I'm guessing he attracted this stellar cast.
In their best moments, Hark's action movies have a what-did-I-just-see giddiness, as if their choreography were springing straight from a cartoon id.
movie_title: Detective Dee and the Mystery of the Phantom Flame (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Mostly it's dopey. The movie just begs too many logical questions for its own good.

It's a mild shame that "Dolphin Tale" director Charles Martin Smith and his screenwriters have chosen to lard the true-life saga up with a bunch of easily digested imaginary detail straight out of the bland Hollywood feel-good recipe mix.
Cornish makes a feature debut here that's almost as stunning as when his pal (and executive producer) Edgar Wright invaded the cineplex with "Shaun of the Dead."
"Fright Night" joins "Rise of the Planet of the Apes" as proof that you actually can do this sort of thing correctly.
It's been a while since I watched a movie that felt as nakedly reverse-engineered as "Safe House."
The movie isn't a frame longer than necessary, the car stunts are cool, and the scenes with Ansari and Eisenberg pop -- particularly during their laugh-out-loud amateur robbery.

The movie's perfectly understated, warts-and-all sense of time and place will send any suburban Gen Xer in the audience flashing right back to their less-cautious days, when mix tapes did heavy lifting as calling cards.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It's fascinating as an offbeat storytelling exercise.
It takes too long to get started, it pulls some key punches, its dialogue is deeply uninteresting, it relies way too heavily on endless jump-scares and its finale is pure slasher-flick formula.
"Winter's Tale" wants to be a magical romance that leaves you feeling like the universe is full of secret purpose, but instead it's convoluted, over-narrated and deeply silly.

Betbeder's tale of aging Parisian art-school grads falling in love is told as a near-relentless collage of fourth-wall-breaking monologues -- "High Fidelity"-style -- and peppered with chapter breaks, dream sequences, and clips from other movies.
"Age of Uprising" unsettles as it raises troubling questions about the price, morality and flexibility of a "principled stand."
movie_title: Age of Uprising: The Legend of Michael Kohlhaas (2014)

movie_review_blurb: In Elkatsha's editing bay, the frustrations of traffic become a potent metaphor for a nation's much-larger frustrations.
The island setting is lovely and the few forays into slapstick are fairly lame, but Wilson and Luchini's dramatic tanglings are fun to watch ...
The entire cast does the subtlest work we've seen in a Potter film, right down to the supporting and single-scene players.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Jennifer Lawrence remains the series' biggest coup. "Catching Fire" asks the actress to add PTSD and romantic stirrings to Katniss' psyche, then cover it with a barely affixed public mask. Lawrence steps up.
Overall the movie offers a funny, human take on a wounded person and the gaming subculture that consumes him.
A fascinating, skillfully directed, overpoweringly atmospheric mystery.
Here's a poster blurb: "Your child's attention will be briefly diverted."
It'll have a great opening weekend, but it still seems a shame to have diluted the action-flick purity of the first "Taken" with this cash grab.
There's a potentially innovative teen comedy in here somewhere, but it's surrounded by one that's much duller.
If you've grown old with these characters, "Before Midnight" is an exhilarating and breathtakingly nervy experience.
Whatever weird charisma lightning struck "Five" more or less strikes again here.
It's probably a superfeat that Shannon pulls a coherent performance out of the contradictions (and scene-to-scene changes in wardrobe and hairstyle) handed to him by the character and filmmakers.
It ends quite a bit doofier than it starts, but it's entertaining enough, and it is very, very pretty.
The movie unfolds in the uplifting manner you'd expect, but its real pleasures lie in its terrific '60s pop-soul soundtrack and especially in its frequently funny performances.
I did not know I could yawn angrily. This movie somehow proved it possible.
It's quietly brutal stuff, beautifully acted by Fanning, Englert, Christina Hendricks and a word-twisting Alessandro Nivola.
It's got a big heart and high spirits on a low budget and actors who refuse to phone it in.
A workmanlike drama with less-than-total command of its tone.
Bella's still a bit of a blank, but at least now she's a bit of a blank with superpowers.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Never quite manages to feel like more than a surface-scraping, by-the-numbers sports flick.
It isn't particularly deep, but it's a grab-your-seatmate good time at the haunted house.

"Another Earth" looks great, and I gather that Marling and Cahill squeezed a surprising amount of production value out of their tiny budget. But story-wise, this is a shallow exercise with arty trappings.
In its best moments, the movie approaches the mid-list success of the 2007 Will Ferrell vehicle "Blades of Glory."
The movie's amusing enough, and its plot twisty enough, that you can gloss over the half-baked elements.
It finally just grinds you down with its sheer dull busy-ness.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Kazan has a gift for letting you see her think, even when she's perfectly still; the film's title refers to the ferocious trauma happening between Ivy's ears and her silent struggle to keep it in check.
It coasts a bit, but it's slick, and enough jokes and characters connect that you can't quite dismiss it.
The actors give full-bodied, warm, melancholic performances, and their easy chemistry grounds the film even when it flirts with the cliched and the downright bizarre.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The movie's as casual as its lead characters' approach to changing history; it's also lewdly and frequently laugh-out-loud hilarious -- especially if you wasted any of your youth watching a certain brand of '80s comedy schlock on HBO at 2 a.m.
Its gormless, assertion-free protagonist offends as a role model for idiot youths, and, even worse, offends as drama.

I was emotionally involved in the film's final showdowns. It's a shame this involvement is largely earned by Gere, Snipes and Fuqua in spite of some false moments on the page that hold the film back from the greatness it craves.
North Face is a spectacular, suspenseful bummer.
Edge of Darkness fails as a comeback vehicle, as a remake and, to a lesser degree, as a popcorn thriller.
The story sort of plays like a thrill-ride version of The Road, with healthier-looking cannibals and a sillier ending.
At its core, it's another glossy rom-com about a woman dithering in an unhealthy relationship while another, better, meeker suitor waits in the wings.
Did you really just watch 50 guys on trucks and horses blast one another to bits while chasing one guy on a motorcycle? You did. And it was awesome.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad, the Weird (Joheun-nom, Nabbeun-nom, Isanghan-nom) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: I appreciate that talented people wanted to honor Shelly by making this film. They likely would have better honored her by mounting her script as a play.
Really, what it affirms is that studio executives are already making movies for the future-audience from Idiocracy.

The leads have no chemistry; the supporting cast of carnies and eccentrics is bland; the staging is dull; not a single gag lands; and Justin and Galaxy's one get-to-know-you conversation is never heard because it's buried in a road trip music montage.
You can only get so mad at a movie in which a large crowd cheers and the lone subtitle reads "Hooray." With a period.

The movie's carnival-barker hard sell is that it's after The Truth. It's really after an opening-weekend gross, of course. It's sporadically clever and chilling, but I'll be shocked if it endures as a Blair Witch-style horror vérité phenomenon.
The film is competent without being spectacular or thrilling.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The movie starts out as a potboiler with a troubling character arc; unfortunately, it ends up becoming a goofy, story-overwhelming Rube Goldberg contraption that would make the producers of the Saw series blush.
For teenage girls, I could see Whip It being a minor revelation. I hope they see it in droves.

If there's one moment that perfectly encapsulates the vibe of the horror-comedy Zombieland, it's probably this: Woody Harrelson in a cowboy hat, whooping and hollering, picking off zombies with a gun...from a moving roller coaster.
If I have one real beef with Cold Souls, it's simply this: I don't think it digs particularly deeply into the philosophy or the unanswerable questions dredged up by its premise.
I'm not sure if parents will be counting out each of Shorts' 89 minutes or not, begging for it to end, but I'm guessing 8-year-olds will absolutely love it.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: I hope this kicks off a late-career reinvention that finds Ford spending his remaining years playing cowboys sans aliens.
Harrelson gives what might be a career performance as a jaded mentor who tries to conduct each notification using a well-rehearsed set of rules of engagement.
So here's a pleasant surprise: The 2010 remake of The Karate Kid is charming, thoughtfully paced and even a bit emotionally involving, with what might be a movie-star turn by a movie star's son.
Take your kids and start saving up for the DVD, because I suspect they'll be asking you to buy it as soon as they leave the theater.

If you can settle into its odd, low-key groove, I think you'll find it's a light pop beverage that goes down easy during one of the lamest blockbuster summers in recent memory. My parents are really going to like it.
If it's going to be diet Pixar, at least it's action-packed diet Pixar -- with overwhelming, detail-choked production design that occasionally had my jaw lowering like a forklift.
This is Ayoade's feature debut, and it's fairly stunning.
"X-Men: First Class" recaptures the character-driven strengths of the first two films in this superhero series -- while adding a surprising dash of '60s spy-movie style.

I wouldn't call "On Stranger Tides" a disaster, but it does take everything that was charming about the first film and remixes it far less carefully and at a slower pitch, rendering it mildly diverting and shockingly sludgy.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: In an age of increasingly bland, formulaic rom-coms that seem to star the same three actresses, "Bridesmaids" is almost a revelation.
The film feels a bit enervated, even when the script asks it to fly off the rails toward the end.

Between this and last year's overlooked "Faster," it's great to see The Rock re-embracing the action genre, and when his clobbering match with Diesel finally happens, it's as outlandishly room-wrecking as I'd hoped.
The studio's third outing with the motley crew of talking toys is ridiculously entertaining, tightly plotted, laugh-out-loud funny and emotionally true. It might even be the best in the series.
A tired story full of pratfalls, barn-broad gags, cartoonish stuffed shirts, and the exact same story beats you've seen in a million rom-coms, right down to the wedding-aisle confrontation.
The film doesn't break a centimeter of new ground, but its stripped-down mayhem and more-nuanced-than-necessary performances are a modest surprise.

Carrey fearlessly gives it his best shot, but this fundamental schizophrenia strong-armed me out of the film, and left me feeling like McGregor's more grounded performance existed in another movie entirely.
A clichéd drag that wastes talented actors.
The stunts here are metal-crushingly spectacular and refreshingly physical, and Scott doles them out sparingly enough that they're dramatic instead of merely noisy.
I suspect audiences will divide sharply on the movie's wild tone shifts. I found them sort of fearless.
It earns head-pat adjectives like "admirable" and "inspiring" and "restrained" and "well-acted" and "solidly crafted," but never quite stirs the deeper passions.
It's stagnant to the degree that screenwriter Melissa Rosenberg pads out the narrative with no fewer than three narrated costume-drama flashbacks.
This feels like minor Phillips to me -- something in the neighborhood of 2006's "School for Scoundrels," quality-wise, though with a much grimmer heart.
A pretty decent, grim little lost-patrol mash-up of the original Predator and Pitch Black -- a perfectly fine night at the beer-theater, in other words.

Turteltaub has a workmanlike touch and an easy sense of humor here, and he and his team do a better-than-expected job of keeping you interested in the story, despite it being yet another Tale of a Reluctant Young Man With A Supernatural Hero's Calling.
King is good enough that you can't help but root for her. But frankly, I can't imagine paying full ticket price plus concessions for that privilege.
I like that director Daniel Stamm tries to con me with faux supernatural realism in the same way Cotton tries to con the girl he's "exorcising."
McKay (mostly) pulls off something kind of fascinating here: He's made a huge comedy that ruthlessly rips on corporate corruption through a lens of absurdist gags...
The kids provide an earnest emotional through line to a tiny story, and I sort of hope it kicks off a new mature period for Reiner as a filmmaker.
If I believed in the concept of "guilty pleasures," I'd classify Centurion as one, but I think I maybe just kind of enjoyed it.

Story-wise, The Town isn't nearly as tight as Gone Baby Gone. But Affleck mostly makes up for that by revealing two additional filmmaking gifts: He's really good at staging unpretentious action scenes and at directing himself as an actor.
The actors and the film's genial nature help it go down fairly easy. The racing scenes are well-shot and surprisingly thrilling, given the preordained outcome.
"Worth the $15 to get out of the cold."
It's all very exhilarating and, at times, it's one of the scariest movies I've seen in a long time.
Whiskey Tango Foxtrot is basically a drama, being marketed as a comedy, that's a lot better than you probably think it is and finally gives Tina Fey a worthwhile lead role in a film.
Midnight Special doesn't stop. It's intense from start to finish.
"So, so close to being one of those movies you see projected onto brick walls at cool rooftop parties."
It's the perfect movie for Trump's America.
Zoolander No. 2 is a cameo-filled shadow of the first movie.
Joy is a frustrating movie because I can't remember the last time I wanted to like a movie so much and it just wouldn't let me.
Hail, Caesar! is just one of those things you have to experience.
That's what makes Southside With You work, because it just boils down to two people trying to figure out life and each other.
Dirty Grandpa is the worst movie I've ever seen in a movie theater.
The Star Wars we love is back ... with humor comes heart and it's easy to forgive a couple plot points when a movie has this much heart.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Every bit as good as Dazed And Confused.
There have been a lot of comparisons to Gremlins already and I can go along with them to a point - Krampus has the same kind of vibe.
The Hateful Eight is Tarantino's eighth film, as the opening credits emphasize, and it's one his best - a tense, suspenseful and bloody experience.
Deadpool can fancy itself up as much as it wants and insist it's something totally different. But, yep, here we are: Another superhero movie origin story.
Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice just lands with a big thud.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

as long as you can appreciate a good fart joke, Reno 911! Miami is worth your admission
Too bad most of the performers can't seem to pull off the insane IQs they clearly do not have.
Gore hounds will definitely be pleased as The Ruins boasts some of the most sickening blood and guts this side of snuff films.
Don't waste our time with sentimental homeless crap
Watchmen isn't a superhero movie, it's a pretentious turkey that thinks it's better than the genre.
The acting is always good, but when it's not, you can always expect that character to flash her boobs, so who's complaining?
More tailored for the Oscars than a Clint Eastwood war epic, Doubt features some of the best performances we've seen all year but it falls short in other departments.
I don't think Boyle could film paint drying and make it dull.
Smith and Dawson both look like death, so watching their romance-on-life-support is painfully dreary and tragically unsexy

Barring direct-to-DVD Disney sequels, the first Madagascar was one of the worst animated flicks of all time. The bad news is Escape 2 Africa reunites the same cast and directors that made the first DreamWorks flick such a turkey.
Quantum makes us understand the importance of a good director, which is sadly absent here.
Had the team abandoned the tediously tidy final third of the film and all the awful World War II shenanigans we obviously don't care about, Australia would be a wild romp.
Another winner from the Apatow factory, this is a stoner comedy that soars.
after the overcooked live action Grinch and nauseating Cat In The Hat, Hollywood has finally served up a tasty adaptation of Dr. Seuss.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, Streep and her ancient co-stars create pure torture whenever on screen together. This is the Catwoman of movie musicals
a riveting piece of work that will have us all mourning Ledger's loss but smacking our lips for a third entry
Burn After Reading is a welcome escape from September's usual crop of inane thrillers starring Nicolas Cage or Julianne Moore.
Mixing the immediacy of documentary observation and the slam-bang pace of the modern disaster epic, Cloverfield is economic and engaging.
Director Joe Wright is quickly establishing himself as a powerhouse adapter of period romance tomes.
Luckily, Rambo's years away from war haven't dulled his ability to rip out a man's throat with his bare hands.
And the winner of the overrated Oscar front-runner award goes to...
With plenty of betrayal, attempted incest and beheadings crammed into this period episode of The Young and the Restless, The Other Boleyn Sister has appeal in an otherwise stiff genre.
Never do we believe that these two might actually be capable of hooking up off-screen, and this romantic flatness kills your appetite to keep watching.

If you thought 24's perspective on terrorism was, well, limited, get ready to groan. The meat and potatoes of Vantage Point -- the suicide bomb explosions, the bloody fisticuffs and blaring car chases -- are indeed awesome, and that's what truly matters f
The actors speak in fluent anachronistic English. The dialogue is prehistoric but not in the way Emmerich intended.
Fans of comedies like Legally Blonde and Mean Girls should get a kick out of Anna Faris' amusing starring vehicle, even if this one isn't quite as sly or slickly produced.

Outside of maybe X-men's Jubilee, I can't think of a comic character less deserving of the big-screen treatment than Ghost Rider. But what do I know? Maybe the idea of Nic Cage in unyielding biker leather sounded good on paper.

The acting is hammy, Djimon Hounsou shows up to give the flick a corny air of Karate Kid and there's nothing particularly original about the whole premise but somehow it works. It must be those abs. Or the kicks to them.
Hugh Grant and Drew Barrymore have a charming chemistry, though this shouldn't be too surprising, considering they both can pull off the bumbling goofball lover with ease
If it wasn't for the inherent hilarity in mask-toting midgets that growl or obese wrestling fans who tunnel through walls, Nacho Libre would be an insultingly puerile dump
what we do get is a blast, and the writers have the balls to let good characters die
as melancholy slow as Brokeback, only minus the hunks, the chemistry and the gayness
Cars is about as much fun as a traffic jam in desert heat, or heck, watching NASCAR
Dull Vinci Bore
if getting rained on by fecal matter and fisticuffs with ferocious raccoons (played by three tracks of off-camera Foley-SFX) tickle your funny-bone, then by all means board this trailer-park dump.
don't be mistaking this for a Madagascar rip-off, when it was that sloppy DreamWorks turd that only managed to make it to theatres first because of corporate espionage
worse than those episodes of 24 featuring cougars chasing Kim Bauer
it's the ferocious production design and unrelenting atmosphere that fully immerses us in Gans' horrifically breathtaking Silent Hill.
this rom-com dodges the unsavory omen of its title and once again demonstrates that predictable plots aren't so bad if they involve Matthew McConaughey removing his shirt.
Superman Returns is a thundering epic of Spielbergian proportions: colossal action, grandiose effects and a breathtaking story.
V For Vendetta should be seen less for the conspiracy theories discussion it inspires and more for its vicious storytelling
the most gratifyingly God-awful guilty pleasure since Catwoman, another gem co-starring Sharon Stone
It's here to up the ante from Final Destination 2 (which featured a beautiful car pileup, a barbecue explosion and a fire-escape impaling) and instead it creates poetry out of the filmic slaughter.
Curious George is unbearable animated torture: monotonous, hackneyed and lethally cute
The saccharine production design and nasty pink-and-red buxom costumes are as fabulous as the full palette of hysterical performances.
Munich is worth seeing despite the fact it ends up a tedious watch.
It's nice to watch a femme-driven action piece that doesn't completely suck (except in ways it should)
Brokeback Mountain is concerned with poignant storytelling and not once is this compromised by the glistening manlove.
If you're the squeamish type or think Hollywood's appreciation for bloodbath is barbarically crude, stay away at all costs and lock your kids inside
It's an appropriate thing this film is about the strength of imagination because you'll be needing yours if you plan on surviving until the final credits
This sequel is just a string of lame slapstick gags, where Steve Martin acts handicapped, makes a fool of himself and gets a wetsuit stuck up his butt.
a rare breed of incisive, razor-sharp satire with charming life lessons for the family
you don't have to be female or gay to appreciate vicious wit
Spike Lee's auteur stamp of keeping-it-real dialogue and cross-racial, cross-class themes lets Inside Man pretend it's about more than a clever caper.
The formula is predictable but the film deserves props for making a momentary fan out of someone who wouldn't be caught dead watching Monday Night Football
about as distracting and inoffensive as Jumanji before it, and heck, it might even teach kids that history can be fun!
the PG-rated antics suck any tension away when you become fully aware that killer houses in kids' movies can't actually kill anything.

while the soul, rhythm and blues is belted out to perfection by Beyonce and scene stealer Jennifer Hudson, many of the singing scenes tragically feel more like improvised song-speak than choreographed numbers
Call me rash, but I wager the worst flick of 2007 is Sarah Michelle Gellar's latest clunker, Happily N'ever After.
Retreading familiar territory isn't so bad when you have Hilary Swank as your guide.
Like a highly prized jewel, the Blood Diamond is uniquely beautiful but flawed. Unfortunately, in the movie business, we prefer our gems flawless.
It's no wonder you can expect a spoof called "Epic Movie," in theatres next spring, from the makers of Scary Movie.
Stranger than Fiction is more high-concept than high-brow; a comedy heavy on gimmick that falls a little short of cunning.
The film is an unsentimental departure for the series with an exciting performance in brawny Daniel Craig's debut
The two-hour-plus behemoth actually charms, and you get two gleeful romances for the price of one. If you need more incentive, Jude Law has never been sexier.
Whether or not you still hate Mel Gibson for his drunken Anti-Semitic tirade, Apocalypto is a rousing experience and a spectacular ride.
Charlotte's Web is so good it almost makes a carnivore want to boycott pork.
Where A Good Year is headed is obvious before the opening frame, but working from a warm script, Ridley Scott directs mostly genuine performances to keep us interested
Watching Cage karate chop Leelee "Made-for-TV" Sobiesky into submission is almost worth the price of admission. Well, assuming admission was free.
the whole romance against-all-odds angle is a little been there, done that eight months ago with Tristan & Isolde

I didn't hate every second of All the King's Men. The film is book-ended by two cool bird's eye shots of the Louisiana State crest...Combined, these symbolic images last about 2-3 minutes. I did, however, hate every other second.
I'd have preferred a more Crash -esque collection of vignettes that explored a wider range of the 9/11 repercussions.
Stealing freely from Save the Last Dance but unintentionally nixing the wicked dance moves, this teen turd doesn't even have the logical sense to remove its hunky lead's shirt.
This is one of those chick flicks with nice characters and little plot, so boyfriends had best beware.
Betty Thomas's sloppy storytelling and comic incompetence can be forgiven but to portray young women as flighty airheads obsessed with boys over all else is downright offensive.
Lady in the Water sounds wacky but it's mostly just boring.
Parents would be best to protect their children from the consequent psychological trauma of letting them see this.
only gluttons for the tacky sub-genre of B-movie creature features will likely appreciate (or even see) this barge of filmic cheese, but for them, this is almost an all-you-can-eat buffet.
A dazzling, stirring capper to a once-in-a-generation movie franchise.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There's a reason this formula has endured so long: When you plug the right variables into it, it still can make for an enjoyable, if predictable, story. This film proves it.
At every step, director Tim McCanlies grinds the gears in his earnest, but ultimately clunky, adaptation.
For all of its faults (underdeveloped characters and an ending that flirts with the ridiculous) it manages to squeeze more movie into its 64 minutes than many do in 90 or more
The nerd-rage on display when discussing Lucas' ceaseless tinkering with his films -- to say nothing of the midi-chlorians debate -- is ... plenty entertaining.
A solidly entertaining summertime spectacle and one of the more enjoyable films in the genre since 2008's Iron Man.
It's admirably optimistic -- and it's hard to argue with free hugs -- but the world is a whole lot more complex than Shadyac seems to realize.
The filmmakers create a mythology that goes unexplained, raise questions that go unanswered, and generally go out of their way to confound and frustrate their audience.
A film that is shot straightforwardly -- to the point of being visually unimaginative -- but that benefits enormously from the overflowing charisma of its subjects.
Spurlock's irresistible sense of showmanship once more takes information we all know, and he presents it in a surprisingly engaging and entertaining way.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A period drama that's as predictable and cliched as green beer on St. Patrick's Day.
It should have borrowed some charm.
Even if Hey, Boo falls short as a piece of revelatory filmmaking, it succeeds nicely as a love letter to Lee's novel.
movie_title: Hey, Boo: Harper Lee and 'To Kill a Mockingbird' (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This latest chapter isn't sharp enough to restore the sense of discovery that made that 1st outing so exciting, but it's enough to make up for most of the missteps of the darn arrgh-inducing third one.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's just 40 minutes long, but in that short time it produces more "awwww" moments than any feature-length film to hit theaters this year.
Will Ferrell proves to have a way of turning fortune-cookie platitudes into something that, if not especially deep, is at least enjoyable and buoyant and entirely watchable.
Whether in a throwaway SNl skit or an overlong, uneven comedy such as this, Kristin Wiig has a knack for transforming something lackluster into something entertaining
Audicious and wonderfully offbeat ... it's a fun one to talk about -- if only for the opportunity to shake your head in amused disbelief at what you just saw.
Don't worry if you're not familiar with the obscure source material. There are plenty of other sources of disappointment to be found in director Kevin Munroe's B-movie mess.
Unencumbered by voiceover or any sort of forced narrative, the result is an intimate and riveting look at Dylan unfiltered, a portrait of the artist as a 24-year-old superstar.
It is a thoughtful film, a serious one, and one that is sneakily affecting.
It will give its intended tween audience a lot to squeal about -- and leave their parents reminiscing quietly about how good films from '80s icon John Hughes were.
There's a handful of delightful moments, but most of it feels 30 years too late to carry any sort of fist-pumping resonance
An under-the-radar breath of fresh air built on a strong cast and a smart script.
A textbook example of ye olde two-joke movie -- and beneath those two jokes, there's precious little else to fall back on.
Director Sean McNamara's relentlessly shiny, happy outlook crosses the line between believable and artificial by about the 10-minute mark
Just doesn't have enough new gadgets in its utility belt to keep it from becoming much more than a super shrug
A foul-mouthed, anatomically obsessed and downright fun black comedy.
It's a film for patient moviegoers. But for those moviegoers, it stands to be a rewarding experience.
The influence of Japanese animation master Hayao Miyazaki is obvious here, and it's a comparison that doesn't flatter French filmmaker Jacques-Remy Girerd's movie.
movie_title: Mia et le Migou (Mia and the Migoo) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: With an elegant simplicity that befits the man at the center of it all, it's a multi-layered, metaphor-rich film with beautiful, hard-to-ignore lessons.
A warm and sweet song of hope -- and chocolate pie -- that pushes all the right buttons.
It's (the) insight and honesty that elevates the film, transforming it into an inspiring -- if a shade or two less than truly intimate -- portrait of an immensely likable man

A lovely and lyrical homage to a unique tradition in an already unique city, and one of the best and most affecting A-to-Z accountings of what that tradition truly means. I've seen the film three times. I've cried three times.
While this nouveau Fright Night does a reasonable job of maintaining the fun spirit of the original film, ... (it) never quite makes a convincing case for its own existence.
Covering well-worn territory and offering no solutions, it ends up feeling shrill and angry and not nearly as profound as Chapman seems to think it is.
John C. Reilly does what he always seems to do: He energizes, and thus steals, nearly every scene he's in.
Despite a handful of hiccups and a smattering of cliches, it does exactly what it sets out to do: It ratchets up the tension, then sustains it for an hour and a half.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An icy and humorless -- but entirely suspenseful -- film that works mostly because of its unpredictability.
An adoring, though enlightening, look at the tumultuous run of the influential hip-hop group.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A cerebral, slow-play drama built around mood and heartfelt performances. ... In other words: No robots, no plasma cannons, no Jar-Jar.
A mostly bland crime comedy that only occasionally feels fresher or more memorable than that cold pizza you scarfed for breakfast.
Think Freak Friday with F-bombs.
A sneakily absorbing indie thriller.

Na-na-na-na-na-blah.

This is rusty 'Ghost of Mars' John Carpenter, not 'The Thing' John Carpenter -- and certainly not 'Halloween' John Carpenter.
A story of hope amid the ruins -- one that everybody can appreciate, no matter their politics.
Somewhere on its way to Cliché-ville, this pleasant-surprise romantic comedy ... finds a great deal of fun in what could have been a musty, forgettable film.

Quickly avant-gardes itself right into incomprehensibility.

The kind of film that serves as rigid, nicely paced entertainment during its two-hour running time, then can be counted on to jump-start conversation on the drive home.
A wonderfully intimate insider's look at what was going on backstage while Yves Saint-Laurent's models were strutting down the catwalk for more than four decades.

These women deserve to have their voices heard, and this film finally lets them have their say.
A flat and pretentious teen drama that rings false at every turn.
This film is undoubtedly a piece of art, as much so as a Picasso painting -- one that invites viewers to immerse themselves, scratch their heads and consider it.
A heartfelt and compassionate portrait of mental illness.
For the first time in its 25-year existence, Pixar has created an utterly ordinary film.
A thought-provoking, and at-times creepy, bit of hands-on reportage.
As well-meaning as it is, (it) is a two-dimensional bit of fluff, an untidy string of cutesy scenes and cutesy characters -- few of them as cute as they are intended to be.
A bright, cuddly blend of watercolor warmth and comfy, cozy nostalgia.
With strong performances and striking, well-conceived visuals, in Fukunaga's hands Bronte's tale of love and woe becomes one well worth repeating.
If this movie proves anything it's that Christian Bale is the greatest actor of his generation.
As engrossing as it is emotionally charged.

movie_review_blurb: An example of op-ed cinema. That is, when it's done right, it's edifying and absorbing -- but when it slips, as it often does here, it just feels like a chore.
Something less than a masterpiece, but much closer to it than some of the other recent entries in the Disney catalog. (Yes, you, Chicken Little and Treasure Planet.)

A masterful slice of four-star cinema, featuring an irresistible performance by James Franco, breathtaking cinematography, and the kind of deep, searching soul that is absent from so much of what comes out of Hollywood

The real story here is the arrival of (director Tanya) Hamilton.

Doesn't live up to the 1985 Coen brothers film that inspired it.

movie_review_blurb: Yogi Bear can claim all he wants that he's smarter than the average bear, but his latest big-screen incarnation is uncomfortably close to being a big-screen boo-boo.
Brooks' latest grown-up comedy -- as glossy as it appears, as gracefully as it unfolds, as charming as its impressive, all-star cast often is -- arrives as a mild misfire.
A beautifully shot but aggressively menacing film that is at turns irresistibly sumptuous and hide-your-eyes-behind-your-hands disturbing.

Everything about it is intended to let us know that the emotions in play here are real and nothing to be trifled with. Unfortunately, it all centers around a relationship that's not so easy to root for.
Modern Times magically reaches forward through the decades, resonating loudly for these difficult modern times.
Grown Ups heralds a sad day for comedy nostalgists of a certain age. Call it the day the amusement died.
As he goes about his admirably nonpartisan expose, ... Ferguson misses the opportunity to hammer home the big-picture problem behind the meltdown.
It's surprising in the lovely notes it consistently hits, and the simmering sweetness it achieves, despite the dark, seedy framework propping it up
The best of the franchise to date, a satisfying, appetite-whetting setup for the series finale.

movie_review_blurb: Based on a limp script that holds more padding and melodrama than genuine tension, it all feels like one big wasted opportunity.
Last Train Home will tug at your heartstrings as it opens your eyes, but it also will make you feel incredibly lucky and more than a little spoiled.
As often as Perry's melodramatic storytelling hits the mark (Thandie Newton's performance), it misses at least as often (Whoopi Goldberg's).
Wouldn't be nearly the knee-slapper it is without Robert Downey Jr. and Hangover revelation Galifianakis holding down the lead roles.
This is a movie that is, at its root, a romance, wrapped up in an 80-year-old master director's musings about what happens to us when we die.
A high-octane dose of summer-flavored fun, an AARP action film that comes along just in time to add a little levity -- and some serious weaponry -- to Hollywood's serious-minded fall awards season.

It is a period piece, it is a sci-fi drama, it is a romance. There even is a dash of horror in there. It's an unlikely melange, but it combines for something both refreshingly original and quietly affecting.
Penny Chenery's story is good stuff. It's just that watching it, one can't escape the nagging feeling that it's not the most compelling part of the (Secretariat) story.
Writing and directing partners Anna Boden and Ryan Fleck have come up with a smart little film, a gentle drama with both an embraceable tone and a refreshing optimism.

movie_review_blurb: Every bit as moody, as melancholy and as meaningful as its Swedish inspiration, as it explores heartbreaking themes of alienation and the universal need for human contact.
I Love You Phillip Morris is first and foremost a romantic comedy -- and a more effective one than any to hit theaters in 2010.
A complete and compelling portrait of a woman determined to defy the odds and become a true leader in the Muslim world.

A bloody, but oddly entertaining, holiday ho-ho-horror story.
It will charm the training pants off of the audience for which it is intended -- without leaving parents constantly checking their watches.
A brilliantly told mindbender, a perfect example of how the right approach to storytelling can elevate a film
A fantastic portrayal of His Airness' on-court heroics -- not to mention visually stunning
Burger's stylishly directed film makes up for any narrative hiccups with a mix of wry humor and comic-book-inspired visual flourishes.
A movie that knows exactly what it is and never tries to overreach. This is an unapologetic goofball romp, nothing more, nothing less
It provides ample moments for reflection -- and maybe, judging by the reactions of the American musicians who go back home in his film, a little bit of healing, too
It's really more amusing than it is fall-out-of-your-seat funny. ... There's a general lack of any real edge here -- though not for a lack of trying.
As embraceable as it is, Tulip often feels as if it would have been a better animated short than a feature.
A heartbreaking but engrossing detective story that not only shines a light on Nazi evil but on the manipulative prowess of the Third Reich.
Undeveloped characters, undeveloped performances, undeveloped emotions and a mess of a script that could have benefited greatly from an extensive rewrite. Or at least some singing crockery.
A nicely paced exercise, one that benefits from both a sprinkling of humor and all-around strong performances.
A thoughtful and interesting deconstruction and demythologizing of American celebrity
A remarkably uncomplicated story -- a beautifully uncomplicated story, really -- about the love between daddies and their little girls.
Dragged down by earnest but amateurish performances and an overall Afterschool Special vibe
A poor man's Poltergeist.
Director Antonio Negret's evil-twins film would have made a nice, taut Twilight Zone episode. One of the half-hour ones.
Its plot is every bit as silly, its script is every bit as cliché-ridden, its main characters every bit as afflicted by adolescent emotions as those in Twilight.
A fascinating peek behind the scenes of Clouzot's colossal failure ... (and) a compelling portrait of what happens when an artist's ego is allowed to run amok.
This retelling of the Bard's tale is tedious stuff, in the way that second-rate animated movies tend to be.
The Eagle is exactly what you'd imagine a movie about Roman centurions should be -- if, that is, you're 12 years old and have a fairly limited imagination.
Leigh's Oscar-nominated script isn't so much plot-driven as it is character-driven. Given that there's little arc to any of these characters, it is less than rewarding.
On its way to profundity, Inarritu's film ends up getting tangled in its own histrionics.
Aside from the cast of archetypes and the dash of confusion generated by some less than smooth editing during the film's crisis scenes, Sanctum is fairly entertaining.
Like the original, it is a moody, atmospheric film, one boasting significantly more depth than your typical blow-'em-up.
It's at its root a hard-to-resist character study. That's because the character being studied is you and me and everyone else who has ever fallen in, and out of, love
Part The Great Escape and part Lawrence of Arabia, it is ambitious in scope, grand in vision and rich with examples of the resilience of the human spirit.
An entirely immersing documentary, one of those movies whose real value comes in the way it envelops viewers in a world they never knew existed.
There are lackluster movies Vince Vaughn can charm into being better. There are mediocre scripts Ron Howard can will some life into. The Dilemma just isn't one of them
(The) first unapologetic crowd-pleasing, fist-pumping, just-for-fun popcorn flick of 2011.
The King's Speech is all about layers, and (director Tom) Hooper keeps it humming on several at once.
Not only does Giamatti solidify his reputation as a great actor -- a brilliant cinematic chameleon -- but he helps transform Lewis' film into a lovely bit of dramatic comedy.
A grandly appointed disappointment.

movie_review_blurb: A reasonably solid thriller, built on equal parts action and suspense, and punctuated by the occasional bit of deft rug-pulling.
A wonderfully embraceable little film, one that is at turns honeysuckle-sweet, cherry blossom-delicate, and as comforting as the shade of a City Park oak.
Although New Orleans sparkles as the film's setting, the story boasts too many moving and mismatched parts to resonate in any sort of meaningful way.
Big, loud, ridiculous and eye-popping, writer-director Joss Whedon's film is an empty-calorie summertime treat that delivers on all that it promises.
A beautiful and stirring story of unconditional compassion, of emotional honesty, and -- above all -- of hope.
An engaging portrait of a fascinating artist, it is difficult if not impossible to look away from once it gets going -- much like Crewdson's astonishing photographs.
It isn't quite a religious experience, but it is a sweet one. In other words: We have a charmer.
It's certainly comprehensive, even if -- at two and a half hours long -- not exactly concise.
An exercise in emotional tedium.
As artful as it is appetizing.
While it looks nice, it ends up being more "meh" than "arrr."
Most Apatow-produced movies are grown-up comedies. This one is a comedy for grown-ups.

Two opposable thumbs up.

A vivid and musical illustration of the transportive powers of cinema.

A head-spinning, heart-pounding, 101-minute fusillade of punching, kicking, stabbing, slashing, cracking, crunching, gouting and spurting.
A film that is as important for bullies to see as it is for their parents to see, so everyone can understand just how devastating a problem this can be.
Uneven but entirely embraceable.
A bold and brave statement of defiance.
Standard movie-of-the-week fare dressed up in Sunday-go-to-meeting clothes.

Even if it wasn't propelled by a compelling narrative, and even if Ross' film didn't strike a nice balance between honoring the book and slavishly adhering to it, Katniss would be a fascinating character. That both of those are true only helps.
An unconventionally structured but thoroughly riveting indie drama, propelled by a searing performance from Tilda Swinton.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Roksam tends to spend too much time on the convoluted details of the world of illicit beef hormones, but he has an great character on which to focus the rest of the time.
A great cast -- anchored by a wonderful performance from Jason Segel -- makes the most of what ends up being a surprisingly moving story.
The idea to play the concept for laughs is an inspired one, and Jonah Hill and Channing Tatum mine the material for all the crass, R-rated comedy that it's worth.
It's a sloppy and rushed affair, built around shrug-worthy visuals, a recycled and clichéd plot, and forgettable performances.
Halston's name is in the title, but the faintly irritating Ultrasuede isn't necessarily about the fashion designer. It's about director Whitney Sudler-Smith
Mondern-dance documentary is visually dazzling but it doesn't make the slightest effort to invite the unconverted to the party.
It's the little moments in Farhadi's film that are its most important, speaking every bit as loudly as its big, narrative-driving moments.
Big, loud, dumb -- and fun.
The veteran cast is wonderful, making the most of a movie whose sole reason to exist is to make audiences smile.
Despite a pervasive one-dimensionality, its bold message is well-delivered -- and frankly, hard to debate.
A fun, loose-with-the-facts story that deftly walks the fine line separating bawdy from bad taste.
Universal hits reset, take the series in a new direction, and introduces some fresh ideas that help buttress what ends up being a reasonably intense action film.
Can Ferrell's Cam Brady make us laugh at things we know we shouldn't laugh at while slyly delivering a poke in the eye to modern politics? Yes, he Cam.
Not only are Streep and Jones a delight to watch on-screen, but they are also easily the best things about Frankel's film, which they end up rescuing.
Seizing the role, and the screen, Jordan Gelber actually makes us care what happens to his surly, thoroughly unlikable character.
An entirely harmless and congenial tale of pre-teen social mayhem.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Dog Days (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Instead of a thinking man's film, we get a glorified and soulless chase film, one girded not so much by deep thoughts or clever plotting but by visual razzle-dazzle.
A stirring and thoughtful story of the power of friendship and a tribute to the strength of the human spirit.
The story girding Do-Deca - though intriguing - doesn't feel as well-developed as previous Duplass scripts. As a result, it never quite resonates, style be darned.
The quality of some of the performances are expected (Michelle Williams), some are a surprise (Seth Rogen, Sarah Silverman), but all contribute greatly to a lovely & meaningful film.

Its soaring third act does offers an exhilarating ending to a great trilogy. But for much of the bloated two hours that precede it, this Dark Knight doesn't rise as much as it flounders and frustrates.
Working from a script as uneven as his accent, Sheen turns in an otherwise strong performance, but the sanitized Stella Days generates no real spark.
At the rate things devolving, we can expect Ice Age 10 to be little more than a feature-length flip book.
I saw Katy Perry: Part of Me -- and I liked it.
Imagine Disney's The Rescuers had it been directed by Alfred Hitchcock, and you're zeroing in on the tone of this Oscar-nominated charmer.
Intentionally unnerving from the first moments, it's a hard movie to watch, but it's also fantastically, agonizingly suspenseful.
Woody Allen follows up his magical Midnight in Paris with a sweet but entirely shrug-worthy stroll through Rome.
A portrait of intestinal fortitude in the face of enormous change, Zeitlin's surrealist fairy tale doubles as a tribute to the back-bowing determination of fringe-dwellers everywhere.
From a technical standpoint, Webb has woven a rock-solid superhero flick. Unfortunately, Webb's film never quite shakes the feeling that we've done all this before.
With Burnat's eerily emotionless narration serving as a contrast to the heart-wrenching story, what we end up with is a captivating portrait of the frailty and the failures of humanity
To his credit, MacFarlane earns his laughs here, making an effort to write jokes that would be funny even if they weren't being delivered by a talking teddy bear.
This sick-kid drama is well-made enough, but ultimately too familiar to resonate.
It's a testament to the charm of actress Greta Gerwig that she can save this sluggish script.
Rarely has the apocalypse seemed so sweet.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Wonderfully inventive and entirely immersing.
A sweet story, beautifully animated, and one that -- coming on the heels of "Cars 2" -- suggests the magic is back at Pixar.
It is an offbeat charmer that is fun and engaging from a storytelling standpoint, but one that also brings a surprisingly rich emotional payoff.
The Great Emancipator as the Great Decapitator makes for just so much B-movie schlock.
Beneath all the polish -- and Will Smith's considerable charm -- is a mediocre, lazily written story.
A sprawling, two-hour string of mostly random gags held together with doody jokes and bodily fluids. (Emphasis on the "gag.")
The music is fun, but it's the pesky between-the-songs moments where Shankman's flimsily plotted, paper-thin mix tape of a movie loses its footing.
A brutal and searing drug drama, with an appealing depth amid the appalling violence.
A smart, compelling -- and optimistic -- portrait of heartbreak and hope.
For all of the love and money lavished upon John Carter it ends up feeling a touch musty and overly familiar.
This is not a feel-good movie. This is the frigid, hard-to-embrace cinematic opposite of a feel-good movie, in fact -- all wrapped in one long, dark metaphor for depression.
A sweet but wholly artificial bit of family entertainment.
When it's all said and done, there's no real call for any emotional investment on the part of Almodovar's audience.
A nuance-free, emotionally stunted historical drama.
Filled with soft-focus close-ups, dreamy fades and bizarre angles, (it) nicely matches the dreamy, otherworldly quality of the band's music.
America, meet Elizabeth Olsen.
Sigh. Really, Al Pacino? Really?
A solid but staid portrait of a fascinating man.
Gets the job done, and admirably, blending interviews, testimonials, concert footage and, interestingly, animation to build a full and engaging portrait of Fishbone.
movie_title: Everyday Sunshine: The Story of Fishbone (2011)

movie_review_blurb: That's right: I come to praise Emmerich, not to bury him.
A reasonably taut story of political intrigue, international corruption and one woman's determined fight for justice
A sadly and tenderly honest portrait of a storybook romance lost.
It lubes its audiences' mental gears and sets them to spinning without insulting anyone and without issuing threats of eternal damnation. Subtlety, thy name is Vera.
Following the script of the original as if it were an Arthur Murray dance diagram, Brewer's do-over is at its root a very capable display of painting by numbers.
A satisfyingly tense desert-island thriller -- just without the desert island
A searing drama buoyed by exquisite performances and a keen understanding from its first-time director of the power of the absence of dialog.
Little more than a loud and glossy collection of faintly rusty pieces-parts salvaged from movies that came before it.
Even if Clooney's film is short on solutions, it's still a ticket that everybody, regardless of their political stripes, should be able to support.
One of the more enjoyable horror-comedies to come along since the original Scream.
a sterilized and predictable version of life that plays out like a very special movie of the week -- albeit one with a nice soundtrack.
Once it hits its stride, it's oddly compelling stuff.
It's marked by fine performances from a great cast, but it's hard to escape the fact that The Debt takes itself very, very seriously, to its own detriment.
For all of its seeming conventions, this surprisingly plot-heavy character drama is a wonderfully UNconventional cops-and-robbers picture.
A thought-proving and entirely moving portrait of human arrogance -- in general and with some very, very specific examples.
It's a strong technical film, with good performances and a simmering intensity. If only I could figure out why this was necessary.
An unusually upscale, and surprisingly satisfying, action film.
Director Matthew Bate misjudges the hilarity of it all, as it stops being funny -- and is instead depressing -- after 20 or so minutes.
A Disney-esque amalgam of sweetness, humor and a general heartwarming vibe.
Coasts along the old-fashioned way: On great performances and a surprisingly engaging script
A talky and often-stodgy film that will please history buffs but leave ordinary viewers a touch cold.
This Spanish-language creep-out feels like a road we've been down before.
A calcuated portrait of teen angst, but one that's just interesting enough to be worth watching.
A slumberous bore.
movie_title: Over Your Cities Grass Will Grow (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A wonderful, touching story, one that made me want to scoop up every kid I know who has a scrap of creative talent, and have them watch the film.
A grown-up, emotionally complex film buoyed by Clooney's wonderfully nuanced performance.
More approachable than many anime films, it's a sweet, gentle G-rated story with just the right blend of heart and humor.
Despite the occasional predictability, it ends up being a satisfyingly taut thrill ride. Or maybe Tobin Forst made me say that ...
There's no need for overstatement here, no need to inject this story with melodrama, no need to try to make it more than it is. Unfortunately - and frustratingly - Zhang Yimou didn't recognize that.
A thinking man's drama that rolls deep, heavy thoughts around and around, trying to puzzle out where the truth lies. Or, indeed, if what we see as the truth is just that: a lie.
Searing performances breathe life into this NC-17-rated portrait of a sex addict.
With its big heart and congenial cast, this family-friendly eco-drama is an easy movie to like.
Cold, harsh and riveting.
It is a flawed film, but one that accomplishes what it sets out to do: entertain, if in fits and starts, for an hour and a half.
A beautiful bore.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Strong performances from Fassbender and Mortensen aren't enough to help Cronenberg's techically sound by overly talky film.
Harmless but brainless.
It is at times extremely touching and incredibly moving. Unfortunately, at other times, it also is fairly flawed and slightly disappointing.
There isn't a whole lot of nuance in writer-director Rachid Bouchareb's unapologetically political story. But Blethyn's performance ultimately draws viewers in.
A warm and comfy dose of old-school charm and smile-inducing entertainment.
A return to form for Kermit and company.
Fortunately, Roman Polanski has a dream cast to lean on in his brainy but talky comedy of manners.
David Fincher's smartly written, expertly told chronicling of the dawn of the Facebook era ... is just that compelling, that engrossing, that hard to resist. Kind of like a certain website I know.
There's a fine line separating complex from convoluted, and -- with limited time to tell le Carre's sprawling tale -- Alfredson often comes down on the wrong side.
An extraordinarily compelling and hard-hitting portrait of two Irish families and their decades-old, bare-knuckled feud.
A congenial, though slow-starting, look at an amazing animal.
A beautifully shot film steeped in emotion.
Steven Spielberg's breathless big-screen adventure rescues what otherwise has been a thoroughly lackluster year for animation fans.
Utterly engaging, a transporting bit of cinema that immerses viewers -- uncomfortably at times -- in a riveting detective story.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Though it has its flaws, Young Adult is a smart, thoughtful and quietly, curiously entertaining film.
Like its predecessor, it's a disappointing case of all style and precious little substance. Guy Ritchie has a flair, but he doesn't have a clue.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This sordid soap opera ... goes beyond gritty and into the realm of grimy -- and, at times, downright icky
A richly drawn, and at times disturbing, portrait of one man's descent into madness.
A just-for-fun, feel-good people's picture -- and and one that never gets on its high horse and preaches to get there.
Bill Condon gives the series' fans what they have shown they want: uneven storytelling, maudlin dialog and decidedly one-note performances.
An utterly beautiful film -- both visually and emotionally -- and itself an enchanting gift from Scorsese to film fans everywhere.
The lines have begun to show in Belle's tale, which remains enjoyable but feels more like a quaint artifact than the masterpiece it once was declared to be.
Not nearly cinematic enough or well-written enough to take that doozy of a step that so often separates "inspirational" and "hokey."
It's a slice of reality hidden under a narrative veneer, illustrating the plight of Iran's muzzled arts community. That's hard-to-resist stuff, and it makes Persian Cats purr.
movie_title: No One Knows About Persian Cats (Les Chats Persans) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: As disturbing as the expertly paced Cropsey is, it's not some schlocky spookfest. It's a well-produced and well-researched bit of investigative journalism.
It is interesting. It is ambitious. It is well-assembled, and it is beautifully shot. And it is long -- so long, in fact, that Soderbergh broke his project into two parts.
There are sweet moments, and there are funny moments, but it all just becomes so eye-rollingly calculated that it's hard to appreciate.
It's a gripping tale, as infuriating as it is jaw-dropping at times, but it also becomes a frustratingly sprawling one here.
Insufferable. Burdened with insipid plotting and lame comedy.
By no means is this lukewarm drama Woody Allen's worst work, but it's no dream, either.
A powerful and absorbing drama, built upon strong production values and heartbreakingly authentic performances.
Lacks the satirical edge of Office Space, but with its likable cast elevating the material, Judge extracts enough ironic chuckles to save it.
Beneath its gritty visual realism -- which feels more suited to a full-on drama -- it's a delightful shrug of a movie.
Mild with a chance of chuckles, it's well-cast, well-acted and well-produced. It's just that it would make a far better sitcom than a feature film.
The compassionately acted Adam is a movie with something to say -- it's just not clear exactly what that something is.
A surprisingly uplifting examination of life and loss.
