Aside from the addition of 3-D, the newest Final Destination flick has little to offer audiences other than more gleefully depraved scenes of carnage.
It's interesting and often amusing stuff, populated as it is with a cast of oddball characters, but it's also uneven, with a tendency to sag for stretches.
Not only does it have all the Tarantino hallmarks -- crackling dialog, dark comedy, graphic violence -- but it's also got Brad Pitt and dead Nazis. Entertaining? Immensely.
Tyson's dissection of his own struggles makes the film hard to turn away from. In that respect, Tyson is a lot like a train wreck. In fact, Tyson's life is like a train wreck in a lot of ways.
Even with its appealing cast ... most of the time Post Grad just coasts along, flat as a mortar board and as forgettable as a ... oh, I forgot already.
More reality show than fashion show, it's slight but still as fun as it is fashionable.
Think of Shorts as The Hangover for 10-year-olds -- or for anybody who truly appreciates booger humor.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard to explain all the vitriol aimed at Meirelles' film, which is a beautifully shot picture that is as haunting and profound as it is thought-provoking.
It's predictable, it's overacted, it's little more than a longer version of the TV show -- and it's a guaranteed hit among loyal fans of the fictional pop star.
An utterly magnificent film, one that is as hard to forget as it is to ignore. As such, it is destined to live a long life, in peoples' minds and on scholars' shelves.
Inspired by the touching book -- by Los Angeles Times columnist Steve Lopez -- Downey, Foxx and Wright make appealing, if just short of beautiful, music.
A reasonably satisfying family film that updates things while staying true to the adventurous, sci-fi spirit of the originals.
It's a just-for-funsies caper, and the Coen brothers seem to revel in it, helped along by an impressive cast that gleefully follows their lead.
A modestly uplifting, and at-times poignant, buddy comedy that manages to make the most of the worst of situations.
A bleak and often befuddling 2-hour-15-minute disappointment.
Although it dishes up an original premise and tries to mine laughs from a setup most studios wouldn't have touched with a 10-foot feather boa, it stumbles when it comes to generating any real laughs.
You know what would be brave? Making an unflinching film about a difficult-to-tackle topic and complex characters, and sticking to your message, damn the torpedoes.
Built upon a powerful but gimmicky end, The Boy in the Striped Pajamas would make a fine short. As a full-length feature, though, the pajamas wear thin quickly.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Choke is an admirably fearless no-net movie, but rather than wowing the crowd below, it lands in the center of the big top with a resounding thud.
The body count is high, the running time is particularly long for a children's film, and the themes are fairly heavy. But, like Wardrobe, it's a lush and mostly entertaining production.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Built upon a bedrock of dazzling and richly constructed sets -- think Dr. Seuss meets Jules Verne meets Mad Max -- and complemented by rock-solid storytelling, it's an enormously enjoyable family film.
Despite its sincerity -- and the beautiful visuals -- the often-disjointed story takes too long to gain traction.
More satisfying than your cookie-cutter romantic comedy but far less overwrought than a full-blown period romance, it finds a satisfying and cuddly middle ground.
In addition to blowing bunker-sized holes in the concept of Jewish timidity during the Holocaust, it's also a darn good bit of period storytelling.
It's a gritty, adrenaline-soaked thriller -- and if that's as deep as you care to dig, you'll be entertained. But for those who care to contemplate, it's quite a bit more.
This is both a bad film and a bad influence, and on many levels. Still, for all of its brainlessness, it somehow manages a train-wreck hold on attention.
It not only surpasses Batman Begins - previously considered the high-water mark of movies about the Caped Crusader - but one that magnificently transcends the superhero genre.
A charming, though occasionally off-target -- and consistently tempo-challenged -- romantic comedy.
Death be not proud, but it sure be funny in this deliciously dark comedy.
As a piece of entertainment, it's like being dealt a pair of twos: You could certainly do worse, but ...
Visually, it mixes a gritty reality with eye-popping horror-fantasy, but the story short-circuits the film by adding a level of incomprehensibility, particularly in its second half.
Robert Wise's original is well served by 20th Century Fox's popcorny but respectful update, a sturdy, entertaining sci-fi actioner.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A flimsy blues-oriented Moulin Rouge with a touch of Chinatown-style public corruption thrown in.
Like Anderson's other work, this is light comedy (albeit comedy that flirts with an appealing ridiculousness) that carries with it a satisfying intelligence.
The question isn't whether these masterpieces hold up. It's whether 3 hours of brilliance - the approximate running time of the double feature - is too much of a good thing.
As fun as it is, it never makes a convincing case for its own existence. "Here's a cool band," Jimeno seems to be saying - and that's the extent of it.
A touch slight by Disney standards, but even if it's not high art, it's still warm-and-fuzzy fun.
Crude has all the hallmarks of a John Grisham story - sharp lawyers, raw greed, Big Business behaving badly. The difference is that this David-vs.-Goliath story is no work of fiction.

Beneath all the expected liberal, mad-as-hell indignation, the guy with the closet full of ill-fitting ball caps also happens to be persuasive as hell, crafting an entertaining and provocative call to arms.
A feel-good, if formulaic, dramatic comedy set in the full-contact world of roller derby and boasting a very Drew Barrymore blend of good humor and punky femininity.
An unabashedly violent and hilariously twisted zomb-pocalyptic romp, it's easily the most fun you're bound to have with a cast of corpses this side of Shaun of the Dead.
Mirthless and deliberately paced, there's still enough in the well-acted Lorna's Silence to make it worth listening to.
(N)oodles of good, goofy, family-friendly fun.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: One of the more absorbing and riveting portraits of The Troubles since 1993's In the Name of the Father.
With that singularly British way of being clever and deliriously juvenile all at once, it's a scathing, laugh-out-loud bit of big-screen satire.
While 9 boasts gorgeous images, it runs out of story all too quickly.
The Curious Case of Benjamin Button is the total package, a deftly assembled fairy tale that unspools like a pleasant dream.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: 2008's Oscar-winning foreign film is unquestionably good, a wholly absorbing and taut drama that is as engaging as it is powerful. But Oscar-worthy? There's room for debate.
This is a film that couldn't buy a positive female character if there was a barrel full on clearance at Bloomies.
We've done the whole classless college comedy thing before, many times.
A stylish and satisfyingly intense update of one of Hollywood's most well-trodden film concepts: the attack of the 150-foot (give or take) monster.
What charm CJ7 has is of the Saturday-morning variety, built upon a tiresome mixture of slapstick humor and comic-book action.
Even if it isn't as singular -- or as memorable -- as its title might suggest, it's sweet enough and soft enough around the edges to make it a diverting little road trip.
A dull retread. ... Not even the film's easily enchanted target audience -- that is, children -- are likely to stay under the spell for long.
It doesn't exactly come off as boxed wine to the top-shelf sensibilities of Sideways, but there's not enough story or heart for it to capture the same lightning in a bottle.
Lumet proves he's still a master storyteller, and Philip Seymour Hoffman is fantastic.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A unique and entertaining blend of anthropology and cinema.
If The Hurt Locker doesn't break the curse of the low-performing Iraq war movie then nothing likely will, at least not anytime soon.
You're probably not going to like what you see here, but you'd better hold your nose and choke it down anyway. Food, Inc. is for your own good.
The ugly truth about the eager-to-please The Ugly Truth is that Katherine Heigl and Gerard Butler are all wrong for each other -- and all wrong for this disappointingly ordinary film.
A wonderfully weird film, a modern-day Alice in Wonderland that marries technology and good old-fashioned storytelling.
What Somers Town lacks in story arc, it makes up for in charm, as Meadows and company create an endearing and thoroughly enjoyable portrait of a young British bromance.
Even with that uninspired title, Anita O'Day: The Life of a Jazz Singer is a fitting tribute, a fascinating and swinging documentary.
movie_title: Anita O'Day: The Life of a Jazz Singer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: [Director David] Yates' film makes for a splendid continuation of Rowling's saga -- carrying over ... the same stirringly magical spirit, the same enchanting visuals from Order of the Phoenix.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A mostly hollow experiment, built upon a thoroughly artificial vibe, that never really connects.
Not only does it fail to advance the franchise's overarching storyline (a better title: Terminator Stagnation) but it never distinguishes itself from any other reasonably budgeted action film.
[Sam] Raimi returns to the horror game with a film boasting a satisfying originality -- a device too often missing from the horror-film toolbox -- and wicked, depraved wit.
A meaningful though patient drama built upon beautiful shots, a gentle humor and a great performance from Pavel Liska.
Every character encountered is cookie-cutter, every romance predictable, every punch line older than Richard Dreyfuss' Yoda-like character looks.
Sugar is a refined and appealing love letter to baseball, and a reminder of all that makes it matter.
It does almost everything well, from the direction to the performances. But it does nothing great, dragged down by an uninspired, and oddly uninspiring, script.
Even with its ironic lack of imagination, Imagine That ends up being redeemed by a handful of wonderfully sweet moments.
Three Monkeys proves again that [Nuri Bilge] Ceylan has the eye of an artist, with a soul to match. If only his storytelling skills were equally represented.
A recent headline declared that [Jessica] Biel "is still trying to prove she's more than a pretty face." After Easy Virtue, she's still got something to prove.
A heartwarming -- and at times heartbreaking -- post-"Juno" road comedy for grownups.
Six-and-a-half years after Hollywood left the Enterprise crew for dead, ... Kirk is back, baby, and he's better than ever.
It is classless, it is tasteless, it is idiotic, it is juvenile and it is something your mother totally wouldn't approve of. But it also is flat-out hilarious.
Bullock and Reynolds ... end up elevating The Proposal, turning something old into something (almost) new, something borrowed into something cute.
It is among [Pixar's] most emotional pictures, a heartfelt, high-altitude exploration of love and loss and letting go.
Director Tony Scott pushes all the right buttons, crafting a worthy -- and in many ways, a superior -- update.

Whatever Works doesn't have the exotic flair of last year's Oscar-winning Vicky Cristina Barcelona, but what it lacks in sexy accents and pretension, it makes up for in sheer laughability and entertainment value.
Unlike [Michelle] Pfeiffer, the script for Cheri has a tendency to sag noticeably here and there. She manages to pull the most out of it, however.
With the sci-fi genre descending to disappointing new CG-assisted lows this summer (yes, I'm talking to you, Michael Bay), Moon ... is a perfectly timed little space oddity.
A pleasantly uplifting film, one built upon hope and the strength of the human spirit.
On paper, it sounds like a delight. In practice, though, Ruby Sparks -- which boasts only the occasional twinkle -- mostly just fizzles.
Punk's Not Dead is more than a nostalgia trip. Rather than just capturing what punk sounds like, Dynner shows us what it feels like, what punk really means -- present tense.
The beyond-goofy collection of Commandment-inspired vignettes has funny moments, but it's a wildly uneven anthology, with three or four clunkers for every genuine chuckle.
Though it boasts a noteworthy cast, the film suffers from clunky computer animation that appears to be hinged on technology at least several years behind the curve.
Though his direction is unsurprisingly beautiful, the settings lush and the performances wonderful, no one apparently had the guts to insist Lee streamline his rambling story.
A consistently amusing bit of animated whimsy from funnyman Jerry Seinfeld that has the observational comic's fingerprints all over it.
A family-friendly Adam Sandler movie that, even with its strained plot developments, is tame without being lame.
With a spot-on accent and altogether charming performance, Hathaway makes another convincing statement that she has grown, as a woman and as an actress.
Not so much a story about Jews and Arabs finding a way to get along as it is a nonpolitical story about people discovering the humanity in others, in all their scared, awkward beauty.

That documentary-like naturalism might be a bit much for some viewers, but Baghead is still an intriguing film, as the Duplass brothers construct genuine suspense while toying with their audience's expectations.
Fey and Pohler are an appealing pair, with Fey's wry, deadpan delivery a perfect complement to Poehler's fearlessly juvenile brand of humor.
It's not a film for the impatient -- no guns, no chases, no explosions. What it does have is beautiful cinematography and a thoroughly positive vibe.
movie_title: Bab'Aziz: The Prince Who Contemplated His Own Soul (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Dedicated theater rats might enjoy it, but it's too one-dimensional to qualify as a singular sensation.

It's the film's freshness -- with an original story, told in Blomkamp's unique storytelling voice -- that most defines District 9, injecting it with a feel of game-changing importance that elevates it above normal summertime fare.
A predictable actioner built on big booms, a few one-liners and a major assist from CG department, there are few surprises, few nuances, very little reasoning -- and some distractingly bad acting.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Meryl Streep is yeast that makes this light comedy rise.
A warm-and-cozy romantic stroll built upon the Everyman appeal of Joseph Gordon-Levitt and the refreshingly original storytelling approach of director Marc Webb.
A heartwarming fairy-tale that is undeniably sweet, even if it occasionally crosses over into sappiness.
Frustratingly uneven, struggling to maintain momentum as it lurches through extended lulls and indulges in cliched genre affectations.
It's a well-meaning film, marked by Luke Ford's sensitive portrayal of a disabled character. But the main character is bland, imparting the same vibe on the rest of the film.
A dusty, old-fashioned Western with a dusty, old-fashioned vibe. You can all but smell the saddle soap as the story unfolds.
An intriguing look -- alternately funny and heartbreaking -- inside the heads of today's teens.
If Adventureland was an amusement park ride, it would be the Ferris wheel. Both are amusing but tame, alluring but forgettable.
A lighthearted charmer, one of the most spirited and enjoyable comedies to hit ... theaters so far this year.
Even with its intriguing, sci-fi-ish setup Knowing finds a way of consistently striking all the wrong notes.

The problem isn't so much in the film's clumsy, hand-holding narration, or in its forced quirkiness. Rather it's that its most interesting character -- the one they named the thing after -- isn't the main character.
If nothing else, Watchmen is a commendable feat of art direction. As far as finding a narrative rhythm, however, the film could have stood a little rescuing itself.
Fifty years have elapsed since 3:10 to Yuma last pulled into the station, but, man, the return trip is worth the wait.
Scrapping many of the undead cliches and aided by troublingly realistic special effects, Slade has crafted one hell of a monster movie.
It's a slick enough movie, with an intriguing enough concept. It would be a much more enjoyable movie, however, if the wheels didn't come off script-wise.
It often feels a touch aimless, wandering about without much of a plot to rely upon. But in the end, 2 Days in Paris manages to be a pleasant enough diversion.
17 Again manages to squeeze more than a little life from the old "switch-movie" trope, along the way transforming itself into a sweet and amusing comedy.

A good, old-fashioned horror flick, one that relies on supernatural chills, psychological twists and top-shelf special effects -- as opposed to the recent trend toward ball gags, bound wrists and bad lighting.
With all the nuance of a fist to the groin, ... (it's) the kind of forgettable film that isn't impossible to enjoy but that only a Cena fan could truly love.
Brace yourself for a mammoth disappointment.
Is mediocrity a sin? If it is, then Ron Howard and Tom Hanks should start the novenas now, because they're going to catch holy heck the next time they go to confession.
This uncommon story about an uncommon man is gentle, it is patient, it is compassionate and -- from a technical standpoint -- it is stunning.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: You want underwater scenes of staggering grace and beauty? You got it. You want scintillating narration? Well, you might be swimming in the wrong ocean where that's concerned.
movie_title: Dolphins and Whales 3D: Tribes of the Ocean (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An attention-getting bit of drama built on remarkable performances.
A well-acted and effective drama -- when writer-director Rodrigo Garcia allows it to move along./
The bad and the ugly are both covered, with a main character that has a scarred face and a deep desire for revenge. As for the good? That's more of a hit-or-miss proposition.
Another outing for Woody and the gang, another masterpiece for Pixar.
Riveting -- and important -- stuff.
Eclipse -- the third in the Twilight series -- is more than just corny. Eclipse is boring. It's exceedingly boring.
It's a promising start for director Tze Chun, but despite the film's charms, the story doesn't get interesting enough early enough.
The film's few soapy moments and the plot's investigational contrivances are easily offset by the fine acting and storytelling -- as well as unexpected moments of humor.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: As funny as it often is, the longer it goes on, the more one gets the feeling that, aside from getting them to the Greek, Stoller had no real idea where he was taking his characters.
It's way too long, and its slavish adherence to the original plot saps it of suspense, but - suprisingly - it's something of a kick, thanks to the charm of Chan and Smith.

It tops the list of video game-inspired movies -- which isn't saying much -- but it's also a surprisingly entertaining movie on its own, a strap-yourself-in,suspend-your-disbelief summer popcorn adventure.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the venemous SATC backlash, and despite the extreme vapidity on display, it's a reasonably fun romp that fans of the series will certainly enjoy.
All the edge, all the wit, all the refreshing originality that made the earlier films in the franchise so enjoyable have been all but drained from the swamp this go round.
Fans, being fans, will appreciate the rare footage and the chance to hang with the band one more time. Unfortunately, there's very little by way of real revelation here.
Colorful and imaginative, it's a visual treat. Where the story comes in, however, it loses it's footing.
At its best moments, it's extraordinarily ordinary, and you don't have to be Goldilocks to know that ordinary is never just right.

Imagine Pirates of the Caribbean without Johnny Depp, and you've got an idea of the flavor of Robin Hood: grand scope, engrossing period action and performances that are appealing -- but just shy of indelible.

With its beautiful images and its overwhelming gravitas, it feels like a movie with a message. Unfortunately, on the way to delivering that message, it becomes weighted down by its own dreary self-importance.
A beautiful and entirely embraceable bit of cinema, and a welcome break from the pablum normally served up at theaters this time of year.
There's a nagging, one-sided feel to this unapologetic bit of activist filmmaking, but that doesn't make the story any less compellilng, or the film any less enraging.
As strong as its production values are -- and as good as Giovanna Mezzogiorno's performance is -- Vincere is an uneven melodrama.
Starts out as a comedy, transforms into a quirky Agatha Christie whodunnit and finishes with an unpredictable Hitchcockian flourish.
A tremendously moving drama, filled with heartbreak, humor and, most importantly, humanity.
Built in the Hollywood tradition, it's a dark and relentless thriller, and one of the most engaging and accessible foreign films to come along since Tell No One.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It is ambitious, it is gripping and it is dark. It's also entirely irresistible cinema, an uncompromising and hard-to-turn-away-from nightmare in three acts.
With its muted colors but unmuted violence, it's similar texturally to David Fincher's superb Zodiac, about another 70s serial killer. It's also just as disturbing.
Unrolling at a frustratingly slow pace, it's the weak link in the series, but it's still an extraordinary -- and extraordinarily well-assembled -- series.
Kristen Stewart and Dakota Fanning power the film through its lulls by the sheer force of their performances.
Singular for the way it takes audiences where they never would have otherwise visited: the living rooms of the eccentric and effortlessly hilarious filmmaking Kuchar brothers.
Like the overall trilogy, it's as haunting as it is riveting, the kind of movie that will keep your attention while it's playing, and stick with you after the closing credits.
A well-written, well-acted dramatic comedy that is light on plot but generous in spirit.
In its first feature, Illumination proves to be a double threat: an animation house that knows how to tell a story and one that also has the technical proficiency to make it dazzle the eye.
It's a hit-or-miss affair, the kind of character study that shows flashes of promise between its narrative lulls. Thanks to its talented young actors, however, it's more hit than miss.
Too much eye candy and not enough heart has this bit of blockbuster bait fizzling into frustrating forgettability after its promising, and at times dazzling, start.
This is not a movie with much use for nuance. This is a movie with something to say -- and it says it. Over, and over and over again.
movie_title: Salt of This Sea (Milh Hadha al-Bahr) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: While directors Shari Springer Berman and Robert Pulcini are busy tipping their caps to their favorite literary figures, they seem to forget their obligation to good movie-making.
(Although it) lacks the emotional wallop of Gone Baby Gone, it is an exceedingly well-assembled genre picture, a spell-binding, edge-of-your-seat thriller.
A movie that charms its way to being the kind of well-crafted teen touchstone that very well could become to today's generation what Ferris Bueller was to teens of the '80s.
Clarkson not only anchors Nadda's film, but she lifts it up onto her shoulders, carrying it along and helping it become an emotional and thoughtful story of one woman's journey of self-discovery.
It's edgy, it's funny, it revels in doing things its own way -- but it's also smart, offering an edifying inside peek into an industry that doesn't always welcome outsiders.
When I left the theater, I was exhausted and freaked out and totally bejeezus-less.
A wonderfully constructed and beautifully acted fable that serves as a reminder of how much of a treasure Robert Duvall is.
A slumberous, glacially paced bore -- with George Clooney on the poster
What it lacks in style, it more than makes up for in substance, as Shearer -- as smart as he is funny -- has assembled a vital and admirably accessible post-mortem on Hurricane Katrina.
(This) funny-but-forgettable movie loses its way somewhere between stowing the carry-on and returning the tray tables to the locked position.
A remarkable piece of documentary cinema. Not only does it do Pfc. Restrepo proud, but it brings home the fog of war more powerfully than any other movie in recent memory.
Despite the predictability, the stereotypes and the occasionally overly sentimental moment, it's fun. Honestly, if that's all you get from a movie like this, well, we have a winner.
Nanny McPhee shows up, she says, when she is needed but not wanted. As soon as she is wanted but not needed, she must go. So what does she do when you don't care one way or the other?
It lures you in with a promise of being a smart, zeitgeist-y satire, but before it can deliver on that promise, it morphs into something more resembling a soap opera.
It's beautifully shot and acted, but as with Coco Before Chanel last year, the one thing audiences will most want to know goes unanswered again: What makes this remarkable woman tick?

Given the similarities between the two films -- the muddled fight scenes, the occasional one-liners, the over-the-top violence, used to camouflage the narrative weaknesses -- this easily could have been titled Rambo V.
It's as if Wright took equal parts video game culture, comic book culture and rock 'n' roll culture, and threw it all into one giant pop culture blender. In a good way.
Boon's lovely, embraceable performance is perfectly twinned with Jeunet's deft, artful direction. The result is playful and oddly affecting, a Rube Goldberg contraption of a film.
Even if the genuinely funny punch lines grow thinner the longer the movie goes, The Other Guys functions as a pitch-perfect spoof of the buddy-cop genre.
The street artist known as Banksy is witty, he's smart, he's subversive -- and he's compelling. So it stands to reason that the street-art doc he ostensibly hijacked would be all those things, too.
Armed with a handful of deftly drawn characters and an occasionally wicked sense of humor, Cholodenko has created a thoroughly and unmistakably modern film.

These aren't the kind of laughs that will add points to your IQ. You may actually lose a couple by the time it's all over. But that's OK, because the goofy Dinner for Schmucks doesn't require much brain strain to appreciate.
If Norma Rae and Ferris Bueller's Day Off had a child, you've got to think it would probably be a lot like The Trotsky, a smart - if overlong - indie teen comedy.
A spare but riveting drama built around a raw, revelatory performance from Jennifer Lewis, it is one of the best movies to land in theaters to this point this year. By far.
A highly produced but poorly written rogue-spy thriller featuring an intriguing main character that deserves a better script than this.
Stone can try all he wants to restyle himself as a larger-than-life neo-journalist, but it will take more than clipping a pen to his shirtfront to mitigate the absurdity of that notion.
The message is muddy, but that doesn't feel as important as the delivery method, which ends up redeeming this as a film experiment that succeeds for its sense of derring-do if nothing else.
It is funny, it is heartfelt, it is nicely written, beautifully acted -- and it is the Duplass brothers' most mature, most complete film yet.

An at-times dizzying Mobius strip of a sci-fi thriller, it's both a tremendously challenging and tremendously rewarding movie, the type that will have audiences talking -- and debating -- long after the credits roll.
I've got a fourth verb to add to the comma-challenged title of Julia Roberts' how-to-be-happy travelogue, Eat Pray Love. How about "edit"?
Think GoodFellas, but with Gauloises and accent aigu instead of plates of spaghetti and accent Pesci.
As well-acted and sporadically charming as Greenberg is, Baumbach's consumption with misery keeps Stiller's character, and the film named for him, from being likable.
It's neither a good movie nor a bad movie. It's just a movie.
Curtis' crew, although piloting a fairly flimsy vessel, plot-wise, sure knows how to have fun, armed as they are with one of the most memorable classic-rock sound tracks this side of Forrest Gump.
There's a whole world of destruction going on in the film's ridiculously excessive special-effects sequences. But there's a whole lot of entertaining going on, too.
A remarkably intimate and nearly meditative cinematic experience, as Wiseman all but embeds his audience with the ballet.
movie_title: La Danse -- Le Ballet de l'Opera de Paris (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Not only is Invictus a well-acted, well-directed story of a remarkable man, but it also illustrates how sports can be a salve to a wounded community.
Moments of light laughter fueled by Broken Lizard's non sequitur brand of shock humor are served with a flimsy plot and even flimsier characters.
A depraved, perfect storm of cinema.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Warm and cozy, break-out-in-song entertainment, built upon beautiful artwork - the French Quarter scenes positively glow - and a toe-tapping collection of Big Easy music.
A better title: "Coco Before She Was Interesting."
The only thing missing from the film -- which is frequently amusing but too bleak to be consistently laugh-out-loud funny -- is a genuine connection with its audience.
A strikingly animated and thoroughly magical 3-D adaptation... that, counter to so many other versions, beautifully captures the darkly intense vibe of Dickens' ghost story.
A joyous homage to Jackson's music and peerless dance moves. It's the way Jackson would have wanted to be remembered, and the way his fans will want to remember him.
It makes the most of its on-the-field drama, but it tends toward gross generalizations and oversentimentality. ... As a result, the film is burdened with hokiness.
Although a sporadically stimulating and thoroughly challenging exercise, Examined Life too often feels like a forum for brainy big-thinkers' annoying penchant for being as inscrutable as possible.
Given its stellar cast -- including Vanessa Redgrave, Meryl Streep and Glenn Close -- and source material, it's hard not to think it should be better.
An earnestly acted film with a movie-of-the-week vibe, it's watchable but too slow-moving -- and far too predictable -- to be entirely engaging.
The Bruce Almighty spinoff gets a touch preachy and saccharine at times, but it's still fun and funny enough to work as a nice, family-friendly diversion.
As much as for what it says, the film is important for how it says it, in a manner that is easy to understand and hard to ignore.
There are moments when the story sags, as it postures and revels in its own eloquence, but with strong performances and a moving final act, this is still a fine, thought-provoking film.
A beautiful mix of humor, heart and spectacle that puts the studio that invented the True-Life Adventure back in touch with its wild side.
Even if the frequently low-key plot suffers from the occasional sleepy stretch, Mortensen turns in a magnificent performance.
The Boys are bound to seem a rather boring bunch, which makes it hard for Scott Hicks' downbeat heart-tugger to resonate in any meaningful way.
Music lovers will find a lot to like in It Might Get Loud, and musicians will positively love it.
A stealthily powerful drama ... highlighted by a beautiful score and strong performances.
Even if the Yes Men don't exactly fix the world in their documentary, they certainly give it something to think about.
movie_title: The Yes Men Fix the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Steeped in relentless (and often clumsy) symbolism, and hamstrung by a frustratingly disjointed narrative, it's puzzling for all the wrong reasons.
A gripping, powerful and heart-wrenching expose ... activist filmmaking at its best.
A near-perfect live-action adaptation ... Where the Wild Things Are is a brilliantly conceived and artfully realized translation of Sendak's beloved story.
The latest installment in pop-culture's vampire obsession - a lightweight, sequel-minded fantasy - is a mostly gore-free, adventure-driven bit of "Twilight" counter-programming.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The Duchess doesn't pretend to be anything other than what it is: a comfortable, low-calorie morsel of historical drama.
Hollywood has finally found the key to bringing a Seuss story satisfactorily to life.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Disney offers a delightfully affectionate, and surprisingly entertaining, parody of its own traditions.
It feels as if everybody's just trying a little too hard to be epic.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: In a film marked by strong performances Carey Mulligan is a show-stealer, with a career-making performance that relies as much on charm as on acting ability.
There's potential there for cloying, movie-of-the-week formula, but Hancock deftly dodges it. The Blind Side ends up being a tear-jerker, a heart-warmer and a crowd-pleaser all in one.
This is a movie whose sole purpose is to make people laugh. The really funny thing? Despite that ridiculous title and ridiculous setup, it often succeeds.
Puts a fresh spin on an important chapter in American history.
The true measure of Freudenthal's film is that it's the rare kid's flick that their parents won't have to merely tolerate. Rather, they will enjoy it, too.
It is a striking-looking film, and Haneke expertly builds suspense. And yet it feels overlong and never generates the warmth needed to keep audiences involved.
The Bounty Hunter works as a just-fun-enough action-comedy that is exactly the movie you think it is.
Despite being as predictable and derivative as a wedding singer's playlist, there's just enough sweetness, and just enough smiles, to keep it from falling flat.
It's got good acting, and moments of great intensity but Fuqua's overly episodic film feels like three marginally related stories rather than one cohesive tale.
A sumptuous, bar-raising cinematic portmanteau that both honors and complements the source material.
Much more accessible than you'd expect from a movie about Leo Tolstoy, this is a film built around the performances of Helen Mirren and Christopher Plummer.
It accomplishes what it sets out to do. That is, it puts a smile on your face and leaves you reaching for the hand of your significant other.
I'll give it a star and a half -- but only because I'm too professional to give it a full moon.
An impressive debut from director Scott Cooper, but it wouldn't be the movie it is without Jeff Bridges' astonishingly credible performance.
Imagine Norman Rockwell had he been more of a realist than a nostalgist.
After 7.5 years in which his only starring role involved a drunken traffic stop, Mel Gibson returns -- and he's the same old Mel. (Emphasis on the word "old.")
A glimmer of hope -- along with a raft of remarkably believable performances and moments of well-timed, tension-relieving humor -- transforms Precious into an enormously affecting film.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's a good thing Christian McKay delivers such an eerily accurate performance as Welles, because as pleasant as Linklater's shrug of a film is, it's built on a flimsy plot.
A beautifully simple, and entirely universal, story about appreciating the little things in life. Colin Firth is magnificent.
A full package period romance, from the performances to the costumes to the lush setting and the rich score.
A fun and sweet romantic comedy that lands comfortably on the smart side of vacant, along the way offering a pleasant and satisfying diversion for the grown-ups in the room.
Elementary, my dear -- as in, that's what Ritchie's spirited but superficial version of Arthur Conan Doyle's iconic detective ends up being.
A sensitive and compelling portrait of the lengths one family is willing to go -- specifically, to the wilds of Mongolia -- to reach their autistic child.
Pleasant but tiringly formulaic, it is saved by the presence of the effervescent Amy Adams.
There's a fine line that separates fantastical from nonsensical. Too often, Gilliam's film comes down on the wrong side.
This is film clearly made by people who remember all to well what it was like to be a teenager throbbing with hormones.
A smart and meaningful comedy for grown-ups, easily one of the best films of the year. ... It's so sophisticated and enjoyable it should come in a martini glass.
Not even the clumsy title bears any evidence of inspiration, which actually makes it a nice fit for writer-director Marc Lawrence's dud of a script.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Movie-goers heading to see the romantic comedy Four Christmases might want comedy, Christmas cheer and chemistry, but nobody gets everything on his wish list.
A low-fi road film with an improvised, DIY feel, it at times gives into tedium-induced lulls, but it's built around such an endearing character it's difficult not to be charmed by it.
"Fantastic" might be a touch hyperbolic in describing director Wes Anderson's stop-motion adaptation of Roald Dahl's The Fantastic Mr. Fox, but only by a whisker.
Amreeka is only one of a number of recent immigrant tales to hit theaters, but with its blend of sweet humor and topical relevance, it's one of the more compelling -- and surprising -- in some time.
A cliche-ridden exercise that never exhibits any real heart and focuses on characters who never come alive, it also never comes close to living up to the promise of the names in the credits.
An intriguingly original and attractively shot whodunit that blends a sense of Marilyn Monroe-infused sadness into the mix.
After a promising start, it fritters away any emotional connection with its audience early on, becoming a cold, meandering and tiresome exercise.
The folks at Laika seem to be making an art form out of good-naturedly scaring the Underoos off of pint-sized viewers while simultaneously delighting their parents.
It's just plain less -- less than what sci-fi fans are probably hoping for, and less than what it could have been.
It's hard to imagine another film coming closer to truly explaining the tragic enigma that was Amy Winehouse.
On paper, there's no reason this film should work. But these Minions, they work in mysterious ways. As a result, the uneven but entirely genial Minions does, too.
Brice seems more interested in keeping viewers guessing than in crafting a meaningful story. While that makes his film unpredictable, it comes at the cost of emotional impact.

His well-honed acting chops aside, a big reason the casting of Downey as Stark works so darn well is that incorrigible streak, which he somehow always has been able to balance with an irrepressible likability and which he uses to full effect here.
It took 22 years, and it took three tries, but Hollywood has finally hatched a worthy sequel to Steven Spielberg's groundbreaking and spine-tingling Jurassic Park.
A funny and wholly entertaining romp filled with McCarthy-driven laughs that exceed any expectations generated by that inexplicably empty title.
Somewhere on its way to becoming a live-action Disney classic, Bird's well-crafted illusion flickers and fades, a casualty of faulty storytelling.
While lacking when it comes to nuance, Niccol's film becomes a searing and finely tuned indie drama that benefits from a voice rooted firmly in the now.
While it might not exactly be pitch-perfect, this funny and tuneful slice of easygoing entertainment will be pitch-good-enough for fans of the first film.
Vinterberg's film offers something rare for an adaptation of a 141-year-old work of literature: It delivers a dose of modern relevance -- and thus resonance.
Every bit as warm and kind-hearted as the man whose story it tells.
movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A well intended but scattered dramatic comedy built around the performance of the likeable Jack Black in an very unlikeable role.
Built on a foundation of surprises, it's a zombie film starring Arnold Schwarzenegger -- but it's not like most other zombie movies or Schwarzenegger movies you've seen.
An enjoyable, full-sensory superhero romp, it delivers no less than what one would expect from an Avengers film. At the same time, it delivers no more than that,either.
Honestly, it's difficult to fathom how a filmmaker can, on one hand, so capably handle his film's faith elements but so mishandle others.
Beautifully shot and wonderfully acted, it's an enjoyable, grown-up entertainment, even if it leaves us wanting something deeper.
A bleak but very well realized portrait of hopelessness and despair in modern Russia.
It pretty closely follows the Disneynature formula, so don't expect anything groundbreaking. You can, however, expect a sweet and entirely enjoyable all-ages delight.
A bizarre and at times downright creepy story that functions well as a good yarn but also for its exploration of the often-blurred boundary between truth and fiction.
While it doesn't do anything glaringly wrong, neither does it do much to distinguish itself, or to warrant recommending it to anyone outside of the Glee fan community.
A smart charmer of a comedy that feels as personal as it does universal -- at least for those coming to grips with the fact that they now require reading glasses.
As long as you're willing to buckle your seat belt, disengage your brain and just go along for the ride, there's also no small amount of fun to be had.
Wendy and Lucy -- with its simple shots and edits and an elegantly musicless soundtrack -- proves you don't have to be flashy to be compelling.
Despite that title -- and the debt owed to 1970s cinema, most glaringly in the film's creepy techno-organ score -- It Follows largely charts its own path.
Expect over-the-top idiocy. Expect graphic sexual gags. Expect a lesson on the prison art of 'keistering.' And, yes, expect lots of dicey racial humor.
A fast-moving, fascinating and at times even fun documentary residing squarely at the intersection of sports and geopolitical history.
It is set in, as Bruce Willis' mogul character describes it, "a utopian paradise where you can have and do anything you want." Unless, that is, you want a decent movie.
With its blend of sweetness, silliness and tunefullness, this animated Disney short is satisfyingly consistent in vision and in spirit with the original Frozen.
Despite its formulaic underpinnings, Schumer makes it feel fresh with her comic writing, her comic timing and her ability to make us care for her trainwreck of a character.
Ant-Man is a load of a fun, a light-hearted superhero heist film with a sense of humor and playfulness that will make you forget just how silly the whole thing is.
Ian McKellen turns in a deft and nuanced performance -- two of them, actually -- that are consistently mesmerizing, even when the story threatens to wander off course.
A just-for-fun and mostly benign all-ages romp that doubles as a giddy tip of the cap to those who remember pumping quarter after quarter into coin-op arcade games.
As good as Michael Fassbender is in the lead role, the real star is Aaron Sorkin's smart, thrillingly unconventional script.
While wholesome in its own macabre way, it is every bit as repetitive, predictable and tame as the book series. And all without the added benefit of getting kids to read.
More Cold War nuts-and-bolts than cloak-and-dagger, it's an old-fashioned entertainment that benefits greatly from the warmth of Tom Hanks.
A two-handed portrait of addiction, desperation and regret that both narratively and stylistically harks back to the gritty character plays of the 1960s and early 1970s.
I can't wait to show this movie to my daughter. Perhaps more importantly, I also can't wait to show it to my sons.
With great performances and a surprisingly brisk pace, Bahrani's thoroughly researched film -- part drama, part expose -- drips with a sense of nowness.
It's got an inspired setup, but then wastes it on a half-baked plot, a tepid sense of humor and a preoccupation with one-upping itself with its admittedly solid gore effects.
Where's a wooden stake when you need one?
It's a delight to see Tomlin doing once more what she's supposed to be doing: making us laugh with her sharp-tongued wit, while making us feel something deeper inside.
Intense, riveting and soaring on the type of jaw-dropping visuals one would expect from an IMAX documentary about Everest , it's an entirely immersive cinematic experience.
It might lack subtlety, but Clarkson and Kingsley's triple-threat senses of humor, intelligence and on-screen effortlessness help deliver a breezy, grown-up yarn.
With The Visit, Shyamalan (finally) gets back to what he does best: Using his own sixth sense to subvert audience expectations with a satisfyingly suspenseful yarn.
Hayden Christensen and Adrien Brody turn in solid performances, but this by-the-numbers exercise does little to distinguish itself from any number of better crime thrillers.

As much as Andersson wants to make his audience chuckle and think, it also feels like he wants to confound them, dragging them by the funny bone through an entertainingly bizarre but frustratingly cryptic landscape.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: With beautiful visuals and a sense of fun, director Kenneth Branagh has crafted a fetching, playful delight.
A film that breaks little new narrative ground but which nonetheless offers an enjoyable and handsomely photographed snapshot of the Irish experience
I'll add a message for Pixar's genius collective as a whole: Please don't stop stretching, reaching and pushing the boundaries of the art form.
Beneath all that genre eye candy, though, resides a smart and moving story that, after a somewhat slow-moving first hour, builds nicely to become an emotionally engaging drama.
Even if the pacing of Petzhold's low-key and at-times lull-prone story occasionally gets away from him, there's no denying the power in his tale.
As good as Segel and Eisenberg are, it rarely feels like more than two guys merely chatting about life as they chain-smoke cigarettes and gnaw on Twizzlers.
While Nourizadeh's just-for-fun head trip is no more ambitious than its long-haired pothead of a main character, it delivers on its sole goal: to entertain and to surprise.
A mesmerizing and intimate portrait of the actor/enigma that -- in true Brando from -- stands apart as a decidedly unconventional but undeniably magnetic study of celebrity.
While other, better superhero movies have a way of putting moviegoers in touch with their inner 10-year-old, Trank's film likely will appeal mostly to actual 10-year-olds.
More Cassandra's Dream than it is Midnight in Paris, it's an attractively shot shrug that isn't perfect but which in its best moment is perfectly enjoyable.
Searing, essential and unforgettable.
As attractively shot and as well-cast as it is, the gloomy, inert The Runner isn't a film that sprints or dashes. It merely chugs along steadily.
And there's Remy himself, voiced by irreverent comic Patton Oswalt. Yes, he's a rat, and a pantless one at that, but he's a charming rat.
The tone of Forbes' at-times surprisingly funny script and the latest fine performance from Mark Ruffalo combine for a sweet, compassionate look at mental illness.
It's a cinematic tightrope act, and it is to Slaboshpitsky's credit that he pulls it off.
When does great acting trump a formulaic story? When the actor is Jake Gyllenhaal and the story is the boxing melodrama Southpaw.
A pleasantly amusing whimsy that -- fueled by Baumbach's rapid-fire dialogue and the charm of Gerwig and co-star Lola Kirke -- treads occasionally into laugh-out-loud hilarity
It's familiar stuff but satisfying stuff, thanks largely to the performance of Cooper who brings enough texture to the role of Adam Jones to make his story interesting.
It's as sweet at the first but is too content to repeat itself. The result: a blend of amiability and aimlessness that helps it lives down to the "second best" in its title.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: As they did in I Love You Phillip Morris and Crazy, Stupid, Love, Ficarra and Requa prove to be masters of misdirection in this fluffy but fun romp.
Ayer's film does for tank warfare what Das Boot did for submarines and Saving Private Ryan did for D-Day.
A sturdy if uneven film that will leave audiences disillusioned -- and perhaps a bit horrified -- about truth, justice and what it contends is the real American way.
There's something haunting going on here -- in the story, in the performances, in the overall atmosphere -- that makes it hard to look away from, and equally hard to forget.
Knowing how it all will end doesn't sap much of the pleasure from this fun trifle of a film, one that parents and kids can enjoy side by side.
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The film belongs to three actors you've never heard of, but if putting Witherspoon's mug on the poster is what it takes to get people to go see it, then that's a good lie.

Even if As It Is in Heaven doesn't have the distinction of treading entirely untrodden ground, it does offer a compelling and engrossing take on the subject -- and from a fresh, up-and-coming filmmaking voice, to boot.
It's easy to overlook the narrative shortcomings and instead bask in the sheer artistry on display.
Watching it is like watching a slow-motion train wreck -- you know you should look away, but you can't help but watch to see the potentially horrifying results.
Derivative? Sure. But with Washington in the lead, it's also a heart-pumping, fist-pumping ride, a sort of Jason-Bourne-meets-Batman mashup that you can't help but root for.
Quirky and compelling are two different things, and the visually vibrant -- but wildly unevern -- Zero Theorem seems to be going out of its way to prove that.
Ball's film might be derivative, but it's also intense and entertaining enough to leave audiences hungry for the inevitable sequel so clearly set up by its cliffhanger ending.
Without Tom Hardy, it could have become just another crime drama. With him, though, it's something else entirely - something alive, tightly wound and irresistible.
It's weird, but in the most embraceable of ways, thanks to the presence of the always likeable Domhnall Gleeson and a more-vulnerable-than-you're-used-to Michael Fassbender.
It boasts big ideas that it wants us to mull over, but Folman's labyrinthine film doesn't so much discuss them in any cohesive way as much as it just points them out.
The Identical is a movie beset by odd choices from the very beginning, starting with its foundational concept.
What really sets it apart is its attention to visual detail. Not a single frame of film is wasted in a movie that could be appreciated even if the sound was turned down.
Earl Lynn Nelson is a force of nature as Mitch, a loud, boisterous scene-stealer who breathes comic life into this otherwise low-key road-trip dramedy.
They say it's not about football. That's ironic since the on-field scenes are the best thing about this melodramatic, oddly un-engaging sports drama.
It does a lot right, but ultimately it offers little to distinguish itself from countless like-minded stories.
It's billed as a black comedy, but at its root, Calvary wants to move you emotionally and still you as the closing credits soberly roll. It succeeds on both counts.
A masterpiece of independent filmmaking, Boyhood is nothing short of an emotional epic, one that is relatable and moving and entirely unforgettable.
Unfolding with a hyperactive but magnetic sense of momentum, Get on Up does, indeed, get on up, scene after scene.
A brainy intersection of science and faith, it's a movie that asks big questions. It's also, however, frustratingly short on any real answers.
It delivers just what you'd want from a summer blockbuster. It is fast, it is fun and it is all but assured of making a mint at the box office -- and spawning sequels aplenty.

The Whole Gritty City is both a celebratory film -- filled with fanfares and snares, concerts and parades -- and a very emotional one, an at-times heartbreaking portrait of our at-times heartbreaking city.
It is a great profile of, and tribute to, the man credited with democratizing movie criticism -- and, by extension, cinema itself -- in America. But it's also much more.
There's certainly a lot of information there, but it lacks a sense of fun, coming off instead as a staid and often padded affair.
It's the rare sequel that stands on its own as a film with an epic feel, a movie that is both exciting and laden with emotion - and one that takes the baton and runs with it.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It takes a lot to stand out in a cast that includes Aaron Paul and Juliette Lewis, but Josh Wiggins proves up to the task. It'll be fun to see where his career takes him next.
There's a fine line separating a film that puts its own spin on a proven formula and one that becomes a caricature of itself. The Best of Me treads all over that line.
Aside from its comic-book noir sensibilities, it offers little more than a collision of Hollywood cliches built around a contrived plot we've seen countless times before.
An astute and funny film built around an impressively layered script and an appealing ensemble cast that broaches the delicate issue of race in an honest, sensible way.
Beneath it all is a fairly conventional murder mystery. But the film's defining gimmick -- those curlicue horns -- help provide just enough newness to keep things moving.

Slumdog Millionaire is a lot of films -- it is a comedy, it is an adventure, it is a tragedy -- but more than anything it's a love story, and Boyle manages to nurse every ounce of emotion out of that aspect of the story without overplaying it.

As much as the film is about Bardem's even-keeled determination... it's also about Tommy Lee Jones' brilliantly characterized Texas sheriff, who, faced with a trail of blood like he's never seen, wonders if he's still a match for a changing world.
Julianne Moore isn't merely good in the lead role. She's devastatingly, heartbreakingly good, and she's a big reason why Still Alice is as moving as it is.
An intriguing relationship drama, one that is at times darkly funny, at others thought-provoking, but consistently piano-wire tense as it delivers an avalanche of emotion.
Another fine drama from writer-director J.C. Chandor, it is a smart, small-scale film but one with deceivingly big stakes.
Conventional Hollywood wisdom says one should be wary of any Hollywood thriller released in the first month or so of any year. Black Sea is an exception to that rule.
It might not be the Oscar contender it was once hailed as, but that doesn't mean it's not a solidly made film -- even a brave one, for its willingness to tackle touchy issues.
Aniston's performance stands to change the way many people look at her, with a deft, tempered turn that also could end up redefining her career.
Hard-pounding, compassionate and entirely captivating, it offers an insightful peek inside the pressure-cooker in which American service members operate.

In Miller's hands, a movie that could easily have become so much exploitative trash is instead a sharp study of two tragically lonely lives, of the pitfalls of privilege and, in its own way, of the American way of doing things.
Sharp, brisk and highly entertaining.
A stoner's delight that is part fever dream and part bad trip, Inherent Vice is a dark and wickedly wild neo-noir romp. But it's also a thing of unusual density and often incoherence.
It's OK for a movie to leave an audience asking questions. In fact, it can be a sign that a movie has a lot to say. Except, that is, when the question is this one: "So what?"
Despite its title, Tyldum's film isn't some imitator or wannabe. Rather, The Imitation Game, highlighted by a layered turn from Benedict Cumberbatch, is the real deal.
Beautifully shot and acted, it's one of Leigh's more enjoyable and accessible recent films, one that will appeal to more than the arthouse crowd normally drawn to his films.
Despite a few narrative snags, it is a sturdily crafted period piece. Along the way, Burton also delivers an impassioned justification of art in all of its forms.
Angelina Jolie shows a steady directoral hand in her second trip behind the camera, with a glossy and well-acted -- if conventionally told -- WWII saga.
With a great performance from Witherspoon and a soul-stirring, life-affirming message, this movie is a gift.
It's the movie you expect it to be: bloated from a story standpoint, but built around sweeping visuals and Peter Jackson's keen world-building imagination.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A mildly entertaining and mostly painless family film that provides spark plug Quvenzhane Wallis an extended opportunity to show off her star qualities.
Aimed squarely at children, but painless to keep grown-ups from checking their watches.
Jones and Swank are both in fine form in Jones' sobering and unsentimental -- but thoroughly engrossing -- anti-Western.
A smartly assembled film offering an on-the-ground look at the lingering fallout of the historic BP oil spill -- and at America's troubling relationship with Big Oil.
With no real beginning and no real ending, the unsatisfying Mockingjay Part 1 is essentially all middle -- one big, stretched out, watered-down second act.
Compelling, eye-opening -- and terrifying.
A riveting confluence of energy, passion and broken blisters that serves as a tribute to the obsessive pursuit of excellence at any cost.
As sweet as the story is -- and as charming as James Corden is in the lead role -- it's mostly a safe, forgettable film steeped in a by-the-numbers blandness.
A sweet, smart romantic comedy for grown-ups that quietly exceeds its grasp thanks to great casting and assured direction.
Big Hero 6 is nothing if not fun, a fast-paced fanboy fable that benefits greatly from a Pixar-informed blend of artistry and humor.
A smart, full-pull filmmaking masterpiece that soars simultaneously on a number of levels.
With its Grimm-flavored sets and richly designed costumes, this Disney adaptation boasts a visual grandness. But dramatically, much of the magic feels drained from it all.

Quantum of Solace is energetic enough and muscular enough to make you walk a little taller, a little more confidently, on your way back through the theater parking lot. But it's not a film that will stay with you much past that.
There's still a hint of the caveman about Daniel Craig's Bond, but it's countered by an emotional evolution that makes him the most interesting Bond in franchise history.
An emotional emotional roller coaster ride that is at turns touching, harrowing, crushing and flat-out beautiful.
Even with its overly complicated structure and scarcity of emotion, it's no exaggeration to call it a technical masterpiece, offering a stunning look at a key moment in WWII.
It might not transcend the friends-behaving-badly genre, but it does manage its share of naughty laughs and token emotion, all with New Orleans serving as a fetching backdrop.
While working inside the rigid confines of the Marvel blueprint, it manages to work equally well as a superhero movie and a teen comedy.
An elegant and efficient period thriller that, while perhaps not ringing with resonance, is still an engrossing and well-told yarn.
There's enough there to make young children and dullards laugh. But when all you've got comedically is the occasional flash of bare Minion booties, you've got problems.
A subtly innovative blend of cars, guns, music and old-school cool, it's also one of those increasingly rare creatures in Hollywood: an undeniably original movie.
Dumb-dumb. Dumb-dumb. Dumb-dumb-dumb-dumb-dumb-dumb-dumb-dumb-dumb-dumb-dumb-dumb...
Despite what the film's marketing says, it's not a horror film, and it doesn't function well as one. But it is a pretty darn good dark psychological thriller.
It's no small thing to leave viewers with unanswered questions but still making them satisfied they've gotten a full movie experience. Roger Michell does that here.
There's a Jekyll-and-Hyde dynamic at work here. While the movie at its core boasts a fun, fast-moving vibe, its awkward, franchise-serving midsection undermines much of that.
While it has its charms, it ultimately feels more 'something old' than it does 'something new.'
As much as anything, it's propelled by unflinching honesty, which helps it become a smart, surprising and funny study in grown-up emotion.
Without that backstory, it would be a fairly unremarkable, fairly familiar ride. But with it, and with a fine turn from Liev Schreiber, it scraps its way to respectability.
Above all, it's a very human story and a very well-told one -- which, in the end, makes it very hard to forget.
A tale of corruption and decay that thrums with an undercurrent of discomforting familiarity.
The wholesomeness and embraceable spirit will strike a chord with the sort of moviegoer drawn to such a film. But that doesn't mean it's as good as it could have been.
It moves along nicely, but it never feels rushed. Rather, it slows just enough for audiences to become seduced by the perilous beauty of the jungle -- just as Fawcett did.
As far as Tarantino facsimiles go, it's a solid one, blending violence, humor and style to good effect.
This is not a very good movie. In fact, it is a bad movie -- a very expensive, very highly produced and very predictable cinematic skid mark.
Evans and company inject a dose of charm that saves Gifted from its formulaic underpinnings. The results are enjoyable and, when it matters most, emotionally rewarding.
If The Lost Village were a Smurf, it wouldn't be Brainy. It would be Jokey, the one who gets his jollies with the same exploding-present prank over and over and over.
It zeroes in on a little-known chapter from the post-war era to spin an engaging and emotionally resonant story that, even after 70-plus years of WWII movies, feels fresh.
It shamelessly co-opts the Pixar aesthetic, but at least its working to imitate the best in the biz. The result: a sweet film with a reasonably satisfying emotional element.
Thank goodness for Shirley MacLaine. With anyone else in the lead role, this sweet but uneven indie would have likely buckled under the weight of its mounting contrivances.
Wilson is about a man desperate to connect with people emotionally. It's ironic then, that director Craig Johnson's often amusing movie fails to do just that.
It's got a great ensemble cast. It's got eye-popping visual effects. It's got a blend of non-stop action and well-timed humor. In short, it's just plain fun.
A sturdy historical drama that doubles as a love story and a surprisingly timely appeal for tolerance and understanding.
Easily the best entry in the sprawling X-Men franchise, and arguably the best superhero film since The Dark Knight offered a similar sense of refreshing thoughtfulness.
Without a word of dialog, it says more than most animated films could ever hope to.
Some movies are valuable because they provide answers. This one works because it asks tough questions, then leaves it up to the audience to do the heavy lifting.
A tense and satisfying genre exercise, it shows that 1) there's something to be said for a film that delivers on its promises and 2) don't mess with Halle Berry.
It has its share of horror tropes, but once it gets going, it's got a steady intensity that feels more akin to The Conjuring than the original Annabelle.
A fun and unpretentious romp that benefits from smart pacing, likeable characters and a stick-it-to-the-man undercurrent that helps keep things moving along.
You know that fine line separating "good" weird from just plain off-putting? Today, there are mouse-shaped footprints all over it.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A humorless sense of melodrama helps keep it from becoming unassailably fantastic as a whole, but there's no denying that it is fantastically timely, and touching to boot.
Adam DeVine's doofy charm helps, but it's not enough to save this Groundhog Day-ish exercise that works hard to put every romantic-comedy genre contrivance into play.
John Hughes died in 2009, but if he were alive today and still making movies, one has to think he would probably be making movies like Freak Show.
Hostiles is a very serious film, relentlessly grim and unapologetically grave. It also seems to want badly for people to recognize that it's serious, grim and grave. Like, really, really badly.
Think "Home Alone" meets "Straw Dogs" -- with a crazed Nicolas Cage thrown in -- and you've got an idea of the lunacy in store.
This is movie for its time, one that -- armed with an Oscar-rich cast and crew -- manages to deliver its messages without climbing onto a soapbox and lecturing.
Built on superb performances from Margot Robbie and Allison Janney, it's a warts-and-all portrait of Harding, but one that is also disarmingly sympathetic and revealing.
A wonderfully weird love story that plays like an adult fairy tale, it's a fantastical delight, one of those rare start-to-finish treats that succeeds on every level.
It's pure formula, but Kasdan and company fill in the blanks well in what ends up as a funny and highly entertaining pleasant surprise of a family adventure.
It scores on any number of technical levels, but it's Oldman's award-worthy performance as Churchill more than anything that proves to be the linchpin to the whole exercise.
Like the attraction in the film's title, the wheel turn but it rarely feels like anybody's really going anywhere.
Franco gets credit for focusing every bit as much on the artist as the disaster - and for taking something most saw as trash and spinning it into something close to treasure.
A taut and twisting bit of atmospheric suspense, it sinks its hooks into its audience early and keeps them on the line for the rest of its affecting and briskly paced story.
The Great Wall? The Totally Ridiculous Wall is more like it.
A meticulously shot and sharply written character study, it plays like a blend of the Coen brothers and Quentin Tarantino.
With a delightful lead performance from Ronan and a breezy script built on universal themes, it effortlessly takes wing to become an embraceable exploration of growing up.
A fascinating look at the most fascinating moment in what is arguably the most fascinating movie in the Hitchcock catalog.
While a bit of a slow-starter, when the dam bursts, it bursts, delivering a film that is both darkly comic and deadly serious -- and very weird. (That's a good thing.)
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Unlike Milne's Pooh stories, which are cuddly, effortless and embraceable, it is unwieldy and awkward. To borrow a phrase from a certain fluff-stuffed bear: Oh, bother.
It is at turns charming but unsettling, amusing but poignant, care-free but thought-provoking. But the real story here is Brooklynn Prince, a 6-year-old star in the making.
Sometimes it's stupid-funny, but mostly it's just plain stupid. And sloppy. And that won't matter one bit to fans of Tyler Perry's films.
movie_title: Tyler Perry's Boo 2! A Madea Halloween (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Thanks largely to the interplay of Boseman and Gad, it works, and probably better than it should, with its blend of drama, humor and -- best of all -- fist-pumping triumph.
A cocaine-fueled romp that plays like a lightweight blend of Goodfellas and Argo, it's entertaining stuff - as long as you don't expect it to stick to the facts.
While it threatens at time to lose its focus, its performances -- and its blend of history and humor -- make it a very enjoyable, and recommendable, film.
Like "Clerks" with a conscience.
A surprisingly thoughtful and beautifully shot film that doubles as both a history of and a love letter to the humble typewriter.
It's sweet enough, but sweetness goes only so far, especially when a movie has as messy and rambling a script as this one does.
On paper, it's familiar stuff. In practice, though -- and with Danielle Macdonald in the lead role -- it becomes an altogether sweet and amiable triumph.
An engaging journey to the dark side, thanks to Robert Pattinson's lead turn, which adds a layer of emotional resonance to what ends up an uncommonly intriguing crime drama.
We all know Denzel Washington is among the best in the business. We expect excellence from him. But that doesn't make it any less enjoyable when he delivers, as he does here.
It's an exceedingly dumb film, with its high body count, shockingly bloody violence and comic-book carnage. Still, there are guilty pleasures to be had.
You'll keep thinking, hoping even, that the sheer talent of the cast will take over and elevate things. But the joke's on you.
It is at once sobering and thoughtful - and, yes, uncomfortable, at times. But it's a necessary uncomfortable, the kind of uncomfortable we could use more of right now.
For a movie that makes the campfire scene in Blazing Saddles seem restrained, there's a surprising -- and satisfying -- level of emotion at work here.
Ross' well-intentioned film gets off to an intense and absorbing start, but halfway through he loses the grip on his story and it all becomes a unmoored, overreaching mess.
With a great cast, a sense of fun and no small amount of skillful misdirection, Now You See Me 2 has just enough tricks up its sleeve to overcome its flaws.
An uplifting, modern-day musical fairy tale that -- in addition to telling a crowd-pleasing story -- proves that dreams really, truly can come true.
It is weird, but it is also meaningful, emotional and unexpectedly hilarious. Best of all, it's a strikingly original film, a precious thing in homogenous Hollywood.
Hyperactive, insufferable, wonderless and -- oh, where's a good vorpal sword when you need one?
There's a really interesting, really fresh new Seth Rogen project arriving this week. It is not, however, titled Neighbors 2: Sorority Rising.
Despite a dense first half that might confound newcomers, it delivers all the humor and action that fans have come to expect -- as well as the finest Avengers fight scene yet.
Even if the foundation of Saulnier's film feels familiar and the plot trips itself up unecessarily, it is a thoroughly satisfying -- though thoroughly violent -- thrill ride.
With this cast, it could have raised the bar on its messy predecessor. Instead, this unintentionally fractured fairy tale is a mess -- a pretty mess, but a mess all the same.
It could have become, like so many other biopics, a narrative version of Davis' Wikipedia page. Instead, it becomes something striking and distinct -- and illuminating.
Favreau has crafted a movie that, contrary to the fears of Disney purists, in no way betrays Uncle Walt's vision. Rather, it honors it -- and even enhances it.
It isn't a perfect movie, but it is a rewarding one, thanks largely to its superb cast and its willingness to stray into thought-provoking territory.
If only the rest of the movie was on the level of Hiddleston's performance. Instead, I Saw the Light often feels as if it is built more on oversight than insight.
It might be derivative -- sort of a Toy Story with fur -- but there's a lot to like here: the humor, the heart, the artistry, the mercifully brisk 90-minute run time.
Part sequel, part prequel, director Zack Snyder's film delivers on its titular promises -- eventually.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: I would have said it was impossible to be both shameless and shameful at the same time. London Has Fallen proves me wrong.
Though conventional, Race does a decent job of re-creating the details of Owens' easy-to-root-for story. But it offers only a glimpse of who Owens really was as a man.
Profane, violent and deliciously depraved, it's one of the most start-to-finish enjoyable comic-book movie this side of 2008's original Iron Man.
True-blue Austen fans stand to get the most out of this guilty-pleasure exercise. Everyone else will likely find it tolerable, but not handsome enough to tempt them.
An imperfect but likeable crowd-pleaser, it's the sort of old-fashioned bit of storytelling one might expect from Disney. That proves to be both a good thing and a bad thing.
"A smartly realized and decidedly unforgettable study in the human condition, and one one of the more insightful films to hit screens in the past year."
For better and for worse, it's neither better nor worse than the original Ride Along. That's because it's essentially the same movie.
With a committed turn from Leonardo DiCaprio and beautiful technical elements, Inarritu gives us a film that is harsh, cruel and positively riveting.
At once compelling, compassionate and impossible to ignore.
The Hateful Eight is often deranged, consistently depraved and at-times despicable, but it is also 100 percent Tarantino-style guilty-pleasure entertainment.
Adam McKay might not be the most obvious choice to helm a financial dramedy, but the dude knows a thing or two about the absurd. That comes in handy in The Big Short.
Clearly the hope here, for the studio and fans, is that Sisters will be received as the next Bridesmaids or Trainwreck. They'll just have to keep hoping.
As much as anything, the contributions of that wonderful cast are the key to making Coming Home the emotionally absorbing film that it is.
With a scattered script but an appealing cast, it's more enjoyable than, say, your Nana's fruitcake -- though it's not the dose of memorable holiday cheer it could have been.
In stressing the point that there are no easy answers in war, it scores. In trying to say something insightful, however, something we don't already know, then not so much.
The Jackass guys are always amusing, but this isn't a movie. This is a DVD bonus feature masquerading as a movie.
It generates a reasonable smattering of off-color screwball laughs, but it is for the most part a conventional, surprise-free affair.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Die-hards might enjoy visiting with Edina and Patsy once more, but to everyone else, it won't quite live up to that title.
You know that adage about all that glitters? Consider "Gold" supporting evidence that it's true.
If anyone was hesitant to declare The Visit a sign that M. Night Shyamalan's pendulum career is back on the upswing, Split should do much to convince them.
Through storytelling skill, attention to detail and narrative momentum, Berg again takes a story well all know and makes it compelling, engaging and downright riveting.
It might not leave an award-season mark, but its blend of heart, humor and history should score where it counts the most: at the box office, and in the minds of young viewers.
It feels a touch slight in the homestretch, but its appealing cast and stellar production design help make it a sci-fi journey worth taking.
The sum total is no more filling than the popcorn you'll overpay for upon entering the theater. But, like that popcorn, Sing has empty-calorie, crowd-pleasing appeal.
Natalie Portman is sensational in what ends up as a powerful, intimate and award-worthy portrait of a very public grief.
A deft blend of long-gone filmmaking style with decidedly modern sensibilities, it's the kind of film you'll watch with a permanent smile plastered to your face.
Affleck's performance, equally haunting and electric, helps transform Lonergan's film from merely a dramatic showcase into an emotional powerhouse.
Visually and tonally, Miss Sloane -- like Chastain's one-note performance, in which she does little but bark and glower -- is slick but soulless.
It tells what many consider the greatest real-life boxing comebacks in history, but on-screen it rarely feels like anything but a run-of-the-mill fight picture.
For most of its two-hour running time, the predictable, unimaginative Almost Christmas is merely almost funny.
Even in its best moments, there's nothing flashy, nothing memorable and certainly nothing smart about this purely B-movie remake.
Aided by beautiful, stereotype-shattering performances and subtle but rich cinematography, it is something heartfelt, stirring and unforgettable.
From the very first scene, it is exactly what you'd expect, or want, a Ghostbusters movie to be: fun, scary and silly.
In his return to the big screen after a 10-year time out, Gibson gives us a slow-build to an extended rush of intensity, emotion and inspiration.
A well-executed but stubbornly formulaic crime thriller that telegraphs most of its major surprises long before they ever happen.
Not every joke hits the comedy sweet spot, but thanks to Hart's outsized personality, singular delivery and self-confident on-stage swagger, they all come reasonably close.
An easy-going gem that is at times funny, at times heartbreaking, at times scary -- but always, unfailingly engaging.
Berg strikes an unlikely but impressively delicate balance in a film that honors the victims of the disaster while also functioning as a brisk and absorbing disaster drama.
It might be short on revelations about the iconic band, but fans can expect a good laugh - and a good time - in a film that is, if nothing else, thoroughly entertaining.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: As well made as it is, it's still got that title, which is both blessing and curse in this case, as it does too little to distinguish itself from the 1960 classic.
An often funny and consistently endearing old-school romantic romp that serves up an unapologetically delightful bit of escapist distraction from reality.
A heart-rending, intensely personal portrait of lingering grief and the way a crime - whether iconic or not - forever transforms the lives of those left behind.
A diabolical little genre-defying tale that combines a dash of dark humor with a larger dose of just plain darkness.
movie_title: I Am Not a Serial Killer (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The result is an achingly authentic film, as stirring as it is relevant.
