Where the original was a goofy, campy bit of stylized storytelling, Lowery's becomes a nicely realized, feel-good love song to fantasy and magic.
Who's to say messy can't also be fun?
It boasts some nice cast additions (Alicia Vikander, Tommy Lee Jones, Vincent Cassel), but everything else about this emotionally vacant installment feels recycled.
A powerful and inspiring portrait of unbowed strength and courage in the face of great adversity. Must-see cinema for anyone in need of a psychic pick-me-up.
Howard keeps the pedal pressed firmly to the metal. If only he had taken time to glance in his rearview mirror, he might have noticed he's left much of his audience behind.
It's nothing if not derivative, feeling like E.T. meets Goonies meets the iPhone generation. But there are worse movies to be compared to than those two modern classics.
Though not without its flaws, it crackles with a timeliness and a now-ness that elevates it beyond mere entertainment and into the realm of subtle social commentary.
A thrillingly surrealist exercise, one that plays out like a dream -- sometimes like a nightmare -- as it relates Jodorowsky's semi-autobiographical, coming-of-age tale.
Part period drama, part courtroom drama and part sermon, it's a film that never gives itself much of a chance to hit its narrative stride.
An up-close and personal look at the psychology of war -- their war and, by extension, all war.
What this Die Hard copycat lacks in originality it makes up for in other areas, along the way becoming an entertaining and briskly paced throwback thriller.
There's a fine line separating 'unsettling' and 'off-putting,' and Park treads all over it. What we get is a film that is chilly in addition to be chilling.
It's a surprisingly effective and suspenseful thriller -- up until it's idiotic ending, when the characters and the audience are betrayed all at once.
Chilling and riveting, even if it feels as if there are many questions left unanswered.
A shrug of a film featuring unremarkable characters in an unremarkable story that never does more than limp toward it flat and flimsy third act.
As intriguing as the words "Tommy Lee Jones as Gen. MacArthur" sound, the acting is rote and the story slack in a film that makes a vital historical moment feel irrelevant.
This is one seriously ghoulish and messed-up movie. I realize that certain blood-thirsty moviegoers will consider that high praise. This film is for them. And only them.
It's nice to have all the twists and turns of the iconic case contained tidily in one well-crafted film, although there are no real revelations here.
A lovely family fantasy that pays fitting homage to the spirit of the original with a well-formed sense of magic, wonder and fun.
A barely passable, if unmemorable, bit of action-heavy entertainment -- as long as you don't think too hard about the script's eye-rollingly contrived setup.
Trying to become the next "Twilight," it is a better film in most respects than any entry in that franchise - although that's damning it with faint praise.
It knows exactly what kind of film it is -- unfortunately, what kind of film it is, is an unimaginatively directed coming-of-age tale with hardly any narrative momentum.
It's got a nice message and a strong cast, but both end up getting lost in the muddled storytelling.
A richly directed and historically credible film that -- with its sense of time and place -- ends up functioning as fascinating and poignant temporal travelogue.
A manic Melissa McCarthy does her darndest to save this overly familiar comedy. Alas, it isn't enough.
Lives up to its status as an annual Oscar-season treat.
movie_title: The Oscar Nominated Short Films 2013: Live Action (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Once again, chock-full of bite-sized gems.
movie_title: The Oscar Nominated Short Films 2013: Animation (2013)

movie_review_blurb: There's nothing wrong with tipping one's cap to one's influences, but in no case does this loud, crude and derivative film ever raise the bar. In fact, it actually lowers it.
Though sweet of demeanor, Dustin Hoffman's directoral debut is purely lightweight stuff, built around a flimsy plot and obvious choices every step of the way.
Mary Elizabeth Winstead comes into her own in this lightly directed and disarmingly enjoyable film, which delivers its message without the aid of a soapbox.
The script is clunky, the story is contrived -- but old pros Walken and Pacino are an absolute pleasure to watch working together.
A simple but emotionally laden slice-of-life drama that is at turns heartbreaking and hopeful.
A sumptuous slice of period drama and real-life palace intrigue.
It's an uneven but fairly enjoyable ride, one that benefits from Statham's cool, capable presence.
A hackneyed, from-the-streets Sundance drama that would be mostly forgettable if not for the performance of child actor Michael Rainey Jr.
There's really on one reason for "Mama" to exist, and that is to raise the hairs on the back of one's arm. And it does that -- repeatedly.
A twisting but talky political potboiler.
It does a lot of things well, but nothing extraordinarily. The end result is a solidly middle-of-the-road - and thus forgettable - bit of slapsticky animation.
This is a playtime movie, a bit of pre-adolescent wish fulfillment aimed squarely at 10-year-old boys.
It can boast of some truly extraordinary special effects, but this Evil Dead is far more gruesome than awesome.
All historical and little drama.
Like its predecessors, it is big, it is loud and it is over-the-top in nearly every respect. It is also patently ridiculous and utterly illogical at every turn.
It's not quite an animated masterpiece, but it's still a fun, sweet-hearted kid-pleaser that boasts some downright lovely animation.
This would be a difficult film even for the charismatic Papa Smith to carry. That he spends nearly the entire movie in a chair doesn't help matters.
It largely lacks that fresh, unexpected wildness of the first film, but as long as that great cast is there to elevate the hit-or-miss script, we're in decent shape.
A lurching, stuttering drama, one whose intentions are far better than its sense of storytelling rhythm.
As hard as it is to watch at times, it's even harder to stop watching Shortland's compelling, well-woven tale of a girl on a dual journey.
A spirited and ripping sci-fi yarn that works every bit as well as that first one -- and, at least on one level, even better.
A dark but powerful cautionary tale that benefits from strong performances from a talented cast.
Craig Robinson has a few funny moments in what is an otherwise painfully generic cookie-cutter comedy.
The story might be familiar, but Berger's film is so beautifully shot and so wonderfully scored - and so distinctively Spanish - that it stands as its own film.
With its satisfying combination of humor, action and dazzling set pieces, Robert Downey Jr. and company provide everything fans of the franchise expect.
It tends to sag a touch in its third act, but it's a solidly engaging thriller thanks mostly to its ridiculously talented cast.
Michael Bay's comedy is energetic and edgy, but the fact that it's all based on a real-life tragedy mutes much of the comic potential.
Set in the world of Piggly-Wigglys, people named Mae Pearl and pickup trucks without tailgates, it's a refreshingly non-condescending Southern-set charmer.
An intriguingly unconventional drama that revels in dreamy interludes, stream-of-consciousness montages and weighty drama - but that never lives up to its stylistic promise.
The gifted Elle Fanning turns in an extraordinary performance, although Sally Potter's film is otherwise built on a flimsy, soap-opera story.
A derivative but elegant sci-fi yarn that boasts dazzling visuals, whiz-bang action sequences and occasional moments of humanity.
It's so straight-forwardly shot as to be unimaginative, but the story is an undeniably inspirational one, complemented by strong production values and a peppering of humor.
With wonderfully drawn -- and acted -- characters, it becomes an engrossing and compelling drama built on a powerful sense of emotion.
Playing like an Inception lite, it requires considerable suspension of disbelief, but it does a nice job of keeping audiences back on their heels.
A darkly comic crowd-pleaser built around a strong cast and sharp writing.
A fascinating doc that will get both film geeks and conspiracy theorists alike drooling, it all but guarantees you'll never watch The Shining quite the same way again.
One of the growing number of documentaries occupying that "elsewhere" separating fact and fiction, it is playful but profound stuff.
It cheapens itself by hitting some self-congratulatory notes, but until it does it covers some fascinating rock 'n' roll ground.
Although it times lacks focus, is sure to be of interest to anyone who regularly follows the bruising sport known as New Orleans politics.
Apted's subjects would object to the idea that we really know them, but we think we do -- and that's good enough to make his film feel like a reunion, a visit with an old friend. Or 14 of them.
There's much grave talk of souls in this sci-fi romance. Ironic, then, that it ends up being such a soulless and trifling affair.
Is it accurate depiction of Africa's child soldiers? I don't know, thank God. But it feels authentic to its very core, and that makes it as hard to forget as it is to ignore.
A pretty disappointment.
It's a strictly no-frills, straight-forwardly shot affair, but the women on which it focuses its lens are endlessly inspiring.
Despite some nice period elements, it's a mostly sparkle-free affair, sticking so closely to the genre blueprint as to be generic.
It moves at its own, often slow pace, but Marion Cotillard gives another great performance and the visual effects that turn her into a double amputee are astonishing.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It is a searing and riveting film, but one that doesn't take the easy way out and give short shrift to the complex emotions at play.
Bill Murray is rarely more than serviceable as FDR in a film that is built around a romance more icky than sweet.
An ugly, disjointed smear of over-the-top melodrama.
Part music documentary, part mystery, all inspirational homage to unrecognized genius everywhere.
It's got its flaws, starting with the fact that the ground it covers is exceedingly well-trodden, but it's amiable and it's honest, and that counts for something.
I just hope that they give Perry his granny wig back for any sequels. Because CSI: Madea seems far more appealing than another film like the slack Alex Cross.
Suprisingly charming family fare, although it is pure formula from start to finish.
Based on a magnificently intricate script ... it benefits immensely from Hitchcock's razor-sharp direction.
This story deserves more than a merely functional telling, which is really all it manages here.
movie_title: United in Anger: A History of ACT UP (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Part political portrait, part Iraq war post-mortem, part interrogation, it's a fascinating look at a man who -- like it or not -- will go down in history.
The uninspired and slapsticky Hotel Transylvania is a textbook example of a movie built around a promising premise but cursed by poor execution.
It's formulaic, it's predictable and it's hokey -- but it also is surprisingly fun, built around a solid cast, unexpected humor and a pop-infused acappella soundtrack.
A slow-burn, Mississippi-set drama that is steeped in atmosphere and a gritty, sweaty sense of place but that suffers from its lack of narrative momentum.
An embraceable tale of childhood mischief, teenage rebellion, award-winning creativity and enduring imagination.
As sturdy as it is stylish -- but most of all flat-out entertaining.
If Moneyball was a stand-up triple, Curve is a ground-rule double -- but predictabilities aside, it's an enjoyable and heart-warming trip round the bases.
A sort of Toy Story as seen through an 8-bit lens.
Anderson's talky and willfully opaque film is far easier to appreciate -- namely for its craftsmanship and performances -- than it is to enjoy.
Unpolished performances are forgivable in they've got a great story to support them. Unfortunately, this is not a great story.
A phoned-in sex comedy that arrives with all the charm and warmth of a wrong number
A rare example of a movie that not only survives its 3-D conversion but benefits from it
Those who said Don DeLillo's book was unfilmable were wrong. This is a film. That much is undeniable. Whether it's a compelling one is a whole other question.
The jokes are never quite funny enough, and the situation -- aside from the sleepwalking gimmick -- doesn't feel quite fresh enough.
Every bit as engaging as it is well-shot, it proves once more that truth is, indeed, stranger than fiction.
Hillcoat's bootlegging drama is a solidly told yarn, but it doesn't last any longer in the brain than the blossoming burn of a swig of clear corn liquor would in the chest.
An unflinchingly ugly -- but downright mesmerizing -- tale that plumbs the depths of human immorality.
This isn't a movie that needs, or even welcomes, neat ends. Rather, it imagines the world as it is: messy, confusing, and rarely ever black and white.
This is empty-calorie stuff, but sometimes empty calories are the most enjoyable calories -- and Premium Rush, like Gordon-Levitt's bike-messenger character, delivers.
For all of its flaws, it achieves its chief goal: to put the pedal to the metal for some good, goofy fun, squealing the tires as often as possible along the way.
This is a film with no heroes, no narrative rhythm, and characters with no morals. As a result, it is also a film with no sense of purpose, no authenticity and no life.
Spielberg knows exactly how the human mind works, and he uses that knowledge to plumb the elemental fear buried deep within.
A raunchy shock comedy through and through, one in which nearly every major laugh involves, in one way or another, male genitalia. Or, in one case, an index finger.
A rote rom-com in disguise.
Like a good magic trick, if you look too hard for the strings, you'll sap it of its enjoyment. But if you sit back and let yourself have fun, it becomes a dandy little yarn.
A simple but affecting slice-of-life drama.
Fueled as much by Daniel Craig's vulnerable portrayal of Bond as its crisp action sequences, Mendes offers a rock-solid entry in the long-running franchise.
As oddly magnetic as Sean Penn's performance is, the film seems more preoccupied with being quirky and puzzling than with telling a cohesive, satisfying story.
It hits on several intriguing ideas, but none are fully developed in what ends up being an aimless, scattered exercise.
A lovely, lyrical film that wondrously captures a very specific time and place -- that is, New Orleans at night, as seen through the eyes of a child.
In addition to being built around a plot that unashamedly rips off 2008's Taken, it's a sloppily assembled example of slapdash filmmaking.
Sort of a kung-fu film through a 'Scott Pilgrim' lens, it is a slight but stylistic romp.
Aside from a lack of journalistic integrity, it's a well-assembled film, one that capitalizes on the charisma of its interview subjects.
Pure entertainment, a no-holds-barred dose of double-barreled escapism, built around great characters, great performances and great dialog.
Van Sant never climbs up on his soapbox, opting instead for a soft-play, lecture-free approach that, while bordering on plainness at times, makes it easy to enjoy the story.
Riveting and rewarding.
An ambitious but satisfying cinematic journey built upon a sense of grandeur -- albeit one coated with alternating layers of grime and tear-jerking emotion
Aside from perhaps Jean-Claude Van Damme and Dolph Lundgren's accountants, it's difficult to say for sure who exactly has been calling for another entry in this francise.
Helped along by a smart script and spot-on performances, it builds toward a nicely crafted emotional crescendo, and one that delivers with it a rich and satisfying payoff.
Tame but thoroughly flat The Guilt Trip is a film whose cleverness begins and ends with that title. Call it the mother of all disappointments.
Yes, Apatow's film has its peaks and valleys -- just the way life does - but it stands as a satisfying comedic riff on life and all of its absurdities.
Among the most beautiful shorts to come out of Disney in recent memory.
It is great to once more be whisked back to Tolkien's extraordinarily vivid world, but Jackson's overstuffed film proves that it is possible to get too much of a good thing.
As frustratingly opaque as Carax's art film is, Denis Lavant is fantastic in the lead role, as he portrays character after character, all with the utmost credibility.
It's not the definitive biography diehards might be longing for, but it is an enjoyable lark that weaves fact and fiction, with a dash of old-Hollywood nostalgia thrown in.
Not only is it a mob movie with intelligence, but it oozes modern relevance from its every pore.
Director Joe Wright's undeniably fresh approach helps smooth the wrinkles in a film that suffers from uneven storytelling.
Expertly researched, brilliantly argued and masterfully assembled, it is also easily the documentary of the year.
A sobering, sentimental journey through crumbling Detroit -- but one lacking any real intellectual punch.
An Oscar-ready historical masterpiece that does double duty as a history lesson and as a reminder of the paralytic limitations of a house divided.
An inspiring tale that celebrates the human spirit, underscores the value of connections, and laughs at the beautifully embarrassing urges that make us what we are.
A narrative-starved acid trip of a film, an amalgam of animated styles and anecdotes that never gel, seldom make sense and rarely generate genuine laughs.
movie_title: A Liar's Autobiography - The Untrue Story of Monty Python's Graham Chapman (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An enjoyable diversion, a lightweight bit of philosophizing that blends humor with the bittersweet.
An ode to the wonder of childhood, a salute to the importance of preserving it, and both a love-letter to and an example of the power of imagination.
A wonderfully satisfying cinematic journey built upon big ideas -- and timely ones, too, delivering a message of understanding in this frustrating age of great intolerance.
An intelligent and well-crafted film that seeks to inspire audiences by finding the humor amid the prevailing bittersweetness of life.
This is still a silly, unapologetically melodramatic - and at times unintentionally funny - teen soap opera, and one that is made for fans and only fans. Which I still am not.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It feels a bit like a classed-up infomercial at times, but it's still as much a treat to witness Bennett's process as it is to see him interact with today's young stars.
Dennis Quaid turns in a strong performance, but writer-director Ramin Bahrani's earnest but unfocused melodrama offers neither a compelling storyline nor a satisfying message.
A strikingly original and delightfully offbeat gem, and one that is, indeed, alive -- alive!
A sneakily affecting and entirely pleasant movie elevated by its cast.
It takes a bit of patience to sit through the slow opening act. But those who do will find themselves held captive by Flanagan's unsettling story.
Beneath the sheen of sweat on his actors and between the frequent scenes of frantic and entangled limbs, there's substance to Von Trier's tale.
A film that functions just as nicely as a political thriller as it does as an action movie, and which arrives as a big, loud and highly polished dose of popcorn-munching fun.
There are fun moments (Bret MacKenzie's musical numbers stand out), but there are too many lulls in the nearly 2-hour running time, and too many opportunities for ordinariness to creep in.

When people say, 'They don't make movies like that anymore,' they are wrong. Wes Anderson makes movies like that anymore, and 'The Grand Budapest Hotel' -- part comedy caper, part adventure, and all quirky, embraceable whimsy -- is proof.
Combining enough of the characteristic wiseassery of Penn & Teller with a dose of scholarly research on an age-old art-world mystery, it is at once entertaining and edifying.
There are moments of guilty-pleasure fun in Scott Waugh's video-game-inspired stunt-fest, but mostly it's little more than a ridiculous Fast & Furious wannabe.
There's nothing strikingly original about Non-Stop, but it does show that Neeson, even when on autopilot, still knows exactly how to hold down an action film.
Even if it doesn't quite capture the magic of some of his earlier films, The Wind Rises feels like one of Miyazaki's more personal films.
Never strikes a resoundingly false note -- which is a precious thing in movies lately -- and as such is a film that promises moving rewards.
There's a lot wrong with this movie, but there are things it does right. Just when you think things have gone irretrievably off the rails, Costner manages to hold it together.
Even when it includes a dose of dark humor and an admirable sense of craftsmanship, watching other people alter their state of consciousness is rarely a rewarding experience.
Kevin Hart and Regina Hall do a nice job of providing the comedy in this raunchy remake, but there's little else there in what ends up a mostly forgettable film.
A stirring tribute to democracy and those willing to fight for it.
Thank you for your regurgitation.
A slow-starting Army jeep of a film that sputters charmingly to life on occasion but that never quite roars they way one would like.
Not only does it work nicely as a slice-of-life narrative, but it also serves as a subtle study of the endemic hopelessness in America's inner cities.
As handsome as it is, and scandalous as the affair was in its time, it all comes off feeling rather tame in what ends up being a largely inert exercise.
It is at turns sweet, romantic, funny and heartbreaking. More than anything, though, it's just plain affecting, a profound tale of love, loss and -- in the end -- life, in all its bitter beauty.
Fans of Kevin Hart's brand of motormouthed silliness will find some laughs here, but it's otherwise a sloppy, forgettable affair.
It's a nice-looking film, particularly for an independent animated film, but there's just no spark there to elevate beyond something anyone over 8 years old will appreciate.
A unfailingly intense look into what life -- and death -- is like for America's fighting men and women.
An actor's playground, filled with meaty roles and juicy dialog. Every character gets at least one moment in the spotlight, and every actor in Wells' adaptation seizes it.
It boasts a number of wonderfully written profundities, but there's little connective tissue to bind them. The result often feels more like a beautifully appointed bulletin board than a grand mural.
Scorsese's focus isn't so much on telling a tight story as chronicling Belfort's outsized antics, but they're not there just for laughs. This is at its root a cautionary tale.
The Coens don't always require, or even seem to value, plot Fortunately, Inside Llewyn Davis, with its great writing and music, doesn't need much of one.
Practically perfect in every way.
A great deal more fun than most Oscar hopefuls allow themselves to be. Think Goodfellas, but with bad comb-overs. And perms. And yards of corduroy and crushed velour.
An admirably comprehensive film about a frustratingly hard-to-pin-down man, and a postmortem to one of the most heartbreaking betrayals of fans that the sports world has seen.
It can be counted on to deliver a temporary football fix and a few chuckles, but it's not quite enough to make die-hards stop counting down the days until the real NFL Draft.
The fight sequences -- brutal though they are -- are nothing short of brilliant, standing as creatively choreographed and masterfully shot snatches of athletic showmanship.
With gorgeous cinematography and playful narration from John C. Reilly, it's a Goldilocks film -- one that will juuust right for mamma bears, papa bears and baby bears alike.
A deeply atmospheric and thrillingly unconventional movie, one that is unlike any I can recall.
As well-argued as it is, it lacks any real personality -- and so getting people to listen will be a challenge.
There are a few good, R-rated laughs, thanks largely to a cast that makes the most of the material at hand. Still, it ends up being more amusing than outright hilarious.
A small, offbeat dramatic comedy that deftly -- and humorously -- explores touchy territory.
Thanks largely to the involvement of actor Tom Hardy, it manages to become more than just a gimmick film.
Almost Almost Famous.
Not even the tightly wound energy of Kevin Hart can help it from feeling half-baked, through and through. This isn't a movie so much as it is a studio cash-grab.
It's warped, it's frantic, it's dark -- and it's an entertaining bit of guilty-pleasure, midnight-movie craziness
Think Before Midnight crossed with The Out-of-Towners and you're somewhere in the ballpark.
An well-researched and informative (if straight-forwardly shot) blend of history and nostalgia.
movie_title: Going Attractions: The Definitive Story of the American Drive-in Movie (2013)

movie_review_blurb: There's something brilliant in the way directors Lord and Miller subvert Hollywood, studios and even their own audience in the rare sequel that is equal to its predecessor.
It doesn't start with the words 'once upon a time,' but it really should. It's just that storybook-sweet, that gentle, that comforting of a film.
It is a suspenseful, surprise-filled thriller, even if it suffers from a deeply rooted identity crisis.
Yes, it crosses lines. Yes, it works hard to offend. Yes, it is silly. But you know what? It's also laugh-out-loud funny. And isn't that the point?
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It has its storytelling flaws, but if nothing else, Maleficent is an undeniable work of visual beauty.
Where An Unexpected Journey felt disjointed and flabby, The Desolation of Smaug much more effectively captures the sense of adventure of Tolkien's quest story.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It might suffer from a conventional approach and a pat ending, but it's still a reasonably sturdy period drama, one that hinges on the lead performance of Gugu Mbatha-Raw.
Both Nicolas Cage and director David Gordon Green get back to doing what they do best in this backwoods Southern yarn.
It's conventional, dutifully touching all the bases on its way around the pre-established formula, but it succeeds anyway thanks to its considerable charm and oversized heart.
Can a person be two things at once? Yes. Not only is it possible, but it can be of value. Lustiger proved that,and The Jewish Cardinal underscores it.
As handsome and as literary as Jim Jarmusch's agonizingly slow film is, its assets carry it only so far.
A slow-to-develop but nonetheless tantalizing sampling of the depth of Kristen Wiig's talent, one that hints at what may to come from her.
It's not a film that will stick to your ribs to any great degree, but it is a quiet charmer, one that ends up being a pleasant enough diversion for grown-up audiences.
Rogen and his talented co-stars deliver a raunchy but entertaining comic diversion, one that is equally good-natured and bad-behaving.
A slick but limp farce that illustrates how a good premise and a good cast aren't worth a whit if they don't have a strong enough script to back them up.
In Amazing Spider-Man 2, Marc Webb offers an exceedingly enjoyable superhero sequel that benefits both from an appealing lead actor and a daring sense of storytelling.
All three acts boast decidedly different emotional tones, but Teplitzky knits them together into a memorable whole.
Over the years, a certain mystique has surrounded Friedkin's dark tale, as is so often the case with lost films. Unlike many of them, though, Sorcerer delivers.
A movie strictly for the already-converted fans of Marlon Wayans' brand of decidedly off-color, so-stupid-it's-funny big-screen goofballery.
Jude Law shines, disappearing into the lead role of what ends up being a rowdy and giddy blend of style and attitude.
This is a charming crowd-pleaser that is made with love -- just like the food in the titular lunchbox. Better yet, it's just as delectable.

A film that feeds the heart and soul - and will make you want to feed your face when it is done. In fact, make your dinner reservations for after the movie. Otherwise, you're just going to end up eating twice.
As he did with Crazy Heart, Cooper populates his even bleaker Out of the Furnace with a talented cast that helps elevate his portrait of gravel-road America.
A fascinating and inspiring documentary that offers a tantalizing look at what could have been.
A delightful little seven-minute romp.
With a characteristically strong performance from Forest Whitaker and a nicely crafted script from Danny Strong, it serves up a nice slice of historical drama.
Functioning as a better sequel to Cars than does Cars 2, it will undoubtedly accomplish what it sets out to accomplish: rev the engines of millions of ka-chowing spitfires.
The stakes in this latest, disappointing Harry Potter wannabe never feel as high as they should, or as important as its characters seem to think they are.
The on-screen chemistry between Mark Wahlberg and Denzel Washington goes a long way, although it can't entirely hide the fact that this is boilerplate stuff.
It's a briskly paced thriller boasting the expected summertime flourishes: chase scenes, fight scenes, futuristic dystopian obstacles. But it strives to be something more.
It offers plenty of chortles, chuckles and guffaws for those who appreciate Rogen and company's brand of hard-partying but soft-hearted storytelling
It will do what it sets out to do -- to entertain younger kids without driving their parents nuts -- but the bar isn't set very high here.
There's no reason why a superhero film can't dabble in darkness, but in the process Snyder forgets to make his movie fun.
It's a sweet and well-cast film, but it's also unevenly paced and never quite rises above mediocrity.
A tragically relevant and incredibly important film that deserves all the attention it can get from American audiences.
A rock 'n' roll fairy tale, well-told.
It's compelling stuff, a film that starts out as one thing but subtly shifts to become something else entirely.
An unconventional but wonderfully assembled exploration of how -- and why -- we tell stories, all wrapped in a closely guarded family secret.
It might sound like well-covered ground - you know: hopelessly awkward kid struggles to transition from boyhood to manhood - but it's a compelling and surprisingly sweet ride.
The letters in the title might stand for 'Retired, Extremely Dangerous' -- but they could just as well stand for 'Retread, Extremely Derivative.'
Sloppily edited, poorly plotted and overly derivative, it puts the 'R.I.P.' in 'ripoff.'
A phoned-in ode to lazy comedy and staggering stupidity.
It's a touch bloated, but it just might be the most enjoyable Pirates of the Caribbean movie since the first one. (Yes, I said Pirates of the Caribbean.)
The rare animated sequel that rivals the brightness and enjoyability of its predecessor.
An oddly amiable horror-farce that plays like a cross between 1990's Misery and 2012's Tucker and Dale vs. Evil.
Khalfoun generates a handful of moments of stomach-knotting intensity, but this ultimately a gimmick film -- and the gimmick doesn't work.

Some film student or sociologist will have a field day dissecting what it says about Americans' view of their government in 2013 that we blew up the White House not once but twice in a three-month period. In the meantime, though, pass the popcorn.
Not only is it nicely paced, but it features gripping moments of intensity, as well as some impressive visual effects.
The ripped-from-the-headlines story is interesting on its own, but Coppola ups the ante by using it as a springboard for a treatise on our celebrity-obsessed culture.
There will be movies with bigger casts, louder explosions and more zombies -- but few will boast the sheer spirit of The Kings of Summer.
Far more Cars 2 than Up, it is cute -- but no more than cute.
Hawke and Delpy inhabit these characters with such ease and credibility that it takes no effort to become emotionally invested in their story.
It's built around an intriguing and relevant premise, one that is further buoyed by strong performances from its cast.

Most normal people will not see this as a "pleasant" film -- I hope that's the case, anyway -- but it certain makes you feel something. And, as moviegoing experiences go, that's better than feeling nothing.
It's heart is in the right place, but -- with poor writing, lame humor and dreadful on-court sequences -- that's one of the only things right about it.
Strong performances complement the smart and engrossing script and a slowly building tension that blossoms to a piano-string tautness.
Daring though it is, it follows the same trajectory as the wounded plane aboard which the film is set. That is, it circles and circles but never really goes anywhere.
An odd but riveting film that slowly peels back the veneer of one man's tough-guy image and illustrates the very real psychic toll of murder.
Despicable Me 2 will likely go down as the year's highest-grossing animated film, but Frozen is the most complete we've seen so far in 2013.
Krokidas seems more intent on setting a mood than telling a story, and in creating a feeling than building suspense.
Ken Scott's uneven story suffers through its narrative stumbles, but it overcomes its flaws thanks to an embraceable dose of heart and the loveable-lump charisma of Vaughn.
Thanks to McConaughey, we get to see a character not just grow but evolve, developing a soul before our eyes. And if he can evolve, well, then there's hope for the rest of us.
It isn't without its charms, including an appealing cast and high production values. Unfortunately, all that's overshadowed by its inability to convincingly find emotional truths.
It's smart and sweet and unabashedly sentimental. But it's also the kind of movie that - in spite of its faults - strikes a bright, resonant wind-chime of a note.
It's all built around so much clanging of swords and denting of armor, but lacking that spark of life that the Avengers family of films is built upon.
It gets off to a brisk enough start and maintains that momentum for the most part, even if it forgets to have fun in the process.
McQueen makes the theater drapes melt away, immersing audiences in a story that will make them feel like witnesses to history.
As intriguing as it is to see Stallone and Schwarzenegger together, it fails to measure up to the better films in the genre, offering only moments of fun here and there.
It doesn't go very far out of its way to tell more than one side of the story, but the one side of the story that it does tell is an exceedingly compelling and moving one.
A technical and storytelling masterpiece buoyed by stunning visuals and functioning both as a ripping, tension-filled yarn and as a profound and life-affirming work of art.
It's not just a thoroughly enjoyable movie that benefits from a funny, well-humored script, but it's a lovely way to remember the late, great James Gandolfini.
Built around unimaginative direction and an even less imaginative script, it's a textbook example of a formula film. Still, there are minor charms to be found.
A smartly assembled film fueled as much by surprising moments of heart and humor as it is by high-octane, pedal-to-the-metal sports action.
The surprise is that it's a surprise in the first place, as Greengrass takes a story we all know and turns it into one of the most enjoyable and well-made movies of the year.
Shailene Woodley and Miles Teller are, well, spectacular in the lead roles, helping to elevate what could easily have been a standard coming-of-age drama.
To climb aboard the colorful La Camioneta is to be taken on a lyrical journey - both anthropological and philosophical - to a place most of us would never be able to visit.
movie_title: La Camioneta: The Journey of One American School Bus (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It aims to entertain, to offer a few tame chuckles for parents and children to enjoy in a purely Saturday-morning way. And it accomplishes that.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A magnetic but heartbreaking performance from Cate Blanchet as a woman adrift rescues Woody Allen's often rudderless tragi-comedy.
A fascinating and exhaustively researched portrait of a fascinating man.
Both playful and nostalgic, it's the kind of movie that stands to be appreciated on some level by anyone who has ever pointed a stick and yelled, Powpowpow!
A Bonnie & Clyde-informed tale of passion amid the criminal class, it's a film of considerable visual beauty, even lyricism.
A fat, juicy cherry on top of a memorably madcap trilogy.
At its best moments, Hess' film is merely cute, but never more -- and often less.
It might have felt at home alongside various overly lurid thrillers from the late 1980s and early 1990s. Now, however, it feels only cheap and passe.
Part musical history lesson, part performance film and part character study -- all of which combines to become its own song of hope and inspiration.
For anyone who has actually created something -- or been frustrated by their inability to do so -- Fernando Trueba's film stands to offer a dose of quiet resonance.
movie_title: El artista y la modelo (The Artist and the Model) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It boasts tons of atmosphere and flashes of Refn's visual style -- as well as an admirably unhinged performance from Kristen Scott Thomas -- but little else to recommend.
As commendable as Wong's film is at visualizing things, it's far less proficient at contextualizing them.
A contemplative experimental drama, it also invites moviegoers to take a deep breath, to relax, and to float along in its leisurely exploration of leisurely exploration.
This is more than ethnography, and much more than social gesture; this is moviemaking at its eye-opening, startling best.
The Invitation wants to be a slow burn thriller, but it greatly over estimates how much tension it creates.
Well-shot and well-edited violence porn.
M. Night Shyamalan is one of the most consistently interesting auteurs in contemporary American cinema. Split is further evidence.
A brutally honest family drama that boasts a pair of great lead performances.
Funny, scary and with its heart in the right place.
Ultimately, Fantastic Four comes off as a laboured setup to a sequel that's predictably already in the works. That, of course, raises another mammoth question: who the hell will want to see it?

Get past the buckets and buckets of blood in The Hateful Eight, and there's a good argument to be made that -- once the shock value has worn off -- this is Quentin Tarantino at his most philosophical and clever.
If your family made a complete mess of you, it's nice to know that you're anything but alone.
Gimme Danger is content to be a sanitized history lesson -- the last thing you'd expect from [this] band.
Although genuine frights are in short supply, there's plenty of gory goodness to compensate.
Allied's ultimate triumph? That would be making us long for that long-gone time captured in the film.
You can learn a lot about a culture by people-watching.
The genius of Quest is that-perhaps much like life-you're never quite sure where it's going to go.
Nobody enjoys spending time with the relentlessly self-absorbed, so who is the target audience for Vers la Tendresse?
The man never pretended to be a saint. Too bad All Eyez on Me treats him like one.

Smartly, director Leo Scherman never goes for laughs in this sepia-toned period piece, instead creating a sense of 78-feet-below-ground claustrophobia that finds middle ground between The Thing and The Descent.
Prepare to be moved.
Resembles more the bulk of war movies before Vietnam than it does anything made in the last quarter-century.

The Watcher's hemmed-in, pervasively technological urbanscape only allows for one superstitious -- though maybe not entirely irrational -- belief: that the one who photographs you can steal your soul.
If you like intentionally offensive comedy, then parts of Me, Myself & Irene will undoubtedly make you laugh.
For audience members familiar with the story, the protagonists' journey is liable to feel like a simple, and dull, waiting game.
It's a pretty funny movie, and thinking about all this too much while seeing it will just ruin all the jokes.
We're stuck, the movie seems to say. Men and women: this is simply how we are.
The sad story of the dinosaurs is one of the few Walt Disney got right the first time.
As an occasionally somber meditation on the toll war takes on the human soul, it's not without its moments.
Suffers from a halting execution.
Hackneyed script and posterboard characters

All questions of religious symbolism aside, if you think about Illuminati, eyes, and triangles, while looking at the back of a dollar bill (right over where it says, you may get a better sense of which Almighty this movie really worships.
Utterly nauseating.
Quote not available.
By using metal primarily to promote values at odds with the music's expressed philosophies ... it sadly misses an opportunity to be much more vivid and compelling than it is.
A sincere picture, with a lot of interesting, ambitious writing that these blips mostly punctuate.
There's a reach on the part of Abattoir's makers that exceeds their grasp.
NEKROMANTIK is first and foremost a blatant and childish (though successful) attempt to disgust the most jaded conceivable audience, and doesn't have many aspirations beyond this.
[The] subtext of childhood trauma that makes Faster, Pussycat a subtler movie than you might expect.
We Are the Flesh is a work of art masquerading as an atrocity.
movie_title: We Are the Flesh (Tenemos la carne) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Absolutely does not give a f*** about conventional film narration... spins a yarn with the deviant coherence of a paranoid fantasy or a death-bed vision.
Peguri did the soundtrack for this film, and I mention him by name so that you will know to beat him senseless if you happen to see him in the street.
movie_title: Il Boia scarlatto (Bloody Pit of Horror)(The Scarlet Hangman)(A Tale of Torture) (1965)

movie_review_blurb: yet another of those low-budget sexploitation films whose most interesting aspect is its accidents
A Blair Witch-inspired mockumentary that, while based on a brilliant premise, is disappointingly bumpy nonetheless.
Any fool can make a movie that's just frankly obscene, but it takes an edge of intelligence to make a film that crosses the line into the unspeakably abominable. DRILLER KILLER is such a film.
The movie is not a parody or even a spoof. Instead, Date Movie is under the impression that if it mentioned a romantic comedy or uses the same exact joke from a movie, then it's funny.
Who doesn't like a good Charlie Sheen / Viagra gag? I mean, besides Heidi Fleiss...
Failure to Launch in a nutshell: constantly inching past your wildly low expectations.
The World's Fastest Indian isn't so much a story about breaking records and gauging speed as it is about the kindness of strangers and the ultimate road trip.

It doesn't know whether it wants to be a Skin-e-max soft core porno or an episode of a primetime cop drama. It's unfulfilling as neither and ends up as an awful hybrid: we'll call it CSI: Cleavageville. I take that back: CSI: Faux Cleavageville.
Leguizamo's wispy voice work shows that creating compelling animated characters takes more than just placing a sitcom star in front of a mic. Yes, I'm looking at you, David Schwimmer.
Nick Naylor is a much cooler Spin Doctor than the ones who sang Little Miss Can't be Wrong back in 1991.
In an age when surprise endings and indie budgets are hip and trendy, it's nice to get a decent throwback thriller. The script may be manufactured, but the sweat stains are real.
United 93 is a tactful eulogy that could have been ravaged by a Jerry Bruckheimer-esque production of fiery explosions, Aerosmith tracks and Ben Affleck cameos.

Kinky Boots is a rare and unassuming tale about everyday folk, or shall I say blokes, who climb out of their comfort zones to change their lives for the better without the help of Richard Simmons or Tony Robbins.
Art School Confidential ain't a big screen Picasso, but it's also not that ceramic ashtray you made in third grade.

Sandler has rightfully transitioned from annoying frat dude who got lucky to affable everyman who even cries every once in a while, although I'm guessing he needs the prop guy to slice an onion to get the job done.
Hanks' Harvard symbologist alter ego is about as bland as a bowl of cold oatmeal, but it's not his fault %u2013 he's given less dialogue to work with than a Cirque de Soleil mime.

Watching the actors is like watching Elton John try to make out with Anne Heche. They go through the motions in a totally disingenuous display, except Wolverine doesn't break out into an impromptu "Rocket Man" to ease the awkwardness.
What ultimately makes The Break-Up so good and refreshing is its firm denial of the "chick flick" stamp of approval.
Nothing can be something when your characters are actually characters, and they hem and haw about life's simple pleasures and problems in attitudes ranging from blasé to charmingly quixotic.

Part awkward yet surprisingly funny stand-up comedian, part wily environmentalist, whether you like Gore or hate'm, the last thing word you would use to describe Gore in his new documentary is "boring."

Freedomland is a garbled, ripped-from-the-headlines mess of Susan Smith meets the L.A. riots. If you're mad that I've spoiled the ending, than I won't further ruin your day by telling you what happens after you wind up a jack-in-the-box...
Fun to watch but ultimately empty, Tom Cruise has found his most fitting metaphor in MI:3.
Look what the cat dragged in...
Despite the characters' authentic ghetto jet-setting, Rent the movie can't move the audience like its live stage brother, or maybe I should say sister.

Some criticize Jarhead for ambivalence and ambiguity. But that's what Swofford's experience was about.

movie_review_blurb: The undercooked Chicken Little is a strain of cinematic salmonella, riddled with forced fun and forgettable characters.
Did I miss the ballyhoo, or is this the least anticipated sequel since Big Brother 6?

Never before has "space camp" been such a good compliment and such a bad pun.

Superman Returns flawlessly repackages charismatic characters, further dips into the Man of Steel's mythology and adds effects that weren't available 20 years ago without doing a George Lucas-esque animation overkill.
Pat Robertson will clearly be surfing Fandango.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: After LOTR, Jackson could have done Kangaroo Jack II and he still would have been a legend. But he tried to up the ante and create a picture as vast and as charismatic as his award-winning trilogy.
The Family Stone carries itself like a shotgun wedding at a drive-through Vegas wedding chapel. The romance is rushed, but it's pretty darn entertaining.
Dick and Jane is running the ball on third down, asking your ex to the prom or attending junior college. It's a safety flick, and nothing else.
Watching Steve Martin in Cheaper by the Dozen 2 is like watching Emeril manning the kitchen at Arbys.
Maybe it's fitting that, at times, Steven Spielberg's nearly three-hour take on the tragedy of the 1972 Munich Olympic Games moves along like an agonizing death march.

You have to give credit to a movie that focuses 90 percent of its energy on video game and ganja jokes. Even if you make the best movie ever, gamers and tokers are perhaps the two least motivated groups to get out and see a movie.
Where was Stephen A. Smith when you needed him?

Match Point crafts the beginning of a better than average fish-out-of-water tale, bores us for an hour with a milquetoast affair, then gives us a wild sucker punch of an ending that even a Nostradamus / John Edward tag team couldn't predict.
For a movie that aspires to capture the magic of a classic fairy tale, Nanny McPhee has all the warmth and charm of the assembly instructions for an Ikea bookshelf.
An open letter to the filmmakers of the worst movie I've ever seen in my life...
Walk into the theater wearing jean shorts, a popped collar or anything taken off the rack from T J Maxx, and Meryl Streep is likely to jump off the screen and slap you across the face.

Waitress exists in a fictional film universe that many movies strive for but few actually reach, where slightly off-kilter characters are dropped into bizarre circumstances and the whole thing feels far from contrived.

Guillermo Del Toro has achieved a rare success in crafting a mature movie with some of the ingredients that make a good bedtime story. But good luck sleeping after taking in Pan's Labyrinth.
Considering a cast that also touts Ben Affleck and Wayne Newton, Smokin' Aces should have been a veritable bachelor party of guilty pleasures. It's got guns, casinos, girls, drugs and Piven.
Volver is far from a paint-by-numbers, Mad Lib of a movie, but rather a fresh and touching exploration of family, tragedy and second chances.

Do the ghosts of fart jokes, high-pitched voices and biting his lip while slummin' with Chris Farley on "SNL" still linger for Sandler? Nope.
A true ice queen sandwich!

Shrek does what he does best: pop culture shout-outs, irreverent humor that's too high-brow to infect the kiddies, and still enough slapstick and classic cartoon nonsense to keep those wee ones happy, too.

Two hours into this 150-minute behemoth, the worst fears of most moviegoers are confirmed. It's essentially a teaser for the next Pirates flick.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

Outfitted with more bloated southern stereotypes than the parking lot at Shoney's and bursting with red, white and blue, Ricky Bobby is a southern superhero who's both charismatic and cavalier.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: One thing would have made World Trade Center better - having Ann Coulter next to me being forced to watch the new Sept. 11 dirge with her eyelids taped back and her hands shackled to the seat - a la Stanley Kubrick's A Clockwork Orange.

You're going to The Protector for the skull fractures and sky-high knees to the groin. And if this is all you're after, your mind may be black and blue, but you'll be all smiles by the end.

Some of the acting is stiffer than the only one not drinking at an Irish Wake, but Flags of our Fathers is a rare historical snapshot that, true or not, is as honest a movie that you'll find these days.

Reviewing Borat is kind of like doing an autopsy on a clown. Some scenes are borderline awkwardly unbearable, but then you look down and see the bright red nose or big floppy shoes (or in this case a yellow thong bathing suit). And you laugh.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: As a rule, it's usually a good sign when Smith doesn't have a Top-40 hip-hop track featured prominently in the movie that more or less repeats the film's title over and over again.

Here...special effects artists create giant, menacing robots and cool fighter planes without getting high on super glue or stabbing themselves with pipe cleaners.

...its commercial pimping puts a NASCAR rig to shame, but Shark Tale is pretty, fun and smart.

The vocal stylings of Duff are particularly laughable...It's artificial, it's bad, it's a falsetto Max Headroom.
Hilarious...I can't give out more information without committing a hate crime.
Shall we Dance is a chick flick jack-in-the-box. In the beginning it elicits wide appeal...then suddenly morphs into Lifetime fare...

First off, it's never good when Cheech Marin is in a movie and it's not about weed.

Just Like Heaven works desipte its hokey gimmick.
Forrest Gump always said that stupid is as stupid does...some of Junebug's strange folk would respond to that platitude with a resounding "huh?"

With no real heroes, no real lessons and no real resolution, it leaves a lingering sense of 'huh?' But damnit if those exit wounds aren't memorable.

movie_review_blurb: If Shark Tale was Shrek Light, then Madagascar is Shrek Dry.
Unlike other flicks of the genre, The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants doesn't rely on a patched up story or hand-me-down characters.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

Paul Giamatti steals the show as Braddock's smart-*** trainer and manager, Joe Gould. Maybe it's his Oscar comeuppance.

It's like a poor man's Neverending Story or an after-school special with an identity crisis.
movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Schumacher had suffocated the franchise with so much cheese and camp that even Adam West wanted to give the director a WAM! POW!! SOK!!!
Ferrell does what he does best, which is act like a four-year-old with ADD on the morning after Halloween.

If you're 13 years old, you'll love it. If you're 40, you'll love it. If you're 40 and watching it at the theater beside your 13-year-old, you'll hate it.

Will it make up its $175 million budget? Maybe with some divine intervention. Seriously. I wouldn't be surprised to see buses unloading smiling families and frenzied Young Lifers hitting up theaters for the first time since Mel Gibson told them to.

Bay's best effort by far. The robot thespians are better actors than the cast of Armageddon and the plot is probably more historically accurate than Pearl Harbor.
